('34', 0, 1, 2, 44) 1. SATYAGRAHA IN SOUTH AFRICA 1
('34', 0, 2, 3, 76) FOREWORD
('34', 0, 3, 4, 85) Shri Valji Desai’s translation has been revised by me, and I can assure the reader that the spirit of the original in Gujarati has been very faithfuly kept by the translator.
('34', 0, 3, 5, 260) The original chapters were all written by me from memory.
('34', 0, 3, 6, 318) They were written partly in the Yeravda jail and partly outside after my premature release.
('34', 0, 3, 7, 410) As the translator knew of this fact, he made a diligent study of the file of Indian Opinion and wherever he discovered slips of memory, he has not hesitated to make the necessary corrections.
('34', 0, 3, 8, 602) The reader will share my pleasure that in no relevant or material paricular has there been any slip.
('34', 0, 3, 9, 703) I need hardly mention that those who are following the weekly chapters of My Experiments with Truth cannot afford to miss these chapters on satyagraha, if they would follow in all its detail the working out of the search after Truth.
('34', 0, 3, 10, 937) M. K. GANDHI SABARMATI 26th April, 1928 2
('34', 0, 4, 11, 979) 1 Gandhiji started writing in Gujarati the historty of Satyagraha in South Africa on November 26, 1923, when he was in the Yeravda Central Jail; vide “Jail Diary, 1923.” By the time he was released, on February 5, 1924, he had completed 30 chapters.
('34', 0, 4, 12, 1229) The chapters of Dakshina Africana Satyagrahano Itihas, as it was entitled, appeared serially in the issues of the Navajivan, beginning on April 13, 1924, and ending on November 22, 1925. The preface to the first part was written at Juhu, Bombay, on April 2, 1924; that to the second appeared in Navajivan, 5 7 1925. The work was published in book form in two parts in 1924 and 1925, with a dedication to Maganlal K. Gandhi.
('34', 0, 4, 13, 1653) The English translation by Valji G. Desai, which was seen and approved by Gandhiji, was published by S. Ganesan, Madras, in 1928. It carried only the preface to the first part of the Gujarati original.
('34', 0, 4, 14, 1855) The translation carried a foreword by Gandhiji.
('34', 0, 4, 15, 1903) A revised second edition was issued by Navajivan Publishing House, Ahmedabad, in December 1950. The publishers brought out a third impression in August 1961. The translator acknowledged having received helpful suggestions from Verrier Elwin, C. F. Andrews, Kaka Kalelkar and Abhechand G. Desai.
('34', 0, 4, 16, 2198) The text reproduced here is that of the third impression.
('34', 0, 4, 17, 2256) In the foot notes, “source” stands for this third impression of the English translation, while “original” stands for the Gujarati original.
('34', 0, 4, 18, 2396) 2 Though the foreword bears this date, it is reproduced here and not placed in chronological order.
('34', 1, 0, 1, 2496) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 2
('34', 1, 1, 2, 2536) PREFACE
('34', 1, 2, 3, 2544) The satyagraha struggle of the Indians in South Africa lasted eight years.
('34', 1, 2, 4, 2619) The term satyagraha was invented and employed in connection therewith.
('34', 1, 2, 5, 2690) I had long entertained a desire to write a history of that struggle myself.
('34', 1, 2, 6, 2766) Some things only I could write.
('34', 1, 2, 7, 2798) Only the general who conducts a campaign can know the objective of each particular move.
('34', 1, 2, 8, 2887) And as this was the first attempt to apply the principle of satyagraha to politics on a large scale, it is necessary any day that the public should have an idea of its development.
('34', 1, 2, 9, 3068) But today satyagraha has had ample scope in India.
('34', 1, 2, 10, 3119) Here there has been an inevitable series of struggles beginning with the rather local question of the Viramgam customs.
('34', 1, 3, 11, 3239) It was through the instrumentality of Bhai Motilal, the public spirited good tailor of Wadhvan, that I became interested in the Viramgam question.
('34', 1, 3, 12, 3386) I had just arrived from England and was proceeding to Saurashtra in the year 1915. I was travelling third class.
('34', 1, 3, 13, 3499) At Wadhvan station Motilal came up to me with a small party.
('34', 1, 3, 14, 3560) He gave me some account of the hardships inflicted on the people at Viramgam, and said: “Please do something to end this trouble.
('34', 1, 3, 15, 3690) It will be doing an immense service to Saurashtra, the land of your birth.” There was an expression of both compassion and firmness in his eyes.
('34', 1, 4, 16, 3835) “Are you ready to go to jail?” I asked.
('34', 1, 4, 17, 3875) “We are ready to march to the gallows,” was the quick reply.
('34', 1, 4, 18, 3936) “Jail will do for me,” I said.
('34', 1, 4, 19, 3967) “But see that you do not leave me in the lurch.” “That only time can show,” said Motilal.
('34', 1, 5, 20, 4057) I reached Rajkot, obtained detailed information and commenced correspondence with Government.
('34', 1, 5, 21, 4151) In speeches at Bagasra and elsewhere, I dropped a hint that the people should be ready to offer satyagraha at Viramgam if necessary.
('34', 1, 5, 22, 4284) The loyal C. I. D. brought these speeches to the notice of Government.
('34', 1, 5, 23, 4355) In this they served Government and, unintentionally, served the people also.
('34', 1, 5, 24, 4432) Finally, I had a talk with
('34', 1, 6, 25, 4459) 1 Customs duties were levied at Viramgam and elsewhere from persons entering British India from Kathiawar, ostensibly to prevent smuggling of goods from foreign countries.
('34', 1, 6, 26, 4631) The customs cordon was abolished in November 1917; also, An Autobiography, Pt. V, Ch. III.
('34', 2, 0, 1, 4722) VOL. 34 : 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 3
('34', 2, 1, 2, 4766) Lord Chelmsford on the matter.
('34', 2, 1, 3, 4797) He promised abolition of the customs line and was as good as his word.
('34', 2, 1, 4, 4868) I know others also tried for this.
('34', 2, 1, 5, 4903) But I am strongly of opinion that the imminent possibility of satyagraha was the chief factor in obtaining the desired redress.
('34', 2, 2, 6, 5031) Then came the Indian Emigration Act.
('34', 2, 2, 7, 5068) Great efforts were put forth to get indenture repealed.
('34', 2, 2, 8, 5124) There was a considerable public agitation.
('34', 2, 2, 9, 5167) The Bombay meeting fixed May 31, 1917, as the date from which onwards indentured labour should be stopped.
('34', 2, 2, 10, 5274) 1 This is not the place for narrating how that particular date came to be selected.
('34', 2, 2, 11, 5358) A deputation of ladies first waited upon the Viceroy in connection with this.
('34', 2, 2, 12, 5436) I cannot help mentioning here the name of the high souled sister, Mrs. Jaiji Petit.
('34', 2, 2, 13, 5520) It was she who may be said to have organized this deputation.
('34', 2, 2, 14, 5582) Here, too, success came merely through preparedness for satyagraha.
('34', 2, 2, 15, 5650) But it is important to remember the distinction that in this case public agitation was also necessary.
('34', 2, 2, 16, 5753) The stopping of indentured labour was very much more important than the abolition of the Viramgam customs.
('34', 2, 2, 17, 5860) Lord Chelmsford committed a series of blunders beginning with the passing of the Rowlatt Act 2. Still, I think, he was a wise ruler.
('34', 2, 2, 18, 5993) But what Viceroy can escape for long the influence of the permanent officials of the Civil Service?
('34', 2, 3, 19, 6093) The third in order came the Champaran struggle 3, of which Rajendra Babu has written a detailed history.
('34', 2, 3, 20, 6198) Here satyagraha had actually to be offered.
('34', 2, 3, 21, 6242) Mere preparedness for it did not suffice, as powerful vested interests were arrayed in opposition.
('34', 2, 3, 22, 6341) The peace maintained by the people of Champaran deserves to be placed on record.
('34', 2, 3, 23, 6422) I can bear witness to the perfect non violence of theleaders in thought, word and deed.
('34', 2, 3, 24, 6510) Hence it was that this age long abuse came to an end in six months.
('34', 2, 4, 25, 6578) 1 Vide “Speech at Anti Indenture Meeting, Bombay”, February 9 & February 11, 1917. 2 Passed on March 18, 1919, in the teeth of vehement popular opposition, this Act placed in the hands of the Executive vast emergency powers “for the purpose of dealing with anarchical and revolutionary movements”.
('34', 2, 4, 26, 6876) For details vide “Summary of Rowlatt Bills”, Beore February 26, 1919 and “Congres Report on the Punjab Disorders Chapter III The Rowlatt Bills”, Before March 25, 1920. 3 Arising out of the hardships inflicted on the ryots by indigo planters 4 The report of the Champaran Agrarian Enquiry Committee, in the deliberations of which Gandhiji had played a prominent part, was signed on October 3, 1917, and the necessary legislation giving effect to its recommendations followed shortly after.
('34', 3, 0, 1, 7365) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 4
('34', 3, 1, 2, 7405) The fourth struggle was that of the mill hands of Ahmedabad.
('34', 3, 2, 3, 7466) Gujarat is perfectly familiar with its history.
('34', 3, 2, 4, 7514) How peaceful the labourers were!
('34', 3, 2, 5, 7547) As for the leaders, there can hardly be anything for me to say.
('34', 3, 2, 6, 7611) Still I hold the victory in this case was not quite pure, as the fast I had to observe in order to sustain the labourers in their determination exercised indirect pressure upon the mill owners.
('34', 3, 2, 7, 7805) The fast was bound to influence them, as I enjoyed friendly relations with them.
('34', 3, 2, 8, 7886) Still the moral of the fight is clear.
('34', 3, 2, 9, 7925) If the labourers carry on their struggle peacefully, they must succeed and also win the hearts of their masters.
('34', 3, 2, 10, 8038) They have not won their masters’ hearts, as they were not innocent in thought, word and deed.
('34', 3, 2, 11, 8132) They were non violent in deed, which is certainly to their credit.
('34', 3, 2, 12, 8199) The fifth was the Kheda struggle.
('34', 3, 2, 13, 8233) I cannot say that in this case all the local leaders of satyagraha parties adhered to the pure truth.
('34', 3, 2, 14, 8335) Peace was certainly maintained.
('34', 3, 2, 15, 8367) The non violence of the peasantry, however, was only superficial, like that of the mill hands.
('34', 3, 2, 16, 8462) So we came out of the struggle with bare honour.
('34', 3, 2, 17, 8511) However, there was a great awakening among the people.
('34', 3, 2, 18, 8566) But Kheda had not fully grasped the lesson of non violence; the mill hands had not understood the true meaning of peace.
('34', 3, 2, 19, 8687) The people had therefore to suffer.
('34', 3, 2, 20, 8723) At the time of the Rowlatt Act satyagraha, I had to confess my Himalayan blunder, to fast myself and invite others to do so.
('34', 3, 3, 21, 8848) The sixth was in connection with the Rowlatt Act.
('34', 3, 3, 22, 8898) Therein our inherent shortcomings came to the surface.
('34', 3, 3, 23, 8953) But the original foundation was well and truly laid.
('34', 3, 3, 24, 9006) We admitted all our shortcomings and did penance for them.
('34', 3, 3, 25, 9065) The Rowlatt Act was a dead letter even when it was promulgated, and that black act was finally even repealed.
('34', 3, 3, 26, 9175) This struggle taught us a great lesson.
('34', 3, 3, 27, 9215) The seventh was the struggle to right the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs and to win swaraj.
('34', 3, 3, 28, 9307) It is still going on.
('34', 3, 3, 29, 9329) And my confidence is unshaken that if a single satyagrahi holds out to the end, victory is absolutely certain.
('34', 3, 3, 30, 9440) But the present fight is epic in character.
('34', 3, 3, 31, 9484) I have already described our course of unconscious preparation for it.
('34', 3, 3, 32, 9555) When I took up the Viramgam question, little did I know that other fights were in store.
('34', 3, 3, 33, 9644) And even about Viramgam I knew nothing when I was in South
('34', 3, 4, 34, 9703) 1Vide Mahadev Desai, A Righteous Struggle, Navajivan Publishing House, Ahmedabad.
('34', 3, 4, 35, 9785) 2Vide “Speech at Mass Meeting, Ahmedabad”, April 14, 1919.

('34', 4, 1, 2, 9888) Africa.
('34', 4, 1, 3, 9896) That is the beauty of satyagraha.
('34', 4, 1, 4, 9930) It comes up to oneself; one has not to go out in search of it.
('34', 4, 1, 5, 9993) This is a virtue inherent in the principle itself.
('34', 4, 1, 6, 10044) A dharma yuddha, in which there are no secrets to be guarded, no scope for cunning and no place for untruth, comes unsought; and a man of religion is ever ready for it.
('34', 4, 1, 7, 10213) A struggle which has to be previously planned is not a righteous struggle.
('34', 4, 1, 8, 10288) In 3 righteous struggle God Himself plans campaigns and conducts battles.
('34', 4, 1, 9, 10362) A dharma yuddha can be waged only in the name of God, and it is only when the satyagrahi feels quite helpless, is apparently on his last legs and finds utter darkness all around him, that God comes to the rescue.
('34', 4, 1, 10, 10575) God helps when one feels oneself humbler than the very dust under one’s feet.
('34', 4, 1, 11, 10653) Only to the weak and help.
('34', 4, 1, 12, 10680) less is divine succour vouchsafed.
('34', 4, 1, 13, 10715) We are yet to realize this truth, and so I think the history of Satyagraha in South Africa will be helpful to us.
('34', 4, 1, 14, 10829) The reader will note South African parallels for all our experiences in the present struggle to date.
('34', 4, 1, 15, 10931) He will also see from this history that there is so far no ground whatever for despair in the fight that is going on.
('34', 4, 1, 16, 11049) The only condition of victory is a tenacious adherence to our programme.
('34', 4, 1, 17, 11122) I am writing this preface at Juhu.
('34', 4, 1, 18, 11157) I wrote the first thirty chapters of the history in Yeravda jail.
('34', 4, 1, 19, 11223) Shri Indulal Yagnik was good enough to write to my dictation.
('34', 4, 1, 20, 11285) The subsequent chapters I hope to write hereafter.
('34', 4, 1, 21, 11336) I had no books of reference in jail.
('34', 4, 1, 22, 11373) Nor do I propose to get them here.
('34', 4, 1, 23, 11408) I have neither the time nor the inclination to write a regular detailed history.
('34', 4, 1, 24, 11489) My only object in writing this book is that it may be helpful in our present struggle, and serve as a guide to any regular historian who may arise in the future.
('34', 4, 1, 25, 11651) Although I am writing without books of reference at hand, I must ask the reader not to imagine that any single item in this volume is inaccurate or that there is the least exaggeration at any point.
('34', 4, 2, 26, 11850) M. K. GANDHI
('34', 4, 4, 27, 11863) 1980 Phalguna Vadi 13 2nd April, 1924

('34', 5, 0, 1, 11939) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 6
('34', 5, 2, 2, 11979) The reader knows that, owing to my fast 2 and other things, I could not continue writing the history of satyagraha in South Africa.
('34', 5, 2, 3, 12111) I take it up again with the current issue.
('34', 5, 2, 4, 12154) I hope I shall now be able to complete it without impediments.
('34', 5, 2, 5, 12217) From my reminiscences of that history I see that there is nothing in our present position which I had not encountered in South Africa on a smaller scale: in the beginning the same enthusiasm, the same unity, the same persistence; in the middle the same despondency, the same apathy, internecine strife, hatred, and so on; a handful of people who, despite this, had unwavering faith, determination, sacrifice, tolerance and who faced foreseen and unforeseen difficulties of many kinds.
('34', 5, 2, 6, 12702) The final phase of India’s battle is yet to arrive.
('34', 5, 2, 7, 12754) I expect the repetition here of the experience I had of the final phase in South Africa.
('34', 5, 2, 8, 12843) The reader will from now on have an account of the last phase of the struggle in South Africa.
('34', 5, 2, 9, 12938) Therein he will see how help came unsought, how the people’s enthusiasm rose spontaneously and how there was complete victory for the Indians.
('34', 5, 2, 10, 13081) Again, I am convinced that what happened in South Africa will also happen here, because I have unswerving faith in the power of self sacrifice, truth and non violence.
('34', 5, 2, 11, 13249) I literally believe that before one wedded to truth stands all the wealth of the world; such a one feels the presence of God.
('34', 5, 2, 12, 13375) I also literally believe that non violence cannot tolerate the presence of animosity in its vicinity.
('34', 5, 2, 13, 13477) I am a firm follower of the maxim: nothing is impossible for those who are prepared to suffer.
('34', 5, 2, 14, 13572) I see such self sacrifice, truth and non violence in many workers.
('34', 5, 2, 15, 13639) It has been my invariable experience that such sacrifices would never go in vain.
('34', 5, 2, 16, 13721) But some may contend that the complete victory in South Africa meant only that the Indians maintained their status quo.
('34', 5, 2, 17, 13841) Those who say so are ignorant.
('34', 5, 2, 18, 13872) Had the battle in South Africa not been fought, today Indians would have been driven out not only from South Africa, but also from all other British colonies and no one would have even taken notice of it.
('34', 5, 2, 19, 14077) This answer cannot, however, be considered as adequate or satisfactory.
('34', 5, 2, 20, 14149) It can also be argued that, if
('34', 5, 3, 21, 14180) 1 This is a rendering of the second part of the preface published in Navajivan, 5 7 1925. It appeared in the original Gujarati edition, but was omitted in the English translation issued in 1928. 2 For 21 days from 17 9 1924 to 8 10 1924

('34', 6, 1, 2, 14461) there had been no satyagraha and if we had been satisfied with whatever we could secure through conciliatory means, the position would have been different from what it is today.
('34', 6, 1, 3, 14639) Though there is no substance in this argument, where only arguments and guesswork are employed, who can say whose argument or whose guess is best?
('34', 6, 1, 4, 14786) Everyone has a right to hazard guesses.
('34', 6, 1, 5, 14826) The only unanswerable point is this: a thing secured by a particular weapon can be retained only by that weapon.
('34', 6, 1, 6, 14939) ‘Kaba robbed Arjuna, though the latter had the same bow and arrows [with which he had won victory in battles].’ Arjuna, who had defeated Lord Siva and had humbled the Kauravas’ pride, could not overcome a band of robbers with his Gandiva bow and arrows when he was without a charioteer in the form of Lord Krishna!
('34', 6, 1, 7, 15254) Similar is the predicament of the Indians resident in South Africa.
('34', 6, 1, 8, 15322) They are still fighting.
('34', 6, 1, 9, 15347) But if they let go the weapon of satyagraha with which they had won a victory, they will suffer defeat in the end.
('34', 6, 1, 10, 15462) Satyagraha was their charioteer and that charioteer alone can help them.
('34', 6, 2, 11, 15535) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI
('34', 6, 3, 12, 15562) CHAPTER I
('34', 6, 4, 13, 15572) GEOGRAPHY
('34', 6, 5, 14, 15582) Africa is one of the biggest continents in the world.
('34', 6, 5, 15, 15636) India is said to be not a country but a continent, but considering area alone, four or five Indias could be carved out of Africa.
('34', 6, 5, 16, 15766) Africa is a peninsula like India; South Africa is thus mainly surrounded by the sea.
('34', 6, 5, 17, 15851) There is a general impression that Africa is the hottest part of the earth, and in a sense this is true.
('34', 6, 5, 18, 15956) The equator passes through the middle of Africa, and people in India cannot have any idea of the heat in countries situated along this line.
('34', 6, 5, 19, 16097) The heat which we feel in the extreme south of India gives us some notion of it.
('34', 6, 5, 20, 16178) But in South Africa there is nothing of that kind, as it is far away from the equator.
('34', 6, 5, 21, 16265) The climate of many parts is so healthy and temperate that Europeans can settle there in comfort, while it is nearly impossible for them to settle in India.
('34', 6, 5, 22, 16422) Moreover, there are in South Africa lands of great elevation like Tibet or Kashmir, but these do not attain a height of ten to fourteen thousand feet as in Tibet.
('34', 6, 5, 23, 16585) Consequently, the climate is dry and cold enough to be endured, and some places in South Africa are highly recommended as sanatoria for consumptives.
('34', 6, 5, 24, 16735) One of these is
('34', 7, 0, 1, 16751) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 8
('34', 7, 1, 2, 16791) Johannesburg, the golden city of South Africa.
('34', 7, 1, 3, 16838) Only fifty years ago, the site on which it now stands was desolate and covered with dry grass.
('34', 7, 1, 4, 16933) But when gold mines were discovered, houses began to be built one after another, as if by magic, and today there are many handsome and substantial buildings.
('34', 7, 1, 5, 17091) The wealthy people of the place have got trees from the more fertile tracts of South Africa and from Europe, paying as much as a guinea for a tree, and have planted them there.
('34', 7, 1, 6, 17268) A traveller ignorant of this previous history would imagine that these trees had been there for all time.
('34', 7, 1, 7, 17374) I do not propose to describe all the parts of South Africa, but will confine myself only to those which are connected with our subject matter.
('34', 7, 1, 8, 17517) One part of South Africa is under the Portuguese, and the rest under the British.
('34', 7, 1, 9, 17599) The territory under the Portuguese is called Delagoa Bay, and this is the first South African port for steamers from India.
('34', 7, 1, 10, 17723) As we proceed further south, we come to Natal, the first British Colony.
('34', 7, 1, 11, 17796) Its chief seaport is called Port Natal, but we know it as Durban, under which name it is generally known all over South Africa.
('34', 7, 1, 12, 17924) Durban is the largest city in Natal.
('34', 7, 1, 13, 17961) The capital is Pietermaritzburg, situated inland at a distance of about sixty miles from Durban and at a height of about two thousand feet above sea level.
('34', 7, 1, 14, 18117) The climate of Durban is somewhat like that of Bombay, although rather colder.
('34', 7, 1, 15, 18196) If we proceed further inland beyond Natal we reach the Transvaal, whose mines supply the world with the largest amount of gold.
('34', 7, 1, 16, 18324) Some years ago diamond mines were also discovered, in one of which was the world’s largest diamond.
('34', 7, 1, 17, 18424) The Cullinan, so called after the name of the proprietor of the mine, weighed over 3,000 carats, or over 1 1 3 lb.
('34', 7, 1, 18, 18539) avoirdupois, while the Kohinoor now
('34', 7, 2, 19, 18575) weighs about 100 carats and the Orloff, one of the Russian crown jewels, about 200 carats.
('34', 7, 2, 20, 18666) But though Johannesburg is the centre of the gold mining industry and has diamond mines in the neighbourhood, it is not the official capital of the Transvaal.
('34', 7, 2, 21, 18825) The capital is Pretoria, at a distance of about thirty six miles from Johannesburg.
('34', 7, 2, 22, 18909) In Pretoria one chiefly finds officials and politicians and the population drawn by them.
('34', 7, 2, 23, 18999) It is therefore a comparatively quiet place, while Johannesburg is full of bustle.
('34', 7, 2, 24, 19082) As a visitor from a quiet village, or for the matter of that from a small town in India, to Bombay, would be confounded with the din and roar of the city, even so would a visitor from Pretoria be affected by Johannesburg.
('34', 7, 2, 25, 19304) It would be no exaggeration to say that the citizens of Johannesburg do not walk but seem as if they ran.
('34', 7, 2, 26, 19410) No one has the
('34', 8, 0, 1, 19425) VOL. 34 : 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 9
('34', 8, 1, 2, 19469) leisure to look at anyone else, and everyone is apparently engrossed in thinking of how to amass the maximum wealth in the minimum oftime!
('34', 8, 1, 3, 19608) If leaving the Transvaal we travel further inland towards the West, we come to Orange Free State or Orangia.
('34', 8, 1, 4, 19717) Its capital is Bloemfontein, a very quiet and small town.
('34', 8, 1, 5, 19775) There are no mines in Orangia like those in the Transvaal.
('34', 8, 1, 6, 19834) A few hours’ railway journey from here takes us to the boundary of the Cape Colony, the biggest of all the South African colonies.
('34', 8, 1, 7, 19965) Its capital, which is also its largest seaport, is known as Cape Town and is situated on the Cape of Good Hope, so called by King John of Portugal, as after its discovery he hoped his people would be able to find a new and easier way of reaching India, the supreme object of the maritime expeditions of that age.
('34', 8, 1, 8, 20278) 1 Over and above these four principal British colonies, there are several territories under British ‘protection’, inhabited by races which had migrated there before the appearance of Europeans on the scene.
('34', 8, 1, 9, 20485) The chief industry of South Africa is agriculture and for this it is pre eminently fitted.
('34', 8, 1, 10, 20576) Some parts of it are delightful and fertile.
('34', 8, 1, 11, 20621) The principal grain is maize, which is grown without much labour and forms the staple food of the Negro inhabitants of South Africa.
('34', 8, 1, 12, 20754) Wheat also is grown in some parts.
('34', 8, 1, 13, 20789) South Africa is famous for its fruits.
('34', 8, 1, 14, 20828) Natal cultivates many varieties of excellent bananas, pawpaws and pineapples, and that too in such abundance that they are available to the poorest of the poor.
('34', 8, 1, 15, 20989) In Natal as well as in other colonies, oranges, peaches and apricots grow in such plenty that thousands get them in the country for the labour of gathering them.
('34', 8, 1, 16, 21151) The Cape Colony is the land of grapes and plums.
('34', 8, 1, 17, 21200) Hardly any other place grows such fine grapes, and during the season they can be had so cheap that even a poor man can have his fill.
('34', 8, 1, 18, 21334) It is impossible that there should be no mangoes in places inhabited by Indians.
('34', 8, 1, 19, 21415) Indians planted mango trees in South Africa and consequently mangoes also are available in considerable quantities.
('34', 8, 1, 20, 21531) Some varieties of these can certainly compete with the best mangoes of Bombay.
('34', 8, 1, 21, 21610) Vegetables also are extensively grown in that fertile country, and it may be said that almost all the

('34', 24, 3, 8, 61883) A REVIEW OF THE GRIEVANCES
('34', 24, 4, 9, 61910) NATAL The European planters of Natal wanted only slaves.
('34', 24, 4, 10, 61967) They could not afford to have labourers who, after serving their term, would be free to compete with them to however small an extent.
('34', 24, 4, 11, 62101) No doubt the indentured labourers had gone to Natal, as they had not been very successful in agriculture or other pursuits in India.

('34', 24, 4, 14, 62525) Many, therefore, on the termination of their indentures, began to pursue some trade or other on a small scale.
('34', 24, 4, 15, 62636) This was, on the whole, advantageous to the settlers in Natal.
('34', 24, 4, 16, 62699) Various kinds of vegetables, which had not been grown before for want of a competent class of cultivators, now became available.
('34', 24, 4, 17, 62828) Other kinds, which had been grown in small quantities, could now be had in abundance.
('34', 24, 4, 18, 62914) The result was a fall in the prices of vegetables.
('34', 24, 4, 19, 62965) But the European planters did not relish this new development.
('34', 24, 4, 20, 63028) They felt they now had competitors in a field in which they believed they had a monopoly.

('34', 26, 1, 11, 67313) The Indians carried on a powerful agitation against this action of the Government of Natal.
('34', 26, 1, 12, 67405) Memorials were submitted to the Imperial Government and the Government of India, but to no purpose except for a reduction in the amount of the tax.
('34', 26, 1, 13, 67553) What could the poor labourers do or understand in this matter?
('34', 26, 1, 14, 67616) The agitation on their behalf was carried on by the Indian traders, actuated by motives of patriotism or of philanthropy.
('34', 26, 1, 15, 67738) Free Indians fared no better.
('34', 26, 1, 16, 67768) The European traders of Natal carried on a similar agitation against them for mainly the same reasons.
('34', 26, 1, 17, 67871) Indian traders were well established.
('34', 26, 1, 18, 67909) They acquired lands in good localities.
('34', 26, 1, 19, 67949) As the number of freed labourers began to increase, there was a larger and larger demand for the class of goods required by them.
('34', 26, 1, 20, 68079) Bags of rice were imported from India in their thousands and sold at a good profit.
('34', 26, 1, 21, 68163) Naturally this trade was largely in the hands of Indians who had, besides, a fair share of the trade with Zulus.
('34', 26, 1, 22, 68276) They thus became an eye sore to petty European traders.
('34', 26, 1, 23, 68332) Again, some Englishmen pointed out to the Indian traders that according to law they were entitled to vote in the elections for the Legislative Assembly of Natal and to stand as candidates for the same.
('34', 26, 1, 24, 68534) Some Indians therefore got their names entered on the electoral roll.
('34', 26, 1, 25, 68604) This made the European politicians of Natal join the ranks of anti Indians.
('34', 26, 1, 26, 68680) They doubted whether the Europeans could stand in competition with Indians if the Indians’ prestige increased, and if their position was consolidated in Natal.
('34', 26, 1, 27, 68840) The first step, therefore, taken by the responsible Government of Natal in connection with free Indians was that they decided to enact
('34', 27, 0, 1, 68975) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 28
('34', 27, 1, 2, 69016) a law, disfranchising all Asiatics save those who were then rightly contained in any voters’ list.
('34', 27, 1, 3, 69115) A bill 1 to that effect was first introduced in the Legislative Assembly of Natal in 1894. This was based on the principle of excluding Indians as Indians from the franchise, and was in Natal the first piece of legislation affecting them in which racial distinction was made.
('34', 27, 1, 4, 69391) Indians resisted this measure.
('34', 27, 1, 5, 69422) A memorial was prepared during one night and four hundred signatures were appended to it.
('34', 27, 1, 6, 69512) 2 When the memorial was submitted to the Legislative Assembly of Natal, that body was startled.
('34', 27, 1, 7, 69608) But the bill was passed all the same.
('34', 27, 1, 8, 69646) A memorial 3 bearing ten thousand signatures 4 was submitted to Lord Ripon who was then Secretary of State for the Colonies.
('34', 27, 1, 9, 69771) Ten thousand signatures meant almost the total population at the time of free Indians in Natal.
('34', 27, 1, 10, 69867) Lord Ripon disallowed the bill and declared that the British Empire could not agree to the establishment of a colour bar in legislation.
('34', 27, 1, 11, 70004) 5 The reader will be in a position later on to appreciate how great was this victory for Indians.
('34', 27, 1, 12, 70102) The Natal Government, therefore, brought forward another bill, removing racial distinction but indirectly disqualifying Indians.
('34', 27, 1, 13, 70231) Indians protested against this as well but without success.
('34', 27, 1, 14, 70291) This new bill was ambiguous in meaning.
('34', 27, 1, 15, 70331) Indians were in a position to carry it finally to the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council with a view to its interpretation; but they did not think it advisable to do so.
('34', 27, 1, 16, 70506) I still think that they did the right thing in avoiding this endless litigation.
('34', 27, 1, 17, 70587) It was no small thing that the colour bar was not allowed to be set up.
('34', 27, 2, 18, 70659) But the planters and the Government of Natal were not likely to stop there.
('34', 27, 2, 19, 70735) To nip the political power of Indians in the bud was for them the indispensable first step; but the real point of their attack was Indian trade and free Indian immigration.
('34', 27, 2, 20, 70908) They were uneasy at the thought of the Europeans in Natal being swamped if India with its teeming millions invaded Natal.
('34', 27, 2, 21, 71030) The approximate population of Natal at the time was 400,000 Zulus and 40,000 Europeans as against 60,000 indentured, 10,000 ex indentured and

('34', 28, 1, 3, 71595) 1 The Europeans had no solid grounds for their apprehensions, but it is impossible to convince by argument men who have been seized with vague terrors.
('34', 28, 1, 4, 71747) As they were ignorant of the helpless condition of India and of the manners and customs of the Indian people, they were under the impression that the Indians were as adventurous and resourceful as themselves.
('34', 28, 1, 5, 71956) They could scarcely be blamed if they thus created a bugbear of the vast population of India in comparison with their own small numbers.
('34', 28, 1, 6, 72093) However that may be, the result of the successful opposition to the disfranchising bill was that in two other laws passed by the Natal Legislature it had to avoid racial distinction and to attain its end in an indirect manner.
('34', 28, 1, 7, 72320) The position, therefore, was not as bad as it might have been.

('34', 28, 1, 10, 72593) The substance of the first Act was that no one could trade without a licence issued by an official appointed in accordance with its provisions.
('34', 28, 1, 11, 72737) In practice any European could get a licence while the Indian had to face no end of difficulty in the matter.
('34', 28, 1, 12, 72847) He had to engage a lawyer and incur other expenditure.
('34', 28, 1, 13, 72902) Those who could not afford it had to go without a Licence.

('34', 28, 1, 15, 73115) This closed the doors of Natal against crores of Indians.
('34', 28, 1, 16, 73173) Lest I should inadvertently do the Government of Natal an injustice, I must state that the Act further provided that an Indian resident in Natal for three years before the passing of that Act might obtain a certificate of domicile enabling him to leave the Colony and return at any time with his wife and minor children without being required to pass the education test.
('34', 28, 2, 17, 73544) The indentured and free Indians in Natal were and still are subject to other disabilities, both legal and extra legal, in additionto those described above.

('34', 29, 2, 4, 74363) CHAPTER V
('34', 29, 3, 5, 74373) A REVIEW OF THE GRIEVANCES [CONTINUED]
('34', 29, 4, 6, 74412) THE TRANSVAAL AND OTHER COLONIES As in Natal, so in the other colonies anti Indian prejudice had more or less begun to grow even before 1880. Except in the Cape Colony, the general opinion held was that as labourers the Indians were all right, but it had become an axiom with many Europeans that the immigration of free Indians was purely a disadvantage to South Africa.
('34', 29, 4, 7, 74783) The Transvaal was a republic.
('34', 29, 4, 8, 74813) For Indians to declare their British citizenship before its President was only to invite ridicule.
('34', 29, 4, 9, 74912) If they had any grievance, all they could do was to bring it to the notice of the British Agent at Pretoria.
('34', 29, 4, 10, 75021) Still the wonder is that when the Transvaal came under the British flag, there was none from whom Indians could expect even such assistance as the Agent rendered when the Transvaal was independent.
('34', 29, 4, 11, 75219) When during Lord Morley’s tenure of the office of the Secretary of State for India, a deputation on behalf of the Indians waited upon him, he declared in so many words that, as the members of the deputation were aware, the Imperial Government could exercise but little control over self governing dominions.
('34', 29, 4, 12, 75527) 1 They could not dictate to them; they could plead, they could argue, they could press for the application of their principles.
('34', 29, 4, 13, 75655) Indeed, in some instances they could more effectively remonstrate with foreign Powers, as they remonstrated with the Boer Republic, than with their own people in the colonies.
('34', 29, 4, 14, 75831) The relations of the mother country with the colonies were in the nature of a silken tie which would snap with the slightest tension.
('34', 29, 4, 15, 75965) As force was out of the question, he assured the deputation that he would do all he could by negotiations.
('34', 29, 4, 16, 76072) When war was declared on the Transvaal, Lord Lansdowne, Lord Selborne and other British statesmen declared that the scandalous treatment accorded to theIndians by the South African Republic was one of the causes of the war.
('34', 29, 5, 17, 76296) 1 For the full report of the interview between the Indian deputation and Lord Morley, vide “Deputation to Morley”, November 22, 1906 and “Deputation Notes III”, November 23, 1906.
('34', 30, 0, 1, 76476) VOL. 34 : 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 31
('34', 30, 1, 2, 76521) Let us now see what sort of treatment this was.
('34', 30, 1, 3, 76569) Indians first entered the Transvaal in 1881. The late Sheth Abubakar opened a shop in Pretoria and purchased land in one of its principal streets.
('34', 30, 1, 4, 76716) Other traders followed in his wake.
('34', 30, 1, 5, 76752) Their great success excited the jealousy of European traders who commenced an anti Indian campaign in the newspapers, and submitted petitions to the Volksraad or Parliament, praying that Indians should be expelled and their trade stopped.
('34', 30, 1, 6, 76991) The Europeans in this newly opened up country had a boundless hunger for riches.
('34', 30, 1, 7, 77072) They were almost strangers to the dictates of morality.
('34', 30, 1, 8, 77128) Here are some statements they made in their petitions: “These Indians have no sense of human decency.
('34', 30, 1, 9, 77230) They suffer from loathsome diseases.
('34', 30, 1, 10, 77267) They consider every woman as their prey.
('34', 30, 1, 11, 77308) They believe that women have no souls.” These four sentences contain four lies.
('34', 30, 1, 12, 77388) It would be easy to multiply such specimens.
('34', 30, 1, 13, 77433) As were the Europeans, so were their representatives.
('34', 30, 1, 14, 77487) Little did the Indian traders know what a sinister and unjust movement was being carried on against them.
('34', 30, 1, 15, 77593) They did not read newspapers.
('34', 30, 1, 16, 77623) The newspaper campaign and the petitions had the desired effect, and a bill was introduced in the Volksraad.
('34', 30, 1, 17, 77732) The leading Indians were taken aback when they came to know how events had shaped themselves.
('34', 30, 1, 18, 77826) They went to see President Kruger who did not so much as admit them into his house but made them stand in the courtyard.
('34', 30, 1, 19, 77947) After hearing them for a while, he said, “You are the descendants of Ishmael and therefore from your very birth bound to slave for the descendants of Esau.
('34', 30, 1, 20, 78103) As the descendants of Esau we cannot admit you to rights placing you on an equality with ourselves.
('34', 30, 1, 21, 78203) You must rest content with what rights we grant to you.” It cannot be said, that this reply from the President was inspired by malice or anger.
('34', 30, 1, 22, 78347) President Kruger had been taught from his childhood the stories of the Old Testament, and he believed them to be true.
('34', 30, 1, 23, 78466) How can we blame a man who gives candid expression to his opinions such as they are?
('34', 30, 1, 24, 78551) Ignorance, however, is bound to do harm even when associated with candour, and the result was that in 1885 a very drastic law was rushed through the Volksraad, as if thousands of Indians were on the point of flooding the Transvaal.
('34', 30, 1, 25, 78783) The British Agent was obliged to move in the matter at the instance of Indian leaders.
('34', 30, 1, 26, 78870) 1 The question was finally carried to the Secretary of State for the Colonies.
('34', 30, 1, 27, 78949) 2 In terms of this Law 3 of 1885
('34', 30, 2, 28, 78982) 1Vide “Open Letter”, before December 19, 1894. 2 Vide “Petition to Lord Ripon”, before May 5 1895.
('34', 31, 0, 1, 79081) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 32
('34', 31, 1, 2, 79122) every Indian settling in the Republic for the purpose of carrying on trade was required to register at a cost of twentyfive pounds subject to heavy penalties, and no Indian could hold an inch of land or enjoy the rights of citizenship.
('34', 31, 1, 3, 79358) All this was so manifestly unjust that the Transvaal Government could not defend it in argument.
('34', 31, 1, 4, 79455) There was a treaty subsisting between the Boers and the British known as the London Convention, Article XIV of which secured the rights of British subjects.
('34', 31, 1, 5, 79612) 1 The British Government objected to the Law as being in contravention of that Article.
('34', 31, 1, 6, 79700) The Boers urged in reply that the British Government had previously given their consent, whether express or implied, to the law in question.
('34', 31, 1, 7, 79841) A dispute thus arose between the British and the Boer Governments, and the matter was referred to arbitration.
('34', 31, 1, 8, 79952) The arbitrator’s award was unsatisfactory.
('34', 31, 1, 9, 79995) He tried to please both parties.
('34', 31, 1, 10, 80028) The Indians were therefore the losers.
('34', 31, 1, 11, 80067) The only advantage they reaped, if advantage it can be called, was that they did not lose as much as they might have done otherwise.
('34', 31, 1, 12, 80200) The Law was amended in 1886 in accordance with the arbitrator’s award.
('34', 31, 1, 13, 80271) The registration fee was reduced from twenty five to three pounds.
('34', 31, 1, 14, 80338) The clause which completely debarred Indians from holding landed property was removed, and it was provided, instead, that the Indians could own fixed property in such locations, wards and streets as were specially set apart for their residence by the Transvaal Government.
('34', 31, 1, 15, 80611) This Government did not honestly carry out the terms of the amended clause, and withheld from Indians the right to purchase freehold land even in the locations.
('34', 31, 1, 16, 80772) 2 In all towns inhabited by Indians, these locations were selected in dirty places situated far away from the towns where there was no water supply, no lighting arrangement and no sanitary convenience to speak of.
('34', 31, 1, 17, 80986) Thus the Indians became the Panchamas 3 of the Transvaal.
('34', 31, 1, 18, 81044) It can be truly said that there is no difference between these locations and the untouchables’ quarters in India.
('34', 31, 1, 19, 81158) Just as the Hindus believe that touching Dhedhs or residence in their neighbourhood would lead to pollution, so did the Europeans in the Transvaal believe for all practical purposes that physical contact with the Indians or living near them would defile
('34', 31, 2, 20, 81412) 1Vide “Notes on the Grievances of the British Indians in South Africa The Transvaal or the South African Republic”, September 22, 1896. 2Vide “The grievances of the British Indians in South Africa : An Appeal to the Indian Public The Transvaal”, August 14, 1896. 3 The fifth caste among Hindus, traditionally regarded as untouchables
('34', 32, 0, 1, 81746) VOL. 34 : 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 33
('34', 32, 1, 2, 81791) Again the Transvaal Government interpreted Law 3 of 1885 to mean that the Indians could trade, too, exclusively in the locations.
('34', 32, 1, 3, 81921) The arbitrator had decided that the interpretation of the law rested with the ordinary tribunals of the Transvaal.
('34', 32, 1, 4, 82036) The Indian traders were therefore in a very awkward condition.
('34', 32, 1, 5, 82099) Still they managed to maintain their position fairly well by carrying on negotiations in one place, by having recourse to law courts in another, and by exerting what little influence they possessed in a third.
('34', 32, 1, 6, 82309) 1 Such was the miserable and precarious position of Indians in the Transvaal at the outbreak of the Boer War.
('34', 32, 1, 7, 82419) We shall now turn to examine the position in the Free State.
('34', 32, 1, 8, 82480) Hardly a dozen Indians had opened shops there when the Europeans started a powerful agitation.
('34', 32, 1, 9, 82575) The Volksraad passed a stringent law and expelled all Indian traders from the Free State, awarding them nominal compensation.
('34', 32, 1, 10, 82701) That law provided that no Indian could on any account hold fixed property or carry on mercantile or farming business or enjoy franchise rights in the Free State.
('34', 32, 1, 11, 82863) With special permission an Indian could settle as a labourer or as a hotel waiter.
('34', 32, 1, 12, 82946) But the authorities were not obliged to grant even this precious permission in every case.
('34', 32, 1, 13, 83037) The result was that a respectable Indian could not live in the Free State even for a couple of days without great difficulty.
('34', 32, 1, 14, 83163) At the time of the Boer War there were no Indians in the Free State except a few waiters.
('34', 32, 2, 15, 83253) In the Cape Colony, too, there was some newspaper agitation against Indians, and the treatment to which they were subjected was not free from humiliating features.
('34', 32, 2, 16, 83417) For example, Indian children could not attend public schools, etc., and Indian travellers could hardly secure accommodation in hotels.
('34', 32, 2, 17, 83552) But there were no restrictions as to trade and the purchase of land for a long time.
('34', 32, 2, 18, 83637) There were reasons for this state of things.
('34', 32, 2, 19, 83682) As we have already seen, there was a fair proportion of the Malays in the population of the Cape Colony in general and of Cape Town in particular.
('34', 32, 2, 20, 83829) As the Malays are Mussalmans, they soon came in contact with their Indian co religionists, and consequently with other Indians later on.
('34', 32, 2, 21, 83966) Moreover, some Indian Mussalmans married Malay women.
('34', 32, 3, 22, 84020) 1 Vide “Notes on the Grievances of the British Indians in South Africa”, September 22, 1896. 2 ibid.
('34', 33, 0, 1, 84121) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 34
('34', 33, 1, 2, 84162) How could the Government of the Cape Colony legislate against the Malays?
('34', 33, 1, 3, 84236) The Cape was their mother land, Dutchwas their mother tongue, they had been living with the Dutch from the very first and therefore largely imitated them in their ways of life.
('34', 33, 1, 4, 84413) The Cape Colony, therefore, has been the least affected by colour prejudice.
('34', 33, 1, 5, 84490) Again as the Cape Colony was the oldest settlement and the chief centre of culture in South Africa, it produced sober, gentlemanly and large hearted Europeans.
('34', 33, 1, 6, 84650) In my opinion, there is no place on earth and no race which is not capable of producing the finest types of humanity, given suitable opportunities and education.
('34', 33, 1, 7, 84812) It has been my good fortune to come across this class of people in all parts of South Africa.
('34', 33, 1, 8, 84906) In the Cape Colony, however, the proportion of such persons was very much the larger.
('34', 33, 1, 9, 84992) Perhaps the best known and the most learned among them is Mr. Merriman who was a member of the first and subsequent ministries that came to power after the grant of responsible government to the Cape Colony in 1872, was again the Premier in the last ministry when the Union was established in 1910, and was known as the Gladstone of South Africa.
('34', 33, 1, 10, 85339) Then there are the Moltenos and the Schreiners.
('34', 33, 1, 11, 85387) Sir John Molteno was the first Premier of the Colony in 1872. Mr. W.P. Schreiner was a wellknown advocate, for some time Attorney General and later on Premier.
('34', 33, 1, 12, 85547) His sister, Olive Schreiner, was a gifted lady popular in South Africa and well known wherever the English language is spoken.
('34', 33, 1, 13, 85674) Ever since she wrote the book, she became famous as the authoress of Dreams.
('34', 33, 1, 14, 85751) Her love for all mankind was unbounded.
('34', 33, 1, 15, 85791) Love was written in her eyes.
('34', 33, 1, 16, 85821) Although she belonged to such a distinguished family and was a learned lady, she was so simple in habits that she cleaned utensils in her house herself.
('34', 33, 1, 17, 85974) Mr. Merriman, the Moltenos and the Schreiners had always espoused the cause of the Negroes.
('34', 33, 1, 18, 86066) Whenever the rights of the Negroes were in danger, they stoutly stood up in their defence.
('34', 33, 1, 19, 86157) They had kindly feelings for the Indians as well, though they made a distinction between Negroes and Indians.
('34', 33, 1, 20, 86267) Their argument was that as the Negroes had been the inhabitants of South Africa long before the European settlers, the latter could not deprive them of their natural rights.
('34', 33, 1, 21, 86441) But as for the Indians, it would not be unfair if laws calculated to remove the danger of their undue competition were enacted.
('34', 33, 1, 22, 86569) All the same they had a warm corner in their hearts for Indians.
('34', 33, 1, 23, 86634) When Gokhale went to South Africa, Mr. Schreiner presided over the Townhall meeting in Cape Town, where he was accorded his first public reception in that country.
('34', 33, 1, 24, 86798) Mr. Merriman also treated him with great courtesy and
('34', 34, 0, 1, 86852) VOL. 34 : 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 35
('34', 34, 1, 2, 86897) expressed his sympathy with the Indian cause.
('34', 34, 1, 3, 86943) There were otherEuropeans of the type of Mr. Merriman.
('34', 34, 1, 4, 86998) I have mentioned these well known names as typical of their class.
('34', 34, 1, 5, 87065) The newspapers in Cape Town, too, were less hostile to Indians than in other parts of South Africa.
('34', 34, 1, 6, 87165) While it is true that for these reasons there has always been less race hatred in the Cape Colony than in other parts, it is but natural that the anti Indian feeling which constantly found expression in the other colonies also found its way to the Cape.
('34', 34, 1, 7, 87419) There too two laws copied from Natal were passed, namely, the Immigration Restriction Act and the Dealers’ Licenses Act.
('34', 34, 1, 8, 87540) It can be said that the door in South Africa, which was formerly wide open, had thus been almost closed against Indians at the time of the Boer War.
('34', 34, 1, 9, 87689) In the Transvaal there was no restriction on immigration except the registration fee of three pounds.
('34', 34, 1, 10, 87791) When Natal and the Cape Colony closed their ports to Indians, they had difficulty in landing on their way to the Transvaal which was in the interior.
('34', 34, 1, 11, 87941) They could reach it via Delagoa Bay, a Portuguese port.
('34', 34, 1, 12, 87997) But the Portuguese also more or less imitated the British.
('34', 34, 1, 13, 88056) It must be mentioned that some stray Indians were able to find their way to the Transvaal via Natal or Delagoa Bay by suffering great hardships or by bribing port officers.
('34', 34, 2, 14, 88229) CHAPTER VI
('34', 34, 3, 15, 88240) A REVIEW OF THE EARLY STRUGGLE
('34', 34, 4, 16, 88271) While considering the position of Indians in the previous chapters, we have seen to some extent how they withstood the attacks made upon them.
('34', 34, 4, 17, 88414) In order, however, to give an adequate idea of the origin of satyagraha, it is necessary to devote special space to the endeavours made with a view to defending Indian interests in the pre satyagraha days.
('34', 34, 4, 18, 88620) Up till 1893 there were hardly any free and well educated Indians in South Africa capable of espousing the Indian cause.
('34', 34, 4, 19, 88741) English knowing Indians were mostly clerks whose knowledge of English was only commensurate with the needs of their occupation and not adequate for drafting representations, and who, again, must give all their time to their employers.
('34', 34, 4, 20, 88976) A second group of English educated Indians was composed of such of them as were born in South Africa.
('34', 34, 4, 21, 89078) They were mostly the descendants of indentured labourers, and if at all qualified for the work, were in Government
('34', 35, 0, 1, 89193) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 36
('34', 35, 1, 2, 89234) service as interpreters in law courts.
('34', 35, 1, 3, 89273) Thus they were not in a positionto help the Indian cause beyond expressing their fellow feeling.
('34', 35, 2, 4, 89370) Again, indentured and ex indentured labourers hailed mainly from Uttar Pradesh and Madras State, while, as we have already seen, the Mussalmans, mostly traders, and the Hindus, mostly clerks, who chiefly represented the class of free Indians, belonged to Gujarat.
('34', 35, 2, 5, 89634) Besides, there were a few Parsi traders and clerks, but the total population of Parsis in South Africa did not probably exceed thirty or forty souls.
('34', 35, 2, 6, 89784) A fourth group among free Indians was composed of Sindhi traders.
('34', 35, 2, 7, 89850) There were two hundred or more Sindhis in South Africa.
('34', 35, 2, 8, 89906) Wherever the Sindhi has settled outside India he deals in ‘fancy goods’, namely, silks and brocades, carved boxes and other furniture made of ebony, sandalwood and ivory and similar goods.
('34', 35, 2, 9, 90095) His customers are mainly Europeans.
('34', 35, 3, 10, 90131) Indentured labourers were called ‘coolies’ by the Europeans.
('34', 35, 3, 11, 90192) A ‘coolie’ means a porter.
('34', 35, 3, 12, 90219) The expression was used so extensively that the indentured labourers began to describe themselves as ‘coolies’!
('34', 35, 3, 13, 90331) Hundreds of Europeans called Indian lawyers and Indian traders ‘coolie’ lawyers and ‘coolie’ traders.
('34', 35, 3, 14, 90433) There were some Europeans who were unable to perceive or believe that the name implied an insult, but many used it as a term of deliberate contempt.
('34', 35, 3, 15, 90582) Free Indians, therefore, tried to differentiate themselves from the indentured labourers.
('34', 35, 3, 16, 90672) For this and other reasons peculiar to conditions in India, a distinction was sought to be drawn in South Africa between indentured and freed labourers on the one hand and free Indians on the other.
('34', 35, 4, 17, 90871) Free Indians and especially the Mussalman traders undertook to resist the wrongs detailed above, but no direct attempt was made to seek the co operation of the indentured and ex indentured labourers.
('34', 35, 4, 18, 91071) Probably it did not occur to anyone to enlist their support; if the idea did suggest itself to some, there was in their opinion the risk that matters might be made worse by their being allowed to join the movement.
('34', 35, 4, 19, 91286) And as it was considered that the free traders were the chief target of attack, the measures for defence were limited to that class.

('34', 58, 3, 9, 147775) THE BOER WAR
('34', 58, 4, 10, 147788) The reader has seen in the previous chapters what was the condition of the Indians in South Africa at the outbreak of the Boer War and what were the steps taken so far in order to ameliorate it.
('34', 58, 4, 11, 147983) In 1899 1, Dr. Jameson carried out his raid on Johannesburg in pursuance of the conspiracy which he had entered into with the owners of the gold mines.
('34', 58, 4, 12, 148135) The conspirators had expected that the Boer Government would come to know of the raid only after they had captured Johannesburg.

('34', 60, 3, 20, 153857) This great war thus broke out in 1899. The reader will remember that one of the causes of the war alleged by the British was the treatment accorded to the Indians by the Boers.

('34', 61, 1, 6, 154776) One of the charges laid against the Indians was that they went to South Africa only for money grubbing and were merely a dead weight upon the British.

('34', 80, 1, 3, 204678) It was my opinion that although we were not bound by law to take out such permits, the Government could insist on requiring them so long as the Peace Preservation Ordinance was in force.
('34', 80, 1, 4, 204865) The Peace Preservation Ordinance in South Africa was something like the Defence of India Act in India.
('34', 80, 1, 5, 204968) Just as the Defence of India Act was kept on the statute book in India longer than necessary in order to harass the people, so was this ordinance allowed to remain in force long after the necessity for it had passed in order to harass Indians in South Africa.
('34', 80, 1, 6, 205228) As for the Europeans, it was a dead letter for all practical purposes.
('34', 80, 1, 7, 205299) Now if permits must be taken out, they should contain some mark of identification.
('34', 80, 1, 8, 205382) There was nothing wrong therefore that those who were illiterate should allow their thumb impression to be taken.
('34', 80, 1, 9, 205496) I did not at all like the inclusion of photographs in the permits.
('34', 80, 1, 10, 205563) Mussalmans again had religious objections to such a course.
('34', 80, 1, 11, 205623) The final upshot of the negotiations between the Indian community and the authorities was that the Indians consented to change their permits for new ones and agreed that fresh Indian immigrants should take out permits in the new form.
('34', 80, 1, 12, 205858) Although the Indians were not bound in law, they voluntarily agreed to reregistration in the hope that new restrictions might not be imposed upon them, it might be clear to all concerned that the Indians did not wish to bring in fresh immigrants by unfair means, and the Peace Preservation Ordinance might no longer be used to harass newcomers.
('34', 80, 1, 13, 206203) Almost all Indians thus changed their old permits for new ones.
('34', 80, 1, 14, 206267) This was no small thing.
('34', 80, 1, 15, 206292) The community completed like one man with the greatest promptitude this re registration, which they were not legally bound to carry out.
('34', 80, 1, 16, 206429) This was a proof of their veracity, tact, large mindedness, common sense and humility.
('34', 80, 1, 17, 206516) It also showed that the community had no desire to violate in any way any law in force in the Transvaal.
('34', 80, 1, 18, 206621) The Indians believed that if they behaved towards the Government with such courtesy, it would treat them well, show regard to them and conferfresh rights upon them.
('34', 80, 1, 19, 206786) We shall see in the next chapter how the British Government in the Transvaal rewarded them for this great act of courtesy.

('34', 81, 1, 5, 207268) We all expected now that re registration would satisfy the Government and confidently looked forward to a period of comparative peace for the community.
('34', 81, 1, 6, 207421) But that was not to be.
('34', 81, 1, 7, 207445) The reader has been already introduced to Mr. Lionel Curtis.
('34', 81, 1, 8, 207506) This gentleman held that the Europeans had not attained their objective simply because the Indians changed their old permits for new certificates of registration.
('34', 81, 1, 9, 207669) It was not enough in his eyes that great measures were achieved by mutual understanding.
('34', 81, 1, 10, 207758) He was of opinion that these should have the force of law behind them, and that thus only could the principles underlying them be secured for all time.
('34', 81, 1, 11, 207910) Mr. Curtis wanted some such restrictions to be placed upon Indians as would produce a striking impression all over South Africa and ultimately serve as a model for the other Dominions of the Empire to imitate.
('34', 81, 1, 12, 208120) He would not consider the Transvaal to be safe so long as even a single point in South Africa was open to Indians.
('34', 81, 1, 13, 208235) Again, re registration by mutual consent was calculated to increase the prestige of the Indian community, while Mr. Curtis was keen upon lowering it.
('34', 81, 1, 14, 208385) He would not care to carry Indian opinion with him but would frighten us into submission to external restrictions backed up by rigorous legal sanctions.
('34', 81, 1, 15, 208538) He therefore drafted an Asiatic Bill and advised the Government that so long as his Bill was not passed, there was no provision in the laws already in force to prevent the Indians from surreptitiously entering the Transvaal or to remove unauthorized residents from the country.
('34', 81, 1, 16, 208816) Mr. Curtis’s arguments met with a ready response from the Government, and a draft Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance to be introduced into the Legislative Council was published in the Transvaal Government Gazette.
('34', 81, 1, 17, 209027) Before dealing with this Ordinance in detail, it would be well to dispose of an important event in a few words.

('34', 82, 1, 19, 211299) We liked the work.

('34', 83, 1, 5, 212535) First, an aspirant after a life exclusively devoted to service must lead a life of celibacy.

('34', 83, 1, 14, 213454) I saw nothing in it except hatred of Indians.

('34', 83, 1, 16, 213649) I clearly saw that this was a question of life and death for them.

('34', 83, 1, 23, 214204) Here is a brief summary of it: Every Indian, man, woman or child of eight years or upwards, entitled to reside in the Transvaal, must register his or her name with the Registrar of Asiatics and take out a certificate of registration.
('34', 83, 1, 24, 214438) The applicants for registration must surrender their old permits to the Registrar and state in their applications their name, residence, caste, age, etc.

('34', 84, 1, 3, 214888) Every Indian who failed thus to apply for registration before a certain date was to forfeit his right of residence in the Transvaal.
('34', 84, 1, 4, 215021) Failure to apply would be held to be an offence in law for which the defaulter could be fined, sent to prison or even deported within the discretion of the court.
('34', 84, 1, 5, 215184) Parents must apply on behalf of their minor children and bring them to the Registrar in order to give their finger impressions, etc.
('34', 84, 1, 6, 215317) In case of parents failing to discharge this responsibility laid upon them, the minor on attaining the age of sixteen years must discharge it himself, and if he defaulted, he made himself liable to the same punishments as could be awarded to his parents.
('34', 84, 1, 7, 215572) The certificate of registration issued to an applicant must be produced before any police officer whenever and wherever he might be required to do so.
('34', 84, 1, 8, 215723) Failure thus to produce the certificate would be held to be an offence for which the defaulter could be fined or sent to prison.
('34', 84, 1, 9, 215852) Even a person walking on public thoroughfares could be required to produce his certificate.
('34', 84, 1, 10, 215944) Police officers could enter private houses in order to inspect certificates.
('34', 84, 1, 11, 216021) Indians entering the Transvaal from some place outside it must produce their certificates before the inspector on duty.
('34', 84, 1, 12, 216141) Certificates must be produced on demand in courts which the holder attended on business, and in revenue offices which issued to him a trading or bicycle licence.
('34', 84, 1, 13, 216303) That is to say, if an Indian wanted any Government office to do for him something within its competence, the officer could ask to see his certificate before granting his request.
('34', 84, 1, 14, 216482) Refusal to produce the certificate or to supply such particulars or means of identification as might be prescribed by regulation would also be held to be an offence for which the person refusing could be fined or sent to prison.
('34', 84, 1, 15, 216711) I have never known legislation of this nature being directed against free men in any part of the world.
('34', 84, 1, 16, 216815) I know that indentured Indians in Natal are subject to a drastic system of passes, but these poor fellows can hardly be classed as free men.
('34', 84, 1, 17, 216956) However, even the laws to which they are subject are mild in comparison to the Ordinance outlined above and the penalties they impose are a mere fleabite when compared with the penalties laid down in the Ordinance.
('34', 84, 1, 18, 217171) A trader with assets running into lakhs could be deported and thus faced with utter ruin in virtue of the Ordinance.
('34', 84, 1, 19, 217288) And the patient reader will see later on how persons were even deported for breaking some of its provisions.
('34', 84, 1, 20, 217397) There are some drastic laws directed against criminal tribes in India, with which this Ordinance can be easily compared and will be found not to suffer by the comparison.

('34', 86, 4, 6, 220311) The meeting was duly held on September 11, 1906. It was attended by delegates from various places in the Transvaal.
('34', 86, 4, 7, 220427) But I must confess that even I myself had not then understood all the implications of the resolutions I had helped to frame; nor had I gauged all the possible conclusions to which they might lead.
('34', 86, 4, 8, 220624) The old Empire Theatre was packed from floor to ceiling.
('34', 86, 4, 9, 220681) I could read in every face the expectation of something strange to be done or to happen.
('34', 86, 4, 10, 220770) Mr. Abdul Gani, Chairman of the Transvaal British Indian Association, presided.
('34', 86, 4, 11, 220850) He was one of the oldest Indian residents of the Transvaal, and partner and manager of the Johannesburg branch of the well known firm of Mamad Kasam Kamrudin 2. The most important among the resolutions passed by the meeting was the famous Fourth Resolution by which the Indians solemnly determined not to submit to the Ordinance in the event of its becoming law in the teeth of their opposition and to suffer all the penalties attaching to such non submission.
('34', 86, 5, 12, 221311) I fully explained this resolution to the meeting and received a patient hearing.
('34', 86, 5, 13, 221392) The business of the meeting was conducted in Hindi or Gujarati; it was impossible therefore that anyone present should not follow the proceedings.
('34', 86, 5, 14, 221539) For the Tamils and Telugus who did not know Hindi there were Tamil and Telugu speakers who fully explained everything in their respective languages.
('34', 86, 5, 15, 221688) The resolution was duly proposed, seconded and supported by several speakers one of whom was Sheth Haji Habib.
('34', 86, 5, 16, 221799) He too was a very old and experienced resident of South Africa and made an impassioned speech.
('34', 86, 5, 17, 221894) He was deeply moved and went so far as to say that we must pass this resolution with God as witness and must never yield a cowardly submission to such degrading legislation.
('34', 86, 5, 18, 222068) He then went on solemnly to declare in the name of God that he would never submit to that law, and advised all present to do likewise.

('34', 87, 1, 2, 222618) Others also delivered powerful and angry speeches in supporting the resolution.
('34', 87, 1, 3, 222698) When in the course of his speech Sheth Haji Habib came to the solemn declaration, I was at once startled and put on my guard.
('34', 87, 1, 4, 222824) Only then did I fully realize my own responsibility and the responsibility of the community.
('34', 87, 1, 5, 222917) The community had passed many a resolution before and amended such resolutions in the light of further reflection or fresh experience.
('34', 87, 1, 6, 223052) There were cases in which resolutions passed had not been observed by all concerned.
('34', 87, 1, 7, 223137) Amendments inresolutions and failure to observe resolutions on the part of persons agreeing thereto are ordinary experiences of public life all the world over.
('34', 87, 1, 8, 223297) But no one ever imports the name of God into such resolutions.
('34', 87, 1, 9, 223360) In the abstract there should not be any distinction between a resolution and an oath taken in the name of God.
('34', 87, 1, 10, 223471) When an intelligent man makes a resolution deliberately he never swerves from it by a hair’s breadth.
('34', 87, 1, 11, 223573) With him his resolution carries as much weight as a declaration made with God as witness does.
('34', 87, 1, 12, 223668) But the world takes no note of abstract principles and imagines an ordinary resolution and an oath in the name of God to be poles asunder.
('34', 87, 1, 13, 223807) A man who makes an ordinary resolution is not ashamed of himself when he deviates from it, but a man who violates an oath administered to him is not only ashamed of himself but is also looked upon by society as a sinner.
('34', 87, 1, 14, 224028) This imaginary distinction has struck such a deep root in the human mind that a person making a statement on oath before a judge is held to have committed an offence in law if the statement is proved to be false and receives drastic punishment.
('34', 87, 1, 15, 224273) Full of these thoughts as I was, possessing as I did much experience of solemn pledges, having profited by them, I was taken aback by Sheth Haji Habib’s suggestion of an oath.
('34', 87, 1, 16, 224449) I thought out the possible consequences of it in a moment.
('34', 87, 1, 17, 224508) My perplexity gave place to enthusiasm.
('34', 87, 1, 18, 224548) And although I had no intention of taking an oath or inviting others to do so, when I went to the meeting I warmly approved of the Sheth’s suggestion.
('34', 87, 1, 19, 224699) But at the same time it seemed to me that the people should be told of all the consequences and should have explained to them clearly the meaning of a pledge.
('34', 87, 1, 20, 224858) And if even then they were prepared to pledge themselves, they should be encouraged to do so; otherwise, I must understand that they were not still ready to stand the final test.
('34', 87, 1, 21, 225037) I therefore asked the President for permission to explain to the meeting the implications of Sheth Haji Habib’s suggestion.
('34', 87, 1, 22, 225161) The President readily granted it and I rose to address the meeting.
('34', 87, 1, 23, 225229) I give below a summary of my remarks

('34', 88, 1, 2, 225311) just as I can recall them now: “I wish to explain to this meeting that there is a vast difference between this resolution and every other resolution we have passed up to date and that there is a wide divergence also in the manner of making it.
('34', 88, 1, 3, 225555) It is a very grave resolution we are making, as our existence in South Africa depends upon our fully observing it.
('34', 88, 1, 4, 225670) The manner of making the resolution suggested by our friend is as much of a novelty as of a solemnity.
('34', 88, 1, 5, 225773) I did not come to the meeting with a view to getting the resolution passed in that manner, which redounds to the credit of Sheth Haji Habib as well as it lays a burden of responsibility upon him.

('34', 88, 1, 9, 226239) “We all believe in one and the same God, the differences of nomenclature in Hinduism and Islam notwithstanding.
('34', 88, 1, 10, 226351) To pledge ourselves or to take an oath in the name of that God or with Him as witness is not something to be trifled with.
('34', 88, 1, 11, 226474) If having taken such an oath we violate our pledge we are guilty before God and man.
('34', 88, 1, 12, 226559) Personally I hold that a man who deliberately and intelligently takes a pledge and then breaks it forfeits his manhood.
('34', 88, 1, 13, 226679) And just as a copper coin treated with mercury not only becomes valueless when detected but also makes its owner liable to punishment, in the same way a man who lightly pledges his word and then breaks it becomes a man of straw and fits himself for punishment here as well as hereafter.
('34', 88, 1, 14, 226966) Sheth Haji Habib is proposing to administer an oath of a very serious character.
('34', 88, 1, 15, 227047) There is no one in this meeting who can be classed as an infant or as wanting in understanding.

('34', 88, 1, 18, 227427) “I know that pledges and vows are, and should be, taken on rare occasions.
('34', 88, 1, 19, 227502) A man who takes a vow every now and then is sure to stumble.
('34', 88, 1, 20, 227563) But if I can imagine a crisis in the history of the Indian community of South Africa when it would be in the fitness of things to take pledges, that crisis is surely now.
('34', 88, 1, 21, 227734) There is wisdom in taking serious steps with great caution and hesitation.
('34', 88, 1, 22, 227809) But caution and hesitation have their limits, and we have now passed them.
('34', 88, 1, 23, 227884) The Government has taken leave of all sense of decency.
('34', 88, 1, 24, 227940) We would only
('34', 89, 0, 1, 227954) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 90
('34', 89, 1, 2, 227995) be betraying our unworthiness and cowardice, if we cannot stake our all in the face of the conflagration which envelopes us and sit watching it with folded hands.
('34', 89, 1, 3, 228158) There is no doubt, therefore, that the present is a proper occasion for taking pledges.
('34', 89, 1, 4, 228246) But every one of us must think out for himself if he has the will and the ability to pledge himself.
('34', 89, 1, 5, 228347) Resolutions of this nature cannot be passed by a majority vote.

('34', 97, 4, 8, 248845) In the Transvaal itself we took all necessary measures for resisting the Black Act such as approaching the Local Government with memorials, etc.

('34', 101, 2, 3, 258016) In England and other Western countries there is one, in my view, barbarous custom of inaugurating movements at dinners.
('34', 101, 2, 4, 258136) The British Premier delivers in the Mansion House on the ninth of November an important speech in which he adumbrates his programme for the year and publishes his own forecast of the future, and which therefore attracts universal notice.
('34', 101, 2, 5, 258374) Cabinet ministers among others are invited to dinner by the Lord Mayor of London, and when the dinner is over, bottles of wine are uncorked, all present drink to the health of the host and the guest, and speeches too are made while this merry business is in progress.
('34', 101, 2, 6, 258642) The toast to the British Cabinet is proposed, and the Premier makes the important speech referred to in reply to it.
('34', 101, 2, 7, 258759) And as in public, so in private, the person with whom some important conversations are to be held is, as a matter of custom, invited to dinner, and the topic of the day is broached either at or after dinner.
('34', 101, 2, 8, 258967) We too had to observe this custom not once but quite a number of times, although of course we never touched meat or liquor.
('34', 101, 2, 9, 259091) We thus invited our principal supporters to lunch.
('34', 101, 2, 10, 259142) About a hundred covers were laid.
('34', 101, 2, 11, 259176) The idea was to tender our thanks to our friends, to bid them good bye and at the same time to constitute the Standing Committee.
('34', 101, 2, 12, 259306) Here too, speeches 2 were made, as usual, after dinner, and the Committee was also organized.
('34', 101, 2, 13, 259400) We thus obtained greater publicity for our movement.
('34', 101, 3, 14, 259453) After a stay in England of about six weeks we returned to South Africa.
('34', 101, 3, 15, 259525) When we reached Madeira, we received a cablegram from Mr. Ritch to the effect that Lord Elgin had declared that he was unable without further consideration to advise His Majesty the King that the Transvaal Asiatic Ordinance should be brought into operation.
('34', 101, 3, 16, 259783) 3 Our joy knew no bounds.
('34', 101, 3, 17, 259809) The steamer took about a fortnight to reach Cape Town from Madeira and we had quite a good time of it during these days and built many castles in the air about the coming redress of many more grievances.
('34', 101, 3, 18, 260013) But the ways of Providence are inscrutable.
('34', 101, 3, 19, 260057) We shall see in the next chapter how the castles we had laboriously built toppled down and passed into nothingness.

('34', 102, 1, 2, 260580) But I must place one or two sacred reminiscences on record before closing this chapter.
('34', 102, 1, 3, 260668) We had utilized every single minute of our time in England.
('34', 102, 1, 4, 260728) The sending of a large number of circulars, etc., could not be done single handed, and we were sorely in need of outside help.
('34', 102, 1, 5, 260855) Money indeed does bring us this kind of help, but my experience ranging over forty years has taught me that assistance thus purchased can never compare with purely voluntary service.
('34', 102, 1, 6, 261038) Fortunately for us we had many volunteer helpers.
('34', 102, 1, 7, 261088) Many an Indian youth who was in England for study surrounded us and some of them helped us day and night without any hope of reward or fame.

('34', 102, 1, 9, 261404) But there was an English friend named Simmonds who cast all these into the shade.

('34', 102, 1, 17, 261930) He believed that truth is always with the minority.

('34', 103, 2, 10, 264426) I have clearly observed in this life the fact that we become trustees or responsible agents from the time that we reach years of discretion.
