('34', 104, 2, 5, 266298) CHAPTER XV
('34', 104, 3, 6, 266309) CROOKED POLICY
('34', 104, 4, 7, 266324) As soon as we landed at Cape Town, 1 and more so when we reached Johannesburg, we saw that we had over rated the Madeira cablegram.
('34', 104, 4, 8, 266456) Mr. Ritch, who sent it, was not responsible for this.
('34', 104, 4, 9, 266510) He cabled only what he had heard about the measure being disallowed.
('34', 104, 4, 10, 266579) As we have already observed, the Transvaal was then, that is to say in 1906, a Crown Colony.
('34', 104, 4, 11, 266672) Crown Colonies are represented in England by agents one of whose duties it is to instruct the Secretary of State for the Colonies in all matters affecting Colonial interests.
('34', 104, 4, 12, 266847) The Transvaal was then represented by Sir Richard Solomon, the noted lawyer of South Africa.
('34', 104, 4, 13, 266940) Lord Elgin had disallowed the Black Act in consultation with him.
('34', 104, 4, 14, 267006) Responsible government was to be conferred on the Transvaal on January l, 1907. Lord Elgin therefore assured Sir Richard that, if an identical measure was passed by the Transvaal legislature constituted after the grant of responsible government, it would not be refused the royal assent.
('34', 104, 4, 15, 267294) But so long as the Transvaal was a Crown Colony, the Imperial Government would be held directly responsible for such class legislation, and as racial discrimination was a departure from the fundamental principles of the British Empire, he could not but advise His Majesty to disallow the measure in question.
('34', 104, 5, 16, 267603) If the measure was to be thus disallowed only in name and if the Transvaal Europeans could at the same time have their own way, Sir Richard Solomon had no reason to object to such an excellent arrangement.
('34', 104, 5, 17, 267809) I have characterized this as crooked policy, but I believe it could be given a still harsher name with perfect justice.
('34', 104, 5, 18, 267929) The Imperial Government is directly responsible for the legislation of Crown Colonies, and there is no place in its constitution for discrimination on
('34', 104, 6, 19, 268080) 1 On December 18, 1906
('34', 105, 0, 1, 268103) 106 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 105, 1, 2, 268145) the ground of race or colour.
('34', 105, 1, 3, 268175) So far so good.
('34', 105, 1, 4, 268191) One can also understand that the Imperial Government could not all at once disallow measures passed by the legislatures of Colonies enjoying responsible government.
('34', 105, 1, 5, 268356) But to hold private conferences with Colonial agents and in advance to promise the royal assent to legislation which is in open violation of the Imperial Constitution,—what is this if it is not a breach of faith and an injustice to those whose rights are thus pilfered?
('34', 105, 1, 6, 268626) Really speaking, Lord Elgin by his assurance encouraged the Transvaal Europeans in their anti Indian activities.
('34', 105, 1, 7, 268739) If he wanted to do this, he ought to have told the Indian deputation so in plain terms.
('34', 105, 1, 8, 268827) As a matter of fact, the Empire cannot escape responsibility even for the legislation of Colonies enjoying responsible government.
('34', 105, 1, 9, 268958) Even such Colonies are bound to accept the fundamental principles of the British Constitution.
('34', 105, 1, 10, 269053) As for example, no such colony can revive the institution of legalized slavery.
('34', 105, 1, 11, 269133) If Lord Elgin disallowed the Black Act because it was an improper piece of legislation, and he could disallow it only on this ground, it was his clear duty privately to have warned Sir Richard Solomon that the Transvaal could not enact such an iniquitous law after the grant of responsible government, and if it had any intention of doing so, the Imperial Government would be constrained to reconsider the advisability of granting it any such superior status.
('34', 105, 1, 12, 269593) Or he should have told Sir Richard that responsible government could be conferred only on condition that the rights of the Indians were fully safeguarded.
('34', 105, 1, 13, 269748) Instead of following such straightforward procedure, Lord Elgin made an outward show of friendliness to the Indians, while at the same time he really and secretly supported the Transvaal Government and encouraged it to pass once more the very law which he had himselfvetoed.
('34', 105, 1, 14, 270023) This is not the only or the first case of such tortuous policy followed by the British Empire.
('34', 105, 1, 15, 270118) Even an indifferent student of its history will easily recall similar incidents.
('34', 105, 1, 16, 270199) In Johannesburg, therefore, the sole topic of conversation was the trick played upon us by Lord Elgin and the Imperial Government.
('34', 105, 1, 17, 270330) Our disappointment in South Africa was as deep as had been our joy in Madeira.
('34', 105, 1, 18, 270409) Yet the immediate consequence of this deception was that the community became even more enthusiastic than before.

('34', 106, 1, 4, 270802) And even crooked policy would in time turn straight if only we were true to ourselves.
('34', 106, 1, 5, 270889) Responsible government was established in the Transvaal.
('34', 106, 1, 6, 270946) The first measure passed by the new Parliament was the budget; the second was the Asiatic Registration Act, which was, except for an alteration in the date specified in one of its clauses, which lapse of time made necessary, an exact replica of the original Ordinance, and was rushed through all its stages at a single sitting on March 21, 1907. 1 The disallowance of the Ordinance, therefore, was forgotten as if it was a dream.

('34', 107, 1, 3, 273053) According to the golden rule that a person’s words must not be interpreted so as to do him an injustice, I take it that the gentleman used this graphic language only in order to evince his strong feeling.
('34', 107, 1, 4, 273258) However that may be, on one side the Transvaal Government was preparing to throw the dog’s collar on the Indians’ necks, while on the other side the Indians were getting ready to put up a fight against the wicked policy of that Government and were concerting measures calculated to strengthen them in their resolution never to wear that collar.
('34', 107, 1, 5, 273603) Of course, we were writing letters to friends in England as well as in India and trying thus to keep them in touch with the situation from day to day.
('34', 107, 1, 6, 273754) But a satyagraha struggle depends but little upon help from outside, and it is only internal remedies that are effective.
('34', 107, 1, 7, 273876) The leaders’ time therefore was chiefly taken up with the endeavours to keep all the elements of the community up to the mark.
('34', 107, 1, 8, 274003) One important question before us was what agency we should use for carrying on the struggle.
('34', 107, 1, 9, 274096) The Transvaal British Indian Association had a large membership.
('34', 107, 1, 10, 274161) Satyagraha had not yet seen the light of day when it was established.
('34', 107, 1, 11, 274231) The Association had resisted in the past, and must resist in the future, not one obnoxious law, but quite a host of them.
('34', 107, 1, 12, 274353) Besides organizing resistance to obnoxious legislation, it had many other functions of a political and social nature to perform.
('34', 107, 1, 13, 274482) Again all the members of the Association were not pledged to resist the Black Act through satyagraha.
('34', 107, 1, 14, 274584) At the same time, we must take account of external risks to which the Association would be exposed in the event of its being identified with the satyagraha struggle.
('34', 107, 1, 15, 274750) What if the Transvaal Government declared the struggle to be seditious and all institutions carrying it on as illegal bodies?
('34', 107, 1, 16, 274876) What in such a case would be the position of members who were not satyagrahis?
('34', 107, 1, 17, 274955) Andwhat about the funds which were contributed at a time when satyagraha was not so much as thought of?
('34', 107, 1, 18, 275059) All these were weighty considerations.
('34', 107, 1, 19, 275098) Lastly, the satyagrahis were strongly of opinion that they not only must not entertain any ill will against those who did not join the struggle whether for want of faith or weakness or any other reason whatever, but must maintain their present friendly relations with them unimpaired and even work side by side with them
('34', 108, 0, 1, 275419) VOL. 34 : 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 109
('34', 108, 1, 2, 275465) in all other movements except the satyagraha struggle.
('34', 108, 2, 3, 275520) For all these reasons the community came to the conclusion that the satyagraha struggle should not be carried on through any of the existing oganizations.
('34', 108, 2, 4, 275675) They might render all help in their power and resist the Black Act in every way open to them except that of satyagraha, for which a new body named the ‘Passive Resistance Association’ was started by the satyagrahis.
('34', 108, 2, 5, 275891) The reader will see from this English name that the word satyagraha had not yet been invented when this new Association came into being.
('34', 108, 2, 6, 276028) Time fully justified the wisdom of constituting a fresh body for the work, and the satyagraha movement might perhaps have suffered a set back if any of the existing organizations had been mixed up with it.
('34', 108, 2, 7, 276234) Numerous members joined this new Association, and the community furnished it funds too with a lavish hand.
('34', 108, 3, 8, 276341) My experience has taught me that no movement ever stops or languishes for want of funds.

('34', 112, 2, 21, 287272) CHAPTER XVII
('34', 112, 3, 22, 287285) A RIFT IN THE LUTE
('34', 112, 4, 23, 287304) The first of July 1907 arrived, and saw the opening of permit offices.
('34', 112, 4, 24, 287375) The community had decided openly to picket each office, that is to say, to post volunteers on the roads leading there to, and these
('34', 113, 0, 1, 287507) 114 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 113, 1, 2, 287549) volunteers were to warn weak kneed Indians against the trap laid for them there.
('34', 113, 1, 3, 287630) Volunteers were provided with badges and expressly instructed not to be impolite to any Indian taking out a permit.
('34', 113, 1, 4, 287746) They must ask him his name, but if he refused to give it they must not on any account be violent or rude to him.
('34', 113, 1, 5, 287859) To every Indian going to the permit office, they were to hand a printed paper detailing the injuries which submission to the Black Act would involve and explain what was written in it.
('34', 113, 1, 6, 288044) They must behave towards the police too with due respect.
('34', 113, 1, 7, 288102) If the police abused or thrashed them, they must suffer peacefully; if the ill treatment by the police was insufferable they should leave the place.
('34', 113, 1, 8, 288251) If the police arrested them, they should gladly surrender themselves.
('34', 113, 1, 9, 288321) If some such incident occurred in Johannesburg, it should be brought to my notice.
('34', 113, 1, 10, 288404) At other places thelocal secretaries were to be informed and asked for further instructions.
('34', 113, 1, 11, 288497) Each party of pickets had a captain whose orders must be obeyed by the rest.

('34', 113, 1, 14, 288769) But not one was taken who was unknown to the local workers.

('34', 117, 1, 12, 298853) But that is not fair.
('34', 117, 1, 13, 298875) Rama Sundara did not become weak intentionally.
('34', 117, 1, 14, 298923) Man can change his temperament, can control it, but cannot eradicate it.
('34', 117, 1, 15, 298996) God has not given him so much liberty.
('34', 117, 1, 16, 299035) If the leopard can change his spots then only can man modify the peculiarities of his spiritual constitution.
('34', 117, 1, 17, 299145) Although Rama Sundara fled away, who can tell how 2 he might have repented of his weakness?
('34', 117, 1, 18, 299237) Or rather was not his very flight a powerful proof of his repentance?
('34', 117, 1, 19, 299307) There was no need for him to flee if he was shameless.
('34', 117, 1, 20, 299362) He could have taken out a permit and steered clear of jail by submission to the Black Act.

('34', 117, 1, 22, 299606) Why should we not judge him charitably and say that instead of doing anything of the kind, he, being ashamed of his weakness, hid his face from the community and even did it a service?

('34', 118, 1, 2, 299966) CHAPTER XIX
('34', 118, 2, 3, 299978) “INDIAN OPINION”
('34', 118, 3, 4, 299995) I propose to acquaint the reader with all the weapons, internal as well as external, employed in the satyagraha struggle and now therefore proceed to introduce to him Indian Opinion, a weekly journal which is published in South Africa to this very day.
('34', 118, 3, 5, 300248) The credit for starting the first Indian owned printing press in South Africa is due to a Gujarati gentleman, Shri Madanjit Vyavaharik.
('34', 118, 3, 6, 300384) After he had conducted the press for a few years in the midst of difficulties, he thought of bringing out a newspaper too.
('34', 118, 3, 7, 300507) He consulted the late Shri Mansukhlal Nazar and myself.
('34', 118, 3, 8, 300563) The paper was issued from Durban.
('34', 118, 4, 9, 300597) Shri Mansukhlal Nazar volunteered to act as unpaid editor.
('34', 118, 4, 10, 300656) From the very first the paper was conducted at a loss.
('34', 118, 4, 11, 300711) At last we decided to purchase a farm, to settle upon it all the workers, who must constitute themselves into a sort of commonwealth, and publish the paper from the farm.
('34', 118, 4, 12, 300882) The farm selected for the purpose is situated on a beautiful hill thirteen miles from Durban.
('34', 118, 4, 13, 300976) The nearest railway station is at a distance of three miles from the farm 2 and is called Phoenix.
('34', 118, 4, 14, 301075) The paper was and is called Indian Opinion.
('34', 118, 4, 15, 301119) It was formerly published in English, Gujarati, Hindi and Tamil.
('34', 118, 4, 16, 301184) But the Hindi and Tamil sections were eventually discontinued, 3 as the burden they imposed upon us seemed to be excessive; we would not find Tamil and Hindi writers willing to settle upon the farm and could not exercise a check upon them.
('34', 118, 4, 17, 301424) The paper was thus being published in English and Gujarati when the satyagraha struggle commenced.
('34', 118, 4, 18, 301523) Among the settlers on the farm were Gujaratis, North Indians and Tamilians as well as Englishmen.
('34', 118, 4, 19, 301621) After the premature death of Mansukhlal Nazar, his place as editor was taken by an English friend, Herbert Kitchin.
('34', 118, 4, 20, 301737) Then the post of editor was long filled by Mr. Henry S. L. Polak and during our incarceration the late Rev.
('34', 118, 4, 21, 301845) Joseph Doke also acted as editor.
('34', 118, 5, 22, 301879) 1 The inaugural issue appeared on June 4, 1903; vide “Ourselves”.
('34', 118, 5, 23, 301945) Gandhiji took over complete responsibility for the journal in October 1904; vide “Letter to G. K. Gokhale”, January 13, 1905. 2 Vide “Ourselves”, December 24, 1904. 3 This was done in February 1906; vide “Letter to M. H. Nazar”, January 5 1906 and “Our Tamil and Hindi Columns”, February 3, 1906. Publication of news in Hindi and Tamil was however resumed in 1914, vide “ Hindi and Tamil”, December 31, 1913.
('34', 119, 0, 1, 302354) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 119, 1, 2, 302396) Through the medium of this paper we could very well disseminate the news of the week among the community.
('34', 119, 1, 3, 302502) The English section kept those Indians informed about the movement who did not know Gujarati, and for Englishmen in India, England and South Africa, Indian Opinion served the purpose of a weekly newsletter.
('34', 119, 1, 4, 302709) I believe that a struggle which chiefly relies upon internal strength can be carried on without a newspaper, but it is also my experience that we could not perhaps have educated the local Indian community, nor kept Indians all over the world in touch with the course of events in South Africa in any other way with the same ease and success as through Indian Opinion, which therefore was certainly a most useful and potent weapon in our struggle.
('34', 119, 1, 5, 303156) As the community was transformed in the course and as a result of the struggle, so was Indian Opinion.
('34', 119, 1, 6, 303259) In the beginning we used to accept advertisements for it, and also execute job work in the printing press.
('34', 119, 1, 7, 303366) I observed that some of our best men had to be spared for this kind of work.
('34', 119, 1, 8, 303443) If we did receive advertisements for publication, there was constant difficulty in deciding which toaccept and which to refuse.
('34', 119, 1, 9, 303571) Again one would be inclined to refuse an objectionable advertisement, and yet be constrained to accept it, say because the advertiser was a leading member of the community and might take it ill if his advertisement was rejected.
('34', 119, 1, 10, 303800) Some of the good workers had to be set apart for canvassing and realizing outstandings from advertisers, not to speak of the flattery which advertisers claimed as their due.
('34', 119, 1, 11, 303974) Moreover, the view commended itself, that if the paper was conducted not because it yielded profit but purely with a view to service, the service should not be imposed upon the community by force but should be rendered only if the community wished.
('34', 119, 1, 12, 304223) And the clearest proof of such wish would be forthcoming if they became subscribers in sufficiently large numbers to make the paper self supporting.
('34', 119, 1, 13, 304372) Finally it seemed that it was in every way better for all concerned that we should approach the generality of the community and explain to them the duty of keeping their newspaper going rather than set about to induce a few traders to place their advertisements with us in the name of service.
('34', 119, 1, 14, 304666) On all these grounds we stopped advertisements in the paper, with the gratifying result that those who were at first engrossed in the advertisement department could now devote their labours to improving the paper.
('34', 119, 1, 15, 304880) The community realized at once their proprietorship of Indian Opinion and their consequent responsibility for maintaining it.
('34', 119, 1, 16, 305006) The workers were relieved of all
('34', 120, 0, 1, 305039) VOL. 34 : 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 121
('34', 120, 1, 2, 305085) anxiety in that respect.
('34', 120, 1, 3, 305110) Their only care now was to put their best work into the paper so long as the community wanted it, and they were not only not ashamed of requesting any Indian to subscribe to Indian Opinion, but thought it even their duty to do so.
('34', 120, 1, 4, 305341) A change came over the internal strength and the character of the paper, and it became a force to reckon with.
('34', 120, 1, 5, 305452) The number of subscribers which generally ranged between twelve and fifteen hundred increased day by day.
('34', 120, 1, 6, 305558) The rates of subscription had to be raised and yet when the struggle was at its height, there were as many as 3,500 subscribers.
('34', 120, 1, 7, 305687) The number of Indians who could read Indian Opinion in South Africa was at the outside 20,000, and therefore a circulation of over three thousand copies may be held to be quite satisfactory.
('34', 120, 1, 8, 305878) The community had made the paper their own to such an extent that if copies did not reach Johannesburg at the expected time, I would be flooded with complaints about it.
('34', 120, 1, 9, 306048) The paper generally reached Johannesburg on Sunday morning.
('34', 120, 1, 10, 306108) I know of many whose first occupation after they received the paper would be to read the Gujarati section through from beginning to end.
('34', 120, 1, 11, 306245) One of the company would read it, and the restwould surround him and listen.
('34', 120, 1, 12, 306322) Not all who wanted to read the paper could afford to subscribe to it by themselves and some of them would therefore club together for the purpose.
('34', 120, 1, 13, 306469) Just as we stopped advertisements in the paper, we ceased to take job work in the press, 1 and for nearly the same reasons.
('34', 120, 1, 14, 306593) Compositors had now some time to spare, which was utilized in the publication of books.
('34', 120, 1, 15, 306681) As here too there was no intention of reaping profits and as the books were printed only to help the struggle forward, they commanded good sales.
('34', 120, 1, 16, 306827) Thus both the paper and the press made their contribution to the struggle, and as satyagraha gradually took root in the community, there was clearly visible a corresponding moral amelioration of the paper as well as of the press from the standpoint of satyagraha.
('34', 120, 2, 17, 307091) 1 The decision to stop advertisements was taken in 1912 while job work had been given up “many years” earlier; vide “Ourselves”, September 14, 1912. 2 For the identification of Indian Opinion with the Indian struggle in South Africa and the stresses it went through, vide for instance “Letter to Maganlal Gandhi”, November 27, 1909 and “Preface to ‘Indian Home Rule’ ”, March 20, 1910.

('34', 121, 2, 3, 307530) A SERIES OF ARRESTS
('34', 121, 3, 4, 307550) We have seen how the Government failed to reap any advantage from Rama Sundara’s arrest.
('34', 121, 3, 5, 307639) On the other hand they observed the spirit of the Indian community rising rapidly.
('34', 121, 3, 6, 307722) The officers of the Asiatic Department were diligent readers of Indian Opinion.
('34', 121, 3, 7, 307802) Secrecy had been deliberately ruled out of the movement.
('34', 121, 3, 8, 307859) Indian Opinion was an open book to whoever wanted to gauge the strength and the weakness of the community, be he a friend, an enemy or a neutral.
('34', 121, 3, 9, 308005) The workers had realized at the very outset that secrecy had no place in a movement where one could do no wrong, where there was no scope for duplicity or cunning, and where strength constituted the single guarantee of victory.
('34', 121, 3, 10, 308233) The very interest of the community demanded that if the disease of weakness was to be eradicated, it must be first properly diagnosed and given due publicity.
('34', 121, 3, 11, 308392) When the officers saw that this was the policy of Indian Opinion, the paper became for them a faithful mirror of the current history of the Indian community.
('34', 121, 3, 12, 308550) They thus came to think the strength of the movement could not by any means be broken so long as certain leaders were at large.
('34', 121, 3, 13, 308678) Some of the leading men were consequently served with a notice in the Christmas week of 1907 to appear before the Magistrate.
('34', 121, 3, 14, 308804) It must be admitted that this was an act of courtesy on the part of the officers concerned.
('34', 121, 3, 15, 308896) They could havearrested the leaders by warrant if they had chosen to do so.
('34', 121, 3, 16, 308972) Instead they issued notices and this, besides being evidence of their courtesy, also showed their confidence that the leaders were willing and prepared to be arrested.
('34', 121, 3, 17, 309140) Those who had thus been warned appeared before the Court on the date specified, Saturday, December 28, 1907, to show cause why, having failed to apply for registration as required by law, they should not be ordered to leave the Transvaal within a given period.
('34', 121, 4, 18, 309401) One of these was one Mr. Quinn, the leader of the Chinese residents of Johannesburg, who numbered three to four hundred, and were either traders or farmers.

('34', 122, 1, 2, 309973) Chinese are.
('34', 122, 1, 3, 309986) The modern progress of agriculture in America and other countries defies description, but I consider it to be still in an experimental stage.
('34', 122, 1, 4, 310128) China, on the other hand, is an old country like India and a comparison between India and China would be therefore fairly instructive.
('34', 122, 1, 5, 310263) I observed the agricultural methods of the Chinese in Johannesburg and also talked with them on the subject, and this gave me the impression that the Chinese are more intelligent as well as diligent than we are.
('34', 122, 1, 6, 310475) We often allow land to lie fallow thinking it is of no use, while the Chinese would grow good crops upon it, thanks to their minute knowledge of varying soils.
('34', 122, 2, 7, 310635) The Black Act applied to the Chinese as well as to the Indians whom they therefore joined in the satyagraha struggle.
('34', 122, 2, 8, 310753) Still from first to last the activities of the two communities were not allowed to be mixed up.
('34', 122, 2, 9, 310849) Each worked through its own independent organization.
('34', 122, 2, 10, 310903) This arrangement produced the beneficent result that so long as both the communities stood to their guns, each would be a source of strength to the other.
('34', 122, 2, 11, 311058) But if one of the two gave way, that could leave the morale of the other unaffected or at least the other would steer clear of the danger of a total collapse.
('34', 122, 2, 12, 311217) Many of the Chinese eventually fell away as their leader played them false.

('34', 122, 2, 18, 311931) I would like to introduce to the reader one out of the several leading Indians who constituted the first batch of prisoners, Shri Thambi Naidoo.
('34', 122, 2, 19, 312076) Thambi Naidoo was a Tamilian born in Mauritius where his parents had migrated from Madras State.
('34', 122, 2, 20, 312173) He was an ordinary trader.

('34', 123, 1, 3, 312806) A working knowledge of so many languages was not a rare accomplishment among the Indians of South Africa, hundreds of whom could claim a general acquaintance with all these languages.
('34', 123, 1, 4, 312990) These men become such good linguists almost without effort.
('34', 123, 1, 5, 313050) And that is because their brains are not fatigued by education received through the medium of a foreign tongue, their memory is sharp, and they acquire these different languages simply by talking with people who speak them and by observation.
('34', 123, 1, 6, 313293) This does not involve any considerable strain on their brains but on the other hand the easy mental exercise leads to a natural development of their intellect.

('34', 124, 1, 4, 315548) I had just heard from Pretoria that my compatriots there had been sentenced to three months’ imprisonment with hard labour, and had been fined a heavy amount, in lieu of payment of which they would receive a further period of three months’ hard labour.
('34', 124, 1, 5, 315801) If these men had committed an offence, I had committed a greater offence and I therefore asked the Magistrate to impose upon me the heaviest penalty.
('34', 124, 1, 6, 315951) The Magistrate, however, did not agree to my request and sentenced me to two months’ simple imprisonment.

('34', 126, 1, 18, 321989) When satyagrahis began to be arrested in large numbers, they were sentenced to imprisonment with hard labour, either because the magistrates lost patience, or because, as we thought, they had received some such instructions from the Government.
('34', 126, 1, 19, 322234) Even today, I think we were right in our conjecture, as, if we leave out the first few cases in which simple imprisonment was awarded, never afterwards throughout the long drawn out struggle was there pronounced a sentence of simple imprisonment, even women having been punished with hard labour.
('34', 126, 1, 20, 322531) If all the magistrates had not received the same orders or instructions, and if yet by mere coincidence they sentenced all men and women at all times to hard labour, that must be held to be almost a miracle.
('34', 126, 1, 21, 322739) In Johannesburg jail prisoners not condemned to hard labour got ‘mealie pap’ in the morning.
('34', 126, 1, 22, 322832) There was no salt in it, but each prisoner was given some salt separately.
('34', 126, 1, 23, 322907) At noon the prisoners were given four ounces of rice, four ounces of bread, one ounce of ghee and a little salt, and in the evening ‘mealie pap’ and some vegetable,

('34', 127, 1, 2, 323114) chiefly potatoes of which two were given if they were small and only one if they were big in size.
('34', 127, 1, 3, 323213) None of us were satisfied with this diet.
('34', 127, 1, 4, 323255) The rice was cooked soft.
('34', 127, 1, 5, 323281) We asked the prison medical officer for some condiments, and told him that condiments were allowed in jails in India.
('34', 127, 1, 6, 323399) “This is not India,” was the stern answer.

('34', 127, 1, 8, 323640) “Prisoners must not indulge in arguments on medical grounds,” replied the doctor.
('34', 127, 1, 9, 323722) “You do get muscle building food, as twice a week you are served boiled beans instead of maize.” The doctor’s argument was sound if the human stomach was capable of extracting the various elements out of various foods taken at various times in a week or fortnight.
('34', 127, 1, 10, 323987) As a matter of fact he had no intention whatever of looking to our convenience.
('34', 127, 1, 11, 324067) The Superintendent permitted us to cook our food ourselves.

('34', 127, 1, 13, 324222) If the vegetable ration issued was short in weight, he would insist on getting full weight.
('34', 127, 1, 14, 324314) 2 On vegetable days which were two in a week we cooked twice and on other days only once, as we were allowed to cook other things for ourselves only for the noon day meal.
('34', 127, 1, 15, 324486) We were somewhat better off after we began to cook our own food.
('34', 127, 1, 16, 324551) But whether or not we succeeded in obtaining these conveniences, every one of us was firm in his resolution of passing his term in jail in perfect happiness and peace.
('34', 127, 1, 17, 324719) The number of satyagrahi prisoners gradually rose to over 150. As we were all simple imprisonment convicts, we had no work to do except keeping the cells, etc., clean.
('34', 127, 1, 18, 324887) We asked the Superintendent for work, and he replied: “I am sorry I cannot give you work, as, if I did, I should be held to have committed an offence.
('34', 127, 1, 19, 325038) But you can devote as much time as you please to keeping the place clean.” We asked for some such exercise as drill, as we had observed even the Negro prisoners with hard labour being drilled in addition to their usual work.
('34', 127, 1, 20, 325263) The Superintendent replied, “If your warder has time and if he gives you drill, I will not object to it; but I will not require him to do it, as he is hard worked as it is, and your arrival in unexpectedly large numbers has made his work harder still.” The warder was a good man and this qualified permission was quite enough for him.
('34', 127, 1, 21, 325598) He began to drill us every morning with great interest.
('34', 127, 1, 22, 325654) This drill must be performed in the small yard before our

('34', 128, 3, 7, 326339) THE FIRST SETTLEMENT
('34', 128, 4, 8, 326360) We had thus been in jail for a fortnight, when fresh arrivals brought the news that there were going on some negotiations about a compromise with the Government.
('34', 128, 4, 9, 326522) After two or three days 1 Mr. Albert Cartwright, editor of The Transvaal Leader, a Johannesburg daily, came to see me.
('34', 128, 4, 10, 326641) All the daily papers then conducted in Johannesburg were the property of one or another of the European owners of the gold mines, but except in cases where the interests of these magnates were at stake, the editors were unfettered in the expression of their own views on all public questions.
('34', 128, 4, 11, 326934) Only very able and well known men were selected as editors.
('34', 128, 4, 12, 326994) For instance, the editor of The Daily Star had formerly been Private Secretary to Lord Milner, and later went to England to take Mr.Buckle’s place as editor of The Times.
('34', 128, 4, 13, 327165) Mr. Albert Cartwright of The Transvaal Leader was as broad minded as he was able.
('34', 128, 4, 14, 327247) He had almost always supported the Indian cause in his columns.
('34', 128, 4, 15, 327311) He and I had become good friends.
('34', 128, 4, 16, 327345) He saw General Smuts after I was sent to jail.
('34', 128, 4, 17, 327392) General Smuts welcomed his mediation.
('34', 128, 4, 18, 327430) Mr. Cartwright thereupon met the Indian leaders, who said, “We know nothing about legal technicalities, and cannot possibly talk about compromise so long as Gandhi is in prison.
('34', 128, 4, 19, 327608) We desire settlement, but if Government wants it while our men are in jail, you should see Gandhi.
('34', 128, 4, 20, 327707) We will ratify any arrangement which he accepts.” Mr. Cartwright thus came to see me and brought with him terms of settlement drafted or approved of by General Smuts.
('34', 128, 4, 21, 327874) I did not like the vague language of the document, but was all the same prepared myself to put my signature to it with one alteration.
('34', 128, 4, 22, 328009) However, I informed Mr. Cartwright that I could not sign it without consulting my fellow prisoners, even if I took the consent of the Indians outside prison for granted.
('34', 128, 5, 23, 328179) 1 On January 21, 1908
('34', 129, 0, 1, 328201) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 129, 1, 2, 328243) The substance of the proposed settlement was that the Indians should register voluntarily and not under any law, that the details to be entered in the new certificates of registration should be settled by Government in consultation with the Indian community, and that if the majority of the Indians underwent voluntary registration, Government should repeal the Black Act and take steps with a view to legalizing the voluntary registration.
('34', 129, 1, 3, 328684) The draft did not make quite clear the condition which required Government to repeal the Black Act.
('34', 129, 1, 4, 328784) I therefore suggested a change calculated to place this beyond all doubt from my own standpoint.
('34', 129, 1, 5, 328881) Mr. Cartwright did not like even this little addition and said, “General Smuts considers this draft to be final.
('34', 129, 1, 6, 328994) I have approved of it myself, and I can assure you that if you all undergo re registration, the Black Act is bound to be repealed.” I replied, “Whether or not there is a settlement, we shall always be grateful to you for your kindness and help.
('34', 129, 1, 7, 329239) I should not like to suggest a single unnecessary alteration in the draft.
('34', 129, 1, 8, 329314) I do not object to such language as would uphold the prestige of Government.
('34', 129, 1, 9, 329391) But where I myself am doubtful about the meaning, I must certainly suggest a change of language, and if there is to be a settlement after all, both the parties must have the right to alter the draft.
('34', 129, 1, 10, 329591) General Smuts need not confront us with an ultimatum, saying that these terms are final.
('34', 129, 1, 11, 329680) He has already aimed one pistol in the shape of the Black Act at the Indians.
('34', 129, 1, 12, 329758) What can he hope to gain by aiming a second?” Mr. Cartwright had nothing to say against this argument, and he promised to place my suggestion for the change before General Smuts.
('34', 129, 2, 13, 329937) I consulted my fellow prisoners.
('34', 129, 2, 14, 329970) They too did not like the language, but agreed to the settlement if General Smuts would accept the draft with my amendment.
('34', 129, 2, 15, 330094) New comers to jail had brought a message from the leaders outside that I should accept any suitable compromise without waiting for their consent.

('34', 131, 2, 3, 332995) OPPOSITION AND ASSAULT
('34', 131, 3, 4, 333018) I reached Johannesburg at about 9 p.m.
('34', 131, 3, 5, 333057) and went direct to the Chairman, Sheth Yusuf Mian 1. He knew that I had been taken to Pretoria, and was hence rather expecting me.
('34', 131, 3, 6, 333188) Still it was a pleasant surprise for him and others to find me unaccompanied by a warder.
('34', 131, 3, 7, 333278) 2 I suggested that a meeting should be called at once with such attendance as was possible at a very short notice.
('34', 131, 3, 8, 333393) The Chairman and other friends agreed with me.
('34', 131, 3, 9, 333440) As most of the Indians lived in the same quarter, it was not difficult to send round notice of the proposed meeting.
('34', 131, 3, 10, 333557) The Chairman’s house was near the mosque, and meetings were usually held on the grounds of the mosque.
('34', 131, 3, 11, 333660) There was hence not much to be done by way of arrangement for the meeting.
('34', 131, 3, 12, 333735) It was enough to have one light on the platform.
('34', 131, 3, 13, 333784) The meeting was held that very night at about 11 or 12. 3 The audience numbered nearly a thousand, in spite of the shortness of the notice and the late hour.
('34', 131, 3, 14, 333942) Before the meeting was held, I had explained the terms of the settlement to the leaders present.

('34', 131, 3, 16, 334069) But all of them understood the situation after they had heard me.
('34', 131, 3, 17, 334135) Every one of them, however, was troubled by one doubt, ‘What if General Smuts broke faith with us?
('34', 131, 3, 18, 334234) The Black Act might not be enforced but it would always hang over our heads like the sword of Damocles.
('34', 131, 3, 19, 334338) If in the meanwhile we registered voluntarily, we would have knowinglyplayed in the adversary’s hands and surrendered the most powerful weapon in our possession for resisting the Act.
('34', 131, 3, 20, 334522) The right order for the settlement was that the Act should be repealed first and then we should be called upon to register voluntarily.’ I liked this argument.
('34', 131, 3, 21, 334682) I felt proud of the keen common sense and high courage of those who advanced it and saw that such was the stuff of which satyagrahis were made.
('34', 131, 3, 22, 334826) In answer to that argument I observed: “It is an excellent argument and deserves serious consideration.
('34', 131, 3, 23, 334930) There would be nothing like it if we registered
('34', 131, 4, 24, 334978) 1 Essop Mia 2 A report in The Transsaal Leader, 31 1 1908, referring to Gandhiji’s unexpected visit to Johannesburg, covered an interview with him on January 30; vide “Interview to The Transvaal Leader”.

('34', 132, 0, 1, 335294) VOL. 34 : 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 133
('34', 132, 1, 2, 335340) voluntarily only after the Act was repealed.
('34', 132, 1, 3, 335385) But then it would not be in the nature of a compromise.
('34', 132, 1, 4, 335441) Compromise means that both the parties make large concessions on all points except where a principle is involved.
('34', 132, 1, 5, 335555) Our principle is that we would not submit to the Black Act, and therefore, would not, in virtue of it, do even such things as were otherwise unobjectionable; and to this principle we must adhere at all costs.
('34', 132, 1, 6, 335764) The principle with the Government is that in order to prevent the illegal entry of Indians into the Transvaal, it must get many Indians to take out non transferable permits with marks of identification and thus set the suspicions of the Europeans at rest and allay all their fears; and the Government can never give it up on its part.
('34', 132, 1, 7, 336099) We have admitted this principle of the Government by our conduct up to date, and therefore even if we feel like resisting it we may not do so until we find fresh grounds for such a departure.
('34', 132, 1, 8, 336291) Our struggle aimed not at the abrogation of this principle but at removing the stigma which the Black Act sought to attach to the community.
('34', 132, 1, 9, 336432) If, therefore, we now utilize the new and powerful force which has sprung up in the community for gaining a fresh point, it would ill become us, who claim to be satyagrahis.
('34', 132, 1, 10, 336606) Consequently, we cannot justly object to the present settlement.
('34', 132, 1, 11, 336671) As for the argument that we must not surrender our weapons before the Act is repealed, it is easily answered.
('34', 132, 1, 12, 336781) A satyagrahi bids goodbye to fear.
('34', 132, 1, 13, 336816) He is therefore never afraid of trusting the opponent.
('34', 132, 1, 14, 336871) Even if the opponent plays him false twenty times, the satyagrahi is ready to trust him for the twenty first time, for an implicit trust in human nature is the very essence of his creed.
('34', 132, 1, 15, 337058) Again, to say that in trusting the Government we play into its hands is to betray an ignorance of the principles of satyagraha.
('34', 132, 1, 16, 337186) Suppose we register voluntarily, but the Government commits a breach of faith and fails to redeem its promise to repeal the Act.
('34', 132, 1, 17, 337315) Could we not then resort to satyagraha?
('34', 132, 1, 18, 337355) If we refused to show at the proper time thecertificates of registration we take out, our registration would count for nothing, and Government could not distinguish between ourselves and the Indians who might enter the Transvaal surreptitiously.
('34', 132, 1, 19, 337601) Therefore, whether there is or there is not any law in force, the Government cannot exercise control over us without our co operation.
('34', 132, 1, 20, 337736) The existence of a law means that if we refuse to accept the restriction sought to be imposed through it by the Government, we are liable to punishment, and generally it so happens that the fear of punishment leads men to submit to the restriction.
('34', 132, 1, 21, 337985) But a satyagrahi differs from the generality of men in this, that if he submits to a restriction, he
('34', 133, 0, 1, 338086) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 133, 1, 2, 338128) submits voluntarily, not because he is afraid of punishment but because he thinks that such submission is essential to the common weal.
('34', 133, 1, 3, 338264) And such is precisely our position regarding registration, which cannot be affected by any breach of faith, however flagrant, on the part of the Government.
('34', 133, 1, 4, 338421) We are the creators of this position of ours, and we alone can change it.
('34', 133, 1, 5, 338495) We are fearless and free, so long as we have the weapon of satyagraha in our hands.
('34', 133, 1, 6, 338579) And if anyone thinks that the community may not be as strong afterwards as it is today, I should say that he is not a satyagrahi nor has he any understanding of satyagraha.
('34', 133, 1, 7, 338752) That would mean that the present strength of the community is not real strength but is in the nature of a momentary effervescence or intoxication, and if that is so, we do not deserve to win, and the fruits of victory will slip out of our hands even if we win.
('34', 133, 1, 8, 339013) Suppose the Government first abrogates the Act and we then register voluntarily.
('34', 133, 1, 9, 339094) Suppose further that the Government afterwards enacts the same obnoxious law and compels the Indians to register.

('34', 133, 1, 11, 339284) And if we are doubtful about our strength today, then too shall we be in an equally bad case.

('34', 133, 1, 13, 339550) And I am also of opinion that when our opponents recognize our humility and sense of justice, they would give up or at least mitigate their opposition.”
('34', 133, 2, 14, 339703) I was thus able fully to satisfy the one or two of the small company who struck a discordant note, but I did not then even dream of the storm which was to break out at the midnight meeting.

('34', 135, 1, 14, 344907) Although there were not entertained any feelings of hatred against those who had submitted to the Black Act, their action had been condemned in plain and strong terms on the public platform as well as in Indian Opinion.

('34', 136, 1, 3, 345708) There were only a few Pathans living in the Transvaal, their total number hardly exceeding fifty.

('34', 136, 1, 6, 346033) The Pathans are an unsophisticated and credulous race.

('34', 136, 1, 8, 346126) To kill and get killed is an ordinary thing in their eyes, and if they are angry with anyone, they will thrash him and sometimes even kill him.

('34', 164, 3, 7, 415600) RESUMPTION OF THE STRUGGLE
('34', 164, 4, 8, 415627) If on the one hand we were trying to induce General Smuts to fulfil his part of the settlement, we were on the other hand enthusiastically engaged in ‘educating’ the community.

('34', 165, 1, 2, 417609) The so called ultimatum may be thus summarized: ‘The point of the agreement between the Indians and General Smuts clearly was that if the Indians registered voluntarily, he on his part should bring forward in the Legislature a bill to validate such registration and to repeal the Asiatic Act.
('34', 165, 1, 3, 417902) It is well known that the Indians have registered voluntarily to the satisfaction of the Government, and therefore the Asiatic Act must be repealed.
('34', 165, 1, 4, 418051) The community has sent many communications to General Smuts and taken allpossible legal steps to obtain redress but thus far to no purpose.
('34', 165, 1, 5, 418191) At a time when the bill is passing through the Legislature, it is up to the leaders to apprise the Government of the discontent and strong feeling prevalent in the community.
('34', 165, 1, 6, 418366) We regret to state that, if the Asiatic Act is not repealed in terms of the settlement and if Government’s decision to that effect is not communicated to the Indians before a specific date, the certificates collected by the Indians would be burnt, and they would humbly but firmly take the consequences.’ One reason why this letter was held to be an ultimatum was that it prescribed a time limit for reply.
('34', 165, 1, 7, 418773) Another reason was that the Europeans looked upon the Indians as savages.
('34', 165, 1, 8, 418847) If the Europeans had considered the Indians to be their equals, they would have found this letter perfectly courteous and would have given it most serious consideration.
('34', 165, 1, 9, 419017) But the fact that the Europeans thought Indians to be barbarians was a sufficient reason for the Indians to write such a letter.
('34', 165, 1, 10, 419146) The Indians must either confess to their being barbarians and consent to be suppressed as such, or else they must take active steps in repudiation of the charge of barbarism.
('34', 165, 1, 11, 419321) This letter was the first of such steps.
('34', 165, 1, 12, 419362) If there had not been behind the letter an iron determination to act up to it; it would have been held an impertinence, and the Indians would have proved themselves to be a thoughtless and foolish race.
('34', 165, 1, 13, 419565) The reader will perhaps point out that the charge of barbarism was repudiated in 1906 when the satyagraha pledge was taken.
('34', 165, 1, 14, 419689) And, if so, there was nothing new about this letter which might warrant my giving it so much importance and dating the denial of the charge from it.
('34', 165, 1, 15, 419838) This is true so far as it goes; but on thinking a little more deeply, it will appear that the repudiation really began with this letter.
('34', 165, 1, 16, 419975) It should be remembered that the satyagraha pledge came in almost by accident, and the subsequent imprisonments followed as an inevitable corollary.
('34', 165, 1, 17, 420124) The community then gained largely in stature,
('34', 166, 0, 1, 420170) VOL. 34 : 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 167
('34', 166, 1, 2, 420216) but unconsciously.
('34', 166, 1, 3, 420235) But when this letter was written, there was a deliberate intention of claiming full knowledge and high prestige.
('34', 166, 1, 4, 420348) Now as well as before the object aimed at was the repeal of the Black Act.
('34', 166, 1, 5, 420423) But there was change in the style of language used, in the methods of work selected and in other things besides.
('34', 166, 1, 6, 420536) When a slave salutes a master and a friend salutes a friend, the form is the same in either case, but there is a world of difference between the two, which enables the detached observer to recognize the slave and the friend at once.

('34', 169, 2, 14, 429623) CHAPTER XXVIII
('34', 169, 3, 15, 429638) CHARGE OF FORCING FRESH ISSUE During the same year in which the Black Act was passed General Smuts carried through the Legislature another bill called the Transvaal Immigrants Restriction Bill (Act 15 of 1907) 1, which was ostensibly of general application but was chiefly aimed at the Indians.
('34', 169, 3, 16, 429933) This Act generally followed the lines of similar legislation in Natal, but it treated as prohibited immigrants those who could pass education tests
('34', 169, 4, 17, 430081) 1 This came into force on January 1, 1908.
('34', 170, 0, 1, 430124) VOL. 34 : 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 171
('34', 170, 1, 2, 430170) but were ineligible for registration under the Asiatic Act, and was thus indirectly made an instrument for preventing the entry of a single Indian newcomer.
('34', 170, 1, 3, 430327) It was absolutely essential for the Indians to resist this fresh inroad on their rights, but the question was whether it should be made a plank in the satyagraha struggle.
('34', 170, 1, 4, 430499) The community was not bound as to when and regarding what subjects they should offer satyagraha, in deciding which question they must only not transgress the limits prescribed by wisdom and appreciation of their own capacity.
('34', 170, 1, 5, 430725) Satyagraha offered on every occasion seasonable or otherwise would be corrupted into duragraha.
('34', 170, 1, 6, 430821) And if anyone takes to satyagraha without having measured his own strength and afterwards sustains a defeat, he not only disgraces himself but also brings the matchless weapon of satyagraha into disrepute by his folly.
('34', 170, 1, 7, 431040) The Satyagraha Committee saw that the Indians’ satyagraha was being offered only against the Black Act, and that if the Black Act was once repealed, the Immigration Restriction Act would lose the sting to which I have referred.
('34', 170, 1, 8, 431268) Still if the Indians did not take any steps regarding the Immigration Act from an idea that a separate movement against it was unnecessary, their silence might be misconstrued as implying their consent to the total prohibition of Indian immigration in the future.
('34', 170, 1, 9, 431532) The Immigration Act too must therefore be opposed, and the only question was: Should this also be included in the satyagraha struggle?
('34', 170, 1, 10, 431667) The community’s view was that it was their duty to include in the satyagraha any fresh attacks on their rights made while the struggle was in progress.
('34', 170, 1, 11, 431819) If they did not feel strong enough to do so, that was altogether a different matter.
('34', 170, 1, 12, 431904) The leaders came to the conclusion that their lack or deficiency of strength should not be made a pretext for letting the Immigration Act alone, and that therefore this Act too must be covered by the satyagraha struggle.
('34', 170, 2, 13, 432125) Correspondence was therefore carried on with the Government 1
('34', 170, 3, 14, 432187) on this subject.

('34', 171, 1, 2, 432669) He therefore charged me with raising a fresh point, and he told as well as wrote to our supporters that they did not know me as he did.
('34', 171, 1, 3, 432805) If he yielded an inch, I would ask for an ell and therefore it was that he was not repealing the Asiatic Act.

('34', 172, 1, 2, 435396) not only did not give me up or the movement but grew even more zealous in supporting us, and the Indians saw later on that they would have been in for no end of trouble if their satyagraha had not been extended to the Immigration Act also.
('34', 172, 1, 3, 435636) My experience has taught me that a law of progression applies to every righteous struggle.
('34', 172, 1, 4, 435727) But in the case of satyagraha the law amounts to an axiom.
('34', 172, 1, 5, 435786) As the Ganga advances, other streams flow into it, and hence at the mouth it grows so wide that neither bank is to be seen and a person sailingupon the river cannot make out where the river ends and the sea begins.
('34', 172, 1, 6, 436001) So also as a satyagraha struggle progresses onward, many another element helps toswell its current, and there is a constant growth in the results to which it leads.
('34', 172, 1, 7, 436166) This is really inevitable, and is bound up with the first principles of satyagraha.
('34', 172, 1, 8, 436250) For in satyagraha the minimum is also the maximum, and as it is the irreducible minimum, there is no question of retreat, and the only movement possible is an advance.
('34', 172, 1, 9, 436418) In other struggles, even when they are righteous, the demand is first pitched a little higher so as to admit of future reduction, and hence the law of progression does not apply to all of them without exception.
('34', 172, 1, 10, 436630) But I must explain how the law of progression comes into play when the minimum is also the maximum as in satyagraha.
('34', 172, 1, 11, 436747) The Ganga does not leave its course in search of tributaries.
('34', 172, 1, 12, 436809) Even so does the satyagrahi not leave his path which is sharp as the sword’s edge.
('34', 172, 1, 13, 436892) But as the tributaries spontaneously join the Ganga as it advances, so it is with the river that is satyagraha.
('34', 172, 1, 14, 437004) Seeing that the Immigration Act was included in the satyagraha, some Indians ignorant of the principles of satyagraha insisted upon the whole mass of the anti Indian legislation in the Transvaal being similarly treated.
('34', 172, 1, 15, 437224) Others again suggested a mobilization of Indians all over South Africa and the offering of satyagraha against all anti Indian legislation in Natal, the Cape Colony, the Orange Free State, etc., while the Transvaal struggle was on.
('34', 172, 1, 16, 437455) Both the suggestions involved a breach of principle.
('34', 172, 1, 17, 437508) I distinctly said that it would be dishonest now, having seen the opportunity, to take up a position which was not in view when satyagraha was started.
('34', 172, 1, 18, 437660) No matter how strong we were, the present struggle must close when the demands for which it was commenced were accepted.
('34', 172, 1, 19, 437781) I am confident that if we had not adhered to this principle, instead of winning, we would not only have lost all along the line, but also forfeited the sympathy which had been enlisted in our favour.
('34', 172, 1, 20, 437981) On the other hand if the adversary himself creates new difficulties for us
('34', 173, 0, 1, 438056) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 174
('34', 173, 1, 2, 438098) while the struggle is in progress, they become automatically included in it.
('34', 173, 1, 3, 438175) A satyagrahi, without being false to his faith, cannot disregard new difficulties which confront him while he is pursuing his own course.
('34', 173, 1, 4, 438313) The adversary is not a satyagrahi,—satyagraha against satyagraha is impossible,—and is not bound by any limit of maximum or minimum.
('34', 173, 1, 5, 438446) He can therefore try if he wishes to frighten the satyagrahi by raising novel issues.
('34', 173, 1, 6, 438532) But the satyagrahi has renounced all fear, tackles by satyagraha the later difficulties as well as the former and trusts that it will help him to hold his own against all odds.
('34', 173, 1, 7, 438709) Therefore as a satyagraha struggle is prolonged, that is to say by the adversary, it is the adversary who stands to lose from his own standpoint, and it is the satyagrahi who stands to gain.
('34', 173, 1, 8, 438900) We shall come across other illustrations of the working of this law in the later stages of this struggle.
('34', 173, 2, 9, 439006) CHAPTER XXIX
('34', 173, 3, 10, 439019) SORABJI SHAPURJI ADAJANIA Now as satyagraha was made to embrace the Immigration Act as well, satyagrahis had to test the right of educated Indians to enter the Transvaal.
('34', 173, 3, 11, 439190) The Committee decided that the test should not be made through any ordinary Indian.
('34', 173, 3, 12, 439274) The idea was that some Indian, who did not come within the four corners of the definition of a prohibited immigrant in the new Act in so far as the definition was acceptable to the community, should enter the Transvaal and go to jail.

('34', 181, 3, 26, 460004) CHAPTER XXXI
('34', 181, 4, 27, 460017) DEPORTATIONS
('34', 181, 5, 28, 460030) The obnoxious Acts provided for three kinds of punishment, viz., fine, imprisonment and deportation.
('34', 181, 5, 29, 460131) The courts were empowered simultaneously to award all the punishments, and all magistrates were given jurisdiction to impose the maximum penalties.
('34', 181, 5, 30, 460279) At first
('34', 181, 6, 31, 460288) 1 The original adds: “They could not have a better opportunity to do so.”
('34', 182, 0, 1, 460362) VOL. 34 : 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 183
('34', 182, 1, 2, 460408) deportation 1 meant taking the ‘culprit’ into the limits of Natal, the Orange Free State or Portuguese East Africa beyond the Transvaal frontier and leaving him there.
('34', 182, 1, 3, 460576) As for instance, the Indians who crossed over from Natal were taken beyond the limits of Volksrust station and there left to their own devices.
('34', 182, 1, 4, 460720) Deportation of this kind was a farce pure and simple, as it involved only a little inconvenience, and instead of disheartening them it only encouraged the Indians still further.
('34', 182, 1, 5, 460898) The local Government therefore had to find out fresh means of harassing the Indians.

('34', 193, 1, 2, 487609) Johannesburg.
('34', 193, 1, 3, 487623) Mr. Kallenbach, whose acquaintance the reader has already made, bought a farm of about 1,100 acres and gave the use of it to satyagrahis free of any rent or charge (May 30, 1910).
('34', 193, 1, 4, 487803) 1 Upon the Farm there were nearly one thousand fruit bearing trees and a small house at the foot of a hill with accommodation for half a dozen persons.
('34', 193, 1, 5, 487955) Water was supplied from two wells as well as from a spring.
('34', 193, 1, 6, 488015) The nearest railway station, Lawley, was about a mile from the farm and Johannesburg was twenty one miles distant.
('34', 193, 1, 7, 488130) We decided to build houses upon this farm and to invite the families of satyagrahis to settle there.
('34', 193, 2, 8, 488231) CHAPTER XXXIV TOLSTOY FARM—II
('34', 193, 3, 9, 488261) Upon the Farm oranges, apricots and plums grew in such abundance that during the season the satyagrahis could have their fill of the fruits and yet have a surplus.
('34', 193, 3, 10, 488425) The spring was about 500 yards away from our quarters, and the water had to be fetched on carrying poles.
('34', 193, 3, 11, 488531) Here we insisted that we should not have any servants either for the household work or, as far as might be, even for the farming and building operations.
('34', 193, 3, 12, 488685) Everything therefore from cooking to scavenging was done with our own hands.
('34', 193, 3, 13, 488762) As regards accommodation for families, we resolved from the first that the men and women should be housed separately.
('34', 193, 3, 14, 488880) The houses therefore were to be built in two separate blocks, each at some distance from the other.
('34', 193, 3, 15, 488980) For the time it was considered sufficient to provide accommodation for ten women and sixty men.

('34', 193, 3, 17, 489216) The settlers hailed from Gujarat, Tamilnad, Andhradesh and North India, and there were Hindus, Mussalmans, Parsis and Christians among them.
('34', 193, 3, 18, 489357) About forty of them were young men, two or three old men, five women and twenty to thirty children of whom four or five were girls.

('34', 196, 1, 24, 496805) No water was permitted to be thrown on the roads.

('34', 196, 1, 28, 497174) There were no flies, and no one would imagine that night soil had been buried there.

('34', 199, 2, 5, 503131) CHAPTER XXXV
('34', 199, 3, 6, 503144) TOLSTOY FARM—III In this chapter I propose to string together a number of Tolstoy Farm reminiscences which are rather disjointed and for which therefore I must crave the reader’s indulgence.
('34', 199, 3, 7, 503335) A teacher hardly ever had to teach the kind of heterogeneous class that fell to my lot, containing as it did pupils of all ages and both the sexes, from boys and girls of about seven years of age to young men of twenty and young girls 12 or 13 years old.
('34', 199, 3, 8, 503590) Some of the boys were wild and mischievous.
('34', 199, 3, 9, 503634) What was I to teach this ill assorted group?
('34', 199, 3, 10, 503679) How was I to be all things to all pupils?
('34', 199, 3, 11, 503721) Again in what language should I talk to all of them?
('34', 199, 3, 12, 503774) The Tamil and Telugu children knew their own mother tongue or English and a little Dutch.
('34', 199, 3, 13, 503864) I could speak to them only in English.
('34', 199, 3, 14, 503903) I divided the class into two sections, the Gujarati section to be talked to in Gujarati and the rest in English.
('34', 199, 3, 15, 504016) As the principal part of the teaching, I arranged to tell or read to them some interesting stories.
('34', 199, 3, 16, 504116) I also proposed to bring them into close mutual contact and to lead them to cultivate a spirit of friendship and service.
('34', 199, 3, 17, 504238) Then there was to be imparted some general knowledge of history and geography and in some cases of arithmetic.
('34', 199, 3, 18, 504349) Writing was also taught, and so were some bhajans which formed part of our prayers, and to which therefore I tried to attract the Tamil children as well.

('34', 212, 3, 4, 536221) GOKHALE’S TOUR Thus the satyagrahis were pursuing the even tenor of their life on Tolstoy Farm, and preparing for whatever the future had in store for them.
('34', 212, 3, 5, 536378) They did not know, nor did they care, when the struggle would end.
('34', 212, 3, 6, 536445) They were only under one pledge, namely, to refuse submission to the Black Act and to suffer whatever hardships were involved in such disobedience.
('34', 212, 3, 7, 536593) For a fighter the fight itself is victory for he takes delight in it alone.
('34', 212, 3, 8, 536669) And as it rests with him to prosecute the fight, he believes that victory or defeat, pleasure or pain, depends upon himself.
('34', 212, 3, 9, 536794) There is no such word in his dictionary as pain or defeat.
('34', 212, 3, 10, 536853) In the words of the Gita pleasure and pain, victory and defeat are the same to him.
('34', 212, 3, 11, 536937) Stray satyagrahis now and then went to jail.
('34', 212, 3, 12, 536982) But when there was no occasion for going to jail, anyone who observed the external activities of the Farm could hardly believe that satyagrahis wereliving there or that they were preparing for a struggle.
('34', 212, 3, 13, 537187) When a sceptic happened to visit the Farm, if a friend he would pity us, and if a critic he would censure us.
('34', 212, 3, 14, 537297) ‘These fellows,’ he would remark, ‘have grown lazy and are therefore eating the bread of idleness in this secluded spot.
('34', 212, 3, 15, 537418) They are sick of going to jail and are therefore enjoying themselves in this fruit garden away from thedin and roar of cities.’ How could it be explained to this critic that a satyagrahi cannot go to jail by violating the moral law, that his very peacefulness and self restraint constitute his preparation for ‘war’, and that the satyagrahi, bestowing no thought on human help, relies upon God as his sole refuge?
('34', 212, 3, 16, 537832) Finally there happened, or God brought to pass, events which no one had expected.
('34', 212, 3, 17, 537914) Help also arrived which was equally unforeseen.
('34', 212, 3, 18, 537962) The ordeal came all unexpected and in the end there was achieved a tangible victory which he who ran could read.

('34', 222, 3, 12, 562192) BREACH OF PLEDGE
('34', 222, 4, 13, 562209) In prosecuting the satyagraha struggle the Indians were very careful not to take a single step not warranted by their principles, and they always remembered that they should not take any illegitimate advantage over the Government.
('34', 222, 4, 14, 562440) For instance, as the Black Act was restricted in its application to Indians in the Transvaal, only the Transvaal Indians were admitted as recruits in the struggle.

('34', 223, 1, 2, 563402) In a pure fight the fighters would never go beyond the objective fixed when the fight began even if they received an accession to their strength in course of the fighting, and on the other hand they could not give up their objective if they found their strength dwindling away.
('34', 223, 1, 3, 563680) This twofold principle was fully observed in South Africa.
('34', 223, 1, 4, 563739) The strength of the community, upon which we counted in determining our goal at the commencement of the struggle, did not answer our expectations as we have already seen, and yet the handful of satyagrahis who remained stuck to their posts.

('34', 226, 2, 6, 571751) CHAPTER XXXIX
('34', 226, 3, 7, 571765) WHEN A MARRIAGE IS NOT A MARRIAGE
('34', 226, 4, 8, 571799) As if, unseen by anyone, God was preparing the ingredients for the Indians’ victory and demonstrating still more clearly the injustice of the Europeans in South Africa, an event happened which none had expected.
('34', 226, 4, 9, 572011) Many married men came to South Africa from India, while some Indians contracted marriages in South Africa itself.
('34', 226, 4, 10, 572125) There is no law for the registration of ordinary marriages in India, and the religious ceremony suffices to confer validity upon them.
('34', 226, 4, 11, 572260) The same custom ought to apply to Indians in South Africa as well and although Indians had settled in South Africa for the last forty years, the validity of marriages solemnized according to the rites of the various religions of India had never been called in question.
('34', 226, 4, 12, 572530) But at this time there was a case in which Mr. Justice Searle of the Cape Supreme Court gave judgment on March 14, 1913, to the effect that all marriages were outside the pale of legal marriages in South Africa with the exception of such as were celebrated according to Christian rites and registered by the Registrar of Marriages.
('34', 226, 4, 13, 572862) 1 This terrible judgment thus nullified in South Africa at a stroke of the pen all marriages celebrated according to the Hindu, Mussalman and Zoroastrian rites.
('34', 226, 4, 14, 573023) The many married Indian women in South Africa in terms of this judgment ceased to rank as the wives of their husbands and were degraded to the rank of concubines, while their progeny were deprived of their right to inherit the parents’ property.
('34', 226, 4, 15, 573269) This was an insufferable situation for women no less than men, and the Indians in South Africa were deeply agitated.
('34', 226, 5, 16, 573386) 1 Vide “Attack on Indian Religions”, March 22, 1913. For the text of the Searle judgment, vide Appendix “Text of the Searle Judgement”, June 21, 1913.
('34', 227, 0, 1, 573537) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 227, 1, 2, 573579) According to my usual practice I wrote to the Government, asking them whether they agreed to the Searle judgment and whether, if the judge was right in interpreting it, they would amend the law so as to recognize the validity of Indian marriages consecrated according to the religious customs of the parties and recognized as legal in India.
('34', 227, 1, 3, 573921) The Government were not then in a mood to listen and could not see their way to complying with my request.
('34', 227, 1, 4, 574028) The Satyagraha Association held a meeting to consider whether they should appeal against the Searle judgment, and came to the conclusion that no appeal was possible on a question of this nature.
('34', 227, 1, 5, 574223) If there was to be an appeal, it must be preferred by Government, or if they so desired, by the Indians provided that the Government openly sided with them through their Attorney General.
('34', 227, 1, 6, 574411) To appeal when these conditions were not satisfied would be in a way tantamount to tolerating the invalidation of Indian marriages.
('34', 227, 1, 7, 574543) Satyagraha would have to be resorted to even if such an appeal was made and if it was rejected.

('34', 267, 1, 3, 671500) When the Indian labourers on the north coast went on strike, the planters at Mount Edgecombe would have been put to great losses if all the cane that had been cut was not brought to the mill and crushed.
('34', 267, 1, 4, 671704) Twelve hundred 1 Indians therefore returned to work solely with a view to finishing this part of the work, and joined their compatriots only when it was finished.
('34', 267, 1, 5, 671867) Again when the Indian employees of the Durban Municipality struck work, those whowere engaged in the sanitary services of the borough or as attendants upon the patients in hospitals were sent back, and they willingly returned to their duties.
('34', 267, 1, 6, 672110) If the sanitary services were dislocated,and if there was no one to attend upon the patients in hospitals, there might be an outbreak of disease in the city and the sick would be deprived of medical aid, and no satyagrahi would wish for such consequences to ensure.
('34', 267, 1, 7, 672376) Employees of this description were therefore exempted from the strike.
('34', 267, 1, 8, 672447) In every step that he takes, the satyagrahi is bound to consider the position of his adversary.
('34', 267, 1, 9, 672543) I could see that the numerous cases of such chivalry left their invisible yet potent impress everywhere, enhanced the prestige of the Indians, and prepared a suitable atmosphere for a settlement.

('34', 269, 1, 3, 676549) Some held that the charges levelled by the Indians against the soldiers must be proved, and therefore suggested that if the evidence could not be placed before the commission, we must challenge libel proceedings by publishing the authentic evidence in our possession.
('34', 269, 1, 4, 676817) I disagreed with these friends.

('34', 269, 1, 7, 677119) As a barrister, I was well aware of the difficulties of proving the truth of statements giving rise to libel proceedings.
('34', 269, 1, 8, 677241) But my weightiest argument was that the satyagrahi is out to suffer.
('34', 269, 1, 9, 677310) Even before satyagraha was started, the satyagrahis knew that they would have tosuffer even unto death, and they were ready to: undergo such suffering.
('34', 269, 1, 10, 677462) Such being the case, there was no sense in proving now that they did suffer.
('34', 269, 1, 11, 677539) A spirit of revenge being alien to satyagraha, it was best for a satyagrahi to hold his peace when he encountered extraordinary difficulties in proving the fact of his suffering.
('34', 269, 1, 12, 677718) A satyagrahi fights only for essentials.
('34', 269, 1, 13, 677759) The essential thing was that the obnoxious laws should be repealed or suitably amended, and when this was fairly within his grasp, he need not bother himself with other things.
('34', 269, 1, 14, 677936) Again a satyagrahi’s silence would at the time of settlement stand him in good stead in his resistance to unjust laws.
('34', 269, 1, 15, 678055) With such arguments I was able to win over most of these friends who differed from me, and we decided to drop the idea of proving our allegations of ill treatment.

('34', 272, 1, 6, 684053) Pain to a satyagrahi is the same as pleasure.

('34', 272, 1, 10, 684584) The Indians now came to a better understanding of the spirit of satyagraha.
('34', 272, 1, 11, 684660) Mr. Andrews was the mediator and the witness in the present agreement, and then there was Sir Benjamin Robertson as representing the Government of India.
('34', 272, 1, 12, 684814) There was therefore the least possible likelihood of the agreement being subsequently repudiated.
('34', 272, 1, 13, 684912) If I had obstinately refused to accept theagreement, it would have become a count of indictment against the Indians, and the victory which was achieved in the next six months would have been beset with various obstacles.
('34', 272, 1, 14, 685133) The author of the Sanskrit saying, ‘Forgiveness is an ornament to the brave’, drew upon his rich experience of satyagrahis never giving any one the least opportunity of finding fault with them.
('34', 272, 1, 15, 685327) Distrust is a sign of weakness and satyagraha implies the banishment of all weakness and therefore of distrust, which is clearly out of place when the adversary is not to be destroyed but to be won over.

('34', 273, 4, 11, 687103) THE END OF THE STRUGGLE Within a short time of the issue of the report, the Government published in the official Gazette of the Union the Indians’Relief Bill 3
('34', 273, 5, 12, 687263) which was to effect a settlement of their long standing dispute with the Indians; and I went at once to Cape Town where the Union Parliament sits.
('34', 273, 5, 13, 687410) The Bill contained 9 sections and would take up only two columns of a paper like Young India.
('34', 273, 5, 14, 687504) One part of it dealt with the question of Indian marriages and validated in South Africa the marriages which were held legal in India, except that if a man had more wives than one, only one of them would at any time be recognized as his legal wife in South Africa.
('34', 273, 5, 15, 687769) The second part abolished the annual licence of £3 to be taken out by every indentured Indian labourer who failed to return to India and settled in the country as a free man on the completion of his indenture.
('34', 273, 5, 16, 687979) The third part provided that the domicile certificates issued by the Government to Indians in Natal and bearing the thumb impression of the holder of the permit should be recognized as conclusive evidence

('34', 275, 2, 7, 692299) CONCLUSION
('34', 275, 3, 8, 692310) Thus the great satyagraha struggle closed after eight years, and it appeared that the Indians in South Africa were now at peace.
('34', 275, 3, 9, 692439) On July 18, 1914, I sailed for England, to meet Gokhale, on my way back to India, with mixed feelings of pleasure and regret,—pleasure because I was returning home after many years and eagerly looked forward to serving the country under Gokhale’s guidance, regret because it was a great wrench for me to leave South Africa, whereI had passed twenty one years of my life sharing to thefull in the sweets and bitters of human experience, and where I had realized my vocation in life.
('34', 275, 4, 10, 692921) When one considers the painful contrast between the happy ending of the satyagraha struggle and the present condition of the Indians in South Africa, one feels for a moment as if all this suffering had gone for nothing, or is inclined to question the efficacy of satyagraha as a solvent of the problems of mankind.
('34', 275, 4, 11, 693236) Let us here consider this point for a little while.
('34', 275, 4, 12, 693288) There is a law of nature that a
('34', 275, 5, 13, 693320) 1 From July 1 to July 18, when Gandhiji embarked at Cape Town, were for him days of leave taking.
('34', 276, 0, 1, 693418) VOL. 34 : 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 277
('34', 276, 1, 2, 693464) thing can be retained by the same means by which it has been acquired.
('34', 276, 1, 3, 693535) A thing acquired by violence can be retained by violence alone, while one acquired by truth can be retained only by truth.
('34', 276, 1, 4, 693658) The Indians in South Africa, therefore, can ensure their safety today if they can wield the weapon of satyagraha.
('34', 276, 1, 5, 693772) There are no such miraculous properties in satyagraha, that a thing acquired by truth could be retained even when truth was given up.
('34', 276, 1, 6, 693906) It would not be desirable even if it was possible.
('34', 276, 1, 7, 693957) If therefore the position of Indians in South Africa has now suffered deterioration, that argues the absence of satyagrahis among them.
('34', 276, 1, 8, 694093) There is no question here of finding fault with the present generation of South African Indians, but of merely stating the facts of the case.
('34', 276, 1, 9, 694235) Individuals or bodies of individuals cannot borrow from others qualities which they themselves do not possess.
('34', 276, 1, 10, 694346) The satyagrahi veterans passed away one after another.
('34', 276, 1, 11, 694401) Sorabji, Kachhalia, Thambi Naidoo, Parsi Rustomji and others are no more, and there are very few now who passed through the fire of satyagraha.
('34', 276, 1, 12, 694545) The few that remain are still in the fighting line, and I have not a shadow of a doubt that they will be the saviours of the community on the day of its trial if the light of satyagraha is burning bright within them.
('34', 276, 1, 13, 694762) Finally, the reader of these pages has seen that had it not been for this great struggle 1 and for the untold sufferings which many Indians invited upon their devoted heads, the Indians today would have been hounded out of South Africa.
('34', 276, 1, 14, 694999) Nay, the victory achieved by Indians in South Africa more or less served as a shield for Indian emigrants in other parts of the British Empire, who, if they are suppressed, will be suppressed thanks to the absence of satyagrahaamong themselves, and to India’s inability to protect them, and not because of any flaw in the weapon of satyagraha.
('34', 276, 1, 15, 695343) I will consider myself amply repaid if I have in these pages demonstrated with some success that Satyagraha is a priceless and matchless weapon, and that those who wield it are Strangers to disappointment or defeat.

('34', 277, 3, 4, 696071) The threatened Asiatic Bill is a breach of the Smuts Gandhi agreement regarding the whole of South Africa, and it is a breach of faith also as regards Natal as brought out by Mr. Andrews in one of his letters to the Press in South Africa and reproduced in Indian Opinion just to hand.
('34', 277, 3, 5, 696356) The following is the apposite extract:
('34', 277, 4, 6, 696395) The Natal Government brought out under contract, from the year 1860 on wards, the vast majority of Indians who landed in South Africa.
('34', 277, 4, 7, 696530) It was agreed between the two Governments, before they left India, that if they fulfilled their five years’ labour contract on the sugar plantations they should be given certain rights in Natal, including those of domicile together with open purchase of land and immovable property.
('34', 277, 4, 8, 696813) The Natal Government, in its eagerness to get this indentured Indian labour, also agreed that Indian traders should be allowed to accompany the labourers as free Indians.
('34', 277, 5, 9, 696984) These Indian labourers purchased those rights at a great cost.
('34', 277, 5, 10, 697047) For the five years’ indenture was accompanied by such grave moral evils, that it has now been entirely abandoned as a vicious labour system.
('34', 277, 5, 11, 697188) The Natal Government, up to quite recent times, has endeavoured to observe faithfully its side of the contract.
