('34', 277, 7, 15, 697461) The same letter thus disposes of the economic argument often brought against the Indian settler:
('34', 277, 8, 16, 697558) The Indian question itself is by no means so serious from an economic standpoint as people in South Africa have been led to think.
('34', 277, 8, 17, 697689) Indeed, in reality, the solution has been already obtained, because the Indian competition is a diminishing and not an increasing factor.
('34', 277, 8, 18, 697827) Yet even in a city like Durban where Indians are most numerous of all, the net increase in the value of properties held by Indians between 1921 and 1925 was only in round figures a quarter of a million while that of Europeans was four millions.

('34', 281, 1, 11, 706326) It therefore seeks to convert the tyrant.
('34', 281, 1, 12, 706368) It may fail because India may not be ready for mass non violence.
('34', 281, 1, 13, 706434) But it would be wrong to judge the movement by false standards.
('34', 281, 1, 14, 706498) My own opinion is that the movement has in no way failed.
('34', 281, 1, 15, 706556) Non violence has found an abiding place in India’s struggle for freedom.
('34', 281, 1, 16, 706629) That the programme could not be finished in a year’s time merely shows that the people could not cope with a mighty upheaval during such a short time.
('34', 281, 1, 17, 706780) But it is a leaven which is silently but surely working its way among the masses.
('34', 281, 2, 18, 706862) Young India, 11 2 1926
('34', 281, 3, 19, 706885) 5. TERMS OF PROHIBITION
('34', 281, 4, 20, 706909) The Government of Bombay has plainly told the Anjuman of Broach that if they want prohibition they must find fresh sources of revenue to replace the revenue derived from drink.
('34', 281, 4, 21, 707086) In other words it is no concern of the Government to arrest the evil of drink.
('34', 281, 4, 22, 707165) It is the duty of the reformer to supply the revenue lost by return to sobriety.
('34', 281, 4, 23, 707246) Prohibitionists therefore, if they want early prohibition, will have to make up their minds as to their reply to H. E. the Governor of Bombay which represents in this case the policy of the Government of India.
('34', 281, 4, 24, 707457) I hold it to be utterly unjust to further tax the already over taxed taxpayer.
('34', 281, 4, 25, 707536) Prohibition can only come by cutting down expenditure.
('34', 281, 4, 26, 707591) The military budget is the item that easily admits of retrenchment.
('34', 281, 4, 27, 707659) But whether this opinion is sound or not, prohibitionists have to formulate their policy as to the method of meeting the difficulty raised by the Governor of Bombay.
('34', 281, 5, 28, 707825) Young India, 11 2 1926
('34', 282, 0, 1, 707848) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 283
('34', 282, 1, 2, 707893) 6. ABUSE OF POWER
('34', 282, 2, 3, 707911) Protests in India notwithstanding, the Union Parliament has passed the anti colour legislation.
('34', 282, 2, 4, 708007) This does not so materially affect Indian settlers as the natives of the soil.
('34', 282, 2, 5, 708086) They and Asiatics are virtually debarred by this legislation from doing any work on the mines which Europeans can or will do.
('34', 282, 2, 6, 708212) It is an unnecessary affront put upon Indians.
('34', 282, 2, 7, 708259) For there are very few working on the mines.
('34', 282, 2, 8, 708304) So far as the natives are concerned the legislation not only reduces their legal status but it also affects the material interest of thousands working on the mines.
('34', 282, 2, 9, 708469) No wonder General Smuts uttered a grave note of waring against the legislation and likened it to a fire brand thrown in a haystack.
('34', 282, 2, 10, 708601) The Bill is a challenge to the Natives.
('34', 282, 2, 11, 708641) Illiterate though they may be, they are as proud and sensitive as any people on earth.
('34', 282, 2, 12, 708728) In their helplessness they may be unable to answer the challenge but there is no doubt that the Europeans of South Africa if they persist in their arrogant policy will have sown the seeds of their own destruction.
('34', 282, 2, 13, 708942) It is stated that the Senate will reject the measure when it comes before it.
('34', 282, 2, 14, 709020) It ought to But the same cable tells us that the existing Government have a majority in the combined Houses which they propose to use in order to carry out their purpose.
('34', 282, 2, 15, 709191) If this temper continues, the anti Asiatic measure which is agitating India at the present moment is not likely to be postponed as Mr. Andrews hopes it will.
('34', 282, 2, 16, 709349) These measures really hang together and represent the settled policy of the present Union Government on the question of colour.
('34', 282, 2, 17, 709477) Only the strongest attitude on the part of the government of India can bring about a reconsideration of that policy.

('34', 290, 1, 2, 720266) admitted that he still had bad dreams.
('34', 290, 1, 3, 720305) The moment I read it I felt that such admissions could have no wholesome effect, and I came to know later that my fear was justified.
('34', 290, 2, 4, 720439) During our sojourn in England my friend and I kept our character unscathed in spite of temptations.
('34', 290, 2, 5, 720539) We remained absolutely free from wine, woman and meat.
('34', 290, 2, 6, 720594) But on reading Gandhiji’s article one of the friends exclaimed to me in despair: ‘If such is the case with Gandhiji even after his Herculean efforts, where are we?
('34', 290, 2, 7, 720758) It is useless to attempt to observe brahmacharya.
('34', 290, 2, 8, 720808) Gandhiji’s confession has entirely changed my point of view.
('34', 290, 2, 9, 720869) Take me to be lost from today.’ Not without some hesitation I tried to reason with him: ‘If the way is so difficult for men like Gandhiji, it is much more so for us, and we should therefore redouble our effort.’—the way Gandhiji or you would argue.
('34', 290, 2, 10, 721118) But it was all in vain.
('34', 290, 2, 11, 721142) A character that had been spotless so long was thus bespattered with mire.

('34', 291, 1, 3, 723005) A knowledge of one as he is can always do good to the people, never any harm.

('34', 291, 1, 8, 723386) For it would sully brahmacharya and dim the lustre of truth.
('34', 291, 1, 9, 723447) How dare I undervalue brahmacharya by false pretences?
('34', 291, 1, 10, 723502) I can see today that the means I suggest for the observance of brahmacharya are not adequate, are not found to be invariably efficacious, because I am not a perfect brahmachari.
('34', 291, 1, 11, 723680) It would be an awful thing for the world to be allowed to believe that I was a perfect brahmachari, whilst I could not show the royal road to brahmacharya.
('34', 291, 1, 12, 723836) Why should it not be sufficient for the world to know that I am a genuine seeker, that I am wide awake, and that my striving is ceaseless and unbending?
('34', 291, 1, 13, 723989) Why should not this knowledge be sufficient encouragement to others?
('34', 291, 1, 14, 724058) It is wrong to deduce conclusions from false premises.
('34', 291, 1, 15, 724113) It is wisest to draw them from things achieved.
('34', 291, 1, 16, 724161) Why argue that because a man like me could not escape unclean thoughts, there is no hope for the rest?
('34', 291, 1, 17, 724264) Why not rather argue that if a Gandhi who was once given to lust can today live as friend and brother to his wife and can look upon the fairest damsel as his sister or daughter, there is hope for the lowliest and the lost?
('34', 291, 1, 18, 724487) If God was merciful to one who was so full of lust, certainly all the rest would have his mercy too!
('34', 291, 1, 19, 724588) The friends of the correspondent who were put back because of a knowledge of my imperfections had never gone forward at all.
('34', 291, 1, 20, 724713) It was a false virtue that fell at the first blast.
('34', 291, 1, 21, 724765) The truth and observance of brahmacharya and similar eternal principles do not depend on person imperfect as myself.
('34', 291, 1, 22, 724882) They rest on the sure foundations of the penance of the many who strove for them and lived them in their fullness.
('34', 291, 1, 23, 724997) When I have the fitness to stand alongside those perfect beings, there will be much more determination and force in my language than today.
('34', 291, 1, 24, 725137) He whose thoughts do not wander and think evil, whose sleep knows no dreams and who can be wide awake even whilst asleep, is truly healthy.
('34', 291, 1, 25, 725277) He does not need to take quinine.
('34', 291, 1, 26, 725311) His incorruptible blood will have the inherent virtue of resisting all infections.
('34', 291, 1, 27, 725394) It is for
('34', 292, 0, 1, 725404) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 293
('34', 292, 1, 2, 725449) such a perfectly healthy state of body, mind, and spirit that I am striving.
('34', 292, 1, 3, 725526) This knows no defeat or failure.
('34', 292, 1, 4, 725559) I invite the correspondent, his friends of little faith, and others to join me in that striving, and I wish that they may go forward even like the correspondent quicker than I. Let my example inspire those who are behind me with more confidence.
('34', 292, 1, 5, 725805) All that I have achieved has been in spite of my weakness, in spite of my liability to passion,—and because of my ceaseless striving and infinite faith in God’s grace.
('34', 292, 1, 6, 725973) No one need therefore despair.
('34', 292, 1, 7, 726004) My Mahatmaship is worthless.
('34', 292, 1, 8, 726033) It is due to my outward activities, due to my politics which is the least part of me and is therefore evanescent.
('34', 292, 1, 9, 726147) What is of abiding worth is my insistence on truth, non violence and bramacharya which is the real part of me.
('34', 292, 1, 10, 726258) That permanent part of me however small, is not to be despised.
('34', 292, 1, 11, 726322) It is my all.
('34', 292, 1, 12, 726336) I prize even the failures and disillusionments which are but steps towards success.
('34', 292, 1, 13, 726420) Brahmacharya means not merely mechanical celibacy, but it means complete control over all the organs and senses enabling one to attain perfect freedom from all passion and hence from sin in thought, word and deed.

('34', 297, 1, 2, 734729) 28. LETTER TO C. V. RANGAM CHETTY
('34', 297, 2, 3, 734763) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 17, 1926
('34', 297, 3, 4, 734800) DEAR FRIEND,
('34', 297, 4, 5, 734813) I have your letter 1. Not every man who says I am a congressman or carries about him a Congress label is a Congressman, but he that carries out the behests of the Congress to the letter and in the spirit; and therefore he, in my opinion, is a Congressman who is an out and out believer in khaddar; who wears khaddar himself not as a makeshift or for show, but with sincerity; who believes in the removal of untouchability and freely associates with the so called untouchables; who believes in inter communal unity and translates his belief into practice whenever the occasion demands it; and who believes in the Congress creed of non violence and truth.
('34', 297, 4, 6, 735467) Such a person should command the confidence and the vote, if they have no conscientious objections to voting, of all true Congressmen.
('34', 297, 5, 7, 735602) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI The Hindu, 17 3 1926

('34', 300, 7, 13, 739668) 35. THE TOPIC OF THE HOUR
('34', 300, 8, 14, 739694) By the time this is before the public the majority of the South African deputation will be on the waters on their way back to SouthAfrica.
('34', 300, 8, 15, 739833) Before sailing, Messrs Amod Bhayat, James Godfrey, Pather and Mirza paid me a visit and discussed the situation as it is developing from day to day.
('34', 300, 8, 16, 739982) They expressed themselves satisfied with the splendid welcome extended to them wherever they went and the support received from all parties in India not excluding European Associations.
('34', 300, 8, 17, 740168) But they were not, I am glad to say, deceived into any false sense of security by the support.
('34', 300, 8, 18, 740263) They realized that India was willing but not equally able to help.
('34', 300, 9, 19, 740330) 1 The postal cancellation mark at Lonavala is dated February 18, 1926. Wednesday, however, was on 17th February.
('34', 301, 0, 1, 740443) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 301, 1, 2, 740485) The Colour Bar Bill is making steady progress.
('34', 301, 1, 3, 740532) On principle, it is just as bad as the Asiatic measure and therefore just as open to objection as the latter.
('34', 301, 1, 4, 740642) Its progress evidences the Union Government’s intention and determination abut the Asiatic Bill.
('34', 301, 1, 5, 740739) It is becoming daily clearer that the Union Government intend if possible to stiffen the measure rather than relax it.
('34', 301, 1, 6, 740858) The proposed amendment of the Section 10 gives no relief worth the name and the inclusion of the Cape has roused against the Bill even a section of the South African Press so much that one paper goes so far as to insinuate that it is probably out of spite against Dr. Abdur Rahman’s doings in India that the S. A. Government seek to include the Cape in the scope of the Bill.
('34', 301, 1, 7, 741234) Let us hope that whatever else that Government may be guilty of, it is not guilty of the little ness ascribed to it.
('34', 301, 1, 8, 741351) Be that as it may, there is no doubt about the mind of that Government.
('34', 301, 1, 9, 741423) It is this root and branch policy that the Indian settlers have to face and combat.
('34', 301, 1, 10, 741507) They can do so successfully, if they have a strong backing from the Imperial and the Indian Governments.
('34', 301, 1, 11, 741612) This they will not have.
('34', 301, 1, 12, 741637) The Indian Government is a shadow of the Imperial.
('34', 301, 1, 13, 741688) The latter is neither feared not respected by the present Union Government.
('34', 301, 1, 14, 741764) On the contrary it fears the Union Government lest South Africa may secede from the Imperial partnership.
('34', 301, 1, 15, 741870) It is the case of the tail wagging the dog.
('34', 301, 1, 16, 741914) The Imperial Government would never assert itself against South Africa unless there was fear of losing India.
('34', 301, 1, 17, 742024) The apparent collapse of non co operation has given the Imperial Government a new hope about India’s helpless ness.
('34', 301, 1, 18, 742140) At the crucial moment therefore the weight of authority will be thrown on the side of South Africa unless the unexpected hap pens this side of the Indian Ocean.
('34', 301, 1, 19, 742301) The ultimate passing of the Bill, even though it may be postponed for the present session, is thus assured.
('34', 301, 1, 20, 742409) What are then our countrymen in South Africa to do?
('34', 301, 1, 21, 742461) There is nothing in the world like self help.
('34', 301, 1, 22, 742507) The world helps those who help themselves.
('34', 301, 1, 23, 742550) Self help in this case, as perhaps in every other, means self suffering, self suffering means satyagraha.
('34', 301, 1, 24, 742656) When their honour is at stake, when their rights are being taken away, when their livelihood is threatened, they have the right and it becomes their duty to offer satyagraha.
('34', 301, 1, 25, 742831) They offered it during 1907 and 1914 and won the support even of the Government of India, indeed the recognition of the Europeans and the Government of South Africa.
('34', 301, 1, 26, 742997) They can do likewise again if they have the will and the courage to suffer for the common good.
('34', 301, 1, 27, 743093) That time is not yet.
('34', 301, 1, 28, 743115) They must, as they are doing, exhaust every diplomatic remedy.
('34', 301, 1, 29, 743178) They must await the result of the negotiations the
('34', 302, 0, 1, 743229) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 303
('34', 302, 1, 2, 743274) Government of India are carrying on with the Union Government.
('34', 302, 1, 3, 743337) And when they have explored and tried every other available channel and failed to find a way out, the case for satyagraha is complete.
('34', 302, 1, 4, 743472) Then it would be cowardice to flinch.
('34', 302, 1, 5, 743510) And victory is a certainty.
('34', 302, 1, 6, 743538) No power on earth can make a person do a thing against his will.
('34', 302, 1, 7, 743603) Satyagraha is a direct result of the recognition of this great Law and is independent of numbers participating in it.
('34', 302, 1, 8, 743721) Terms of satyagraha are imperative, admitting of no exception.
('34', 302, 1, 9, 743784) There should be no violence in any shape or form.
('34', 302, 1, 10, 743834) There must be an irreducible minimum—a minimum that would commend itself to any reasonable and impartial judge.
('34', 302, 1, 11, 743946) We may be justly entitled to many things but satyagraha is offered for things without which self respect, or which is the same thing, honourable existence, is impossible.
('34', 302, 1, 12, 744117) They must count the cost.
('34', 302, 1, 13, 744143) Satyagraha cannot be offered in bravado or as a mere trial.
('34', 302, 1, 14, 744203) It is a measure of the depth of one’s feeling.
('34', 302, 1, 15, 744250) It is therefore offered because it becomes irresistible.
('34', 302, 1, 16, 744307) No price is too dear to pay for it, i.e., truth.
('34', 302, 1, 17, 744356) Success comes when it is least expected.
('34', 302, 1, 18, 744397) It is undertaken not from a belief in human aid but it is based upon an unquenchable faith in God and His justice.
('34', 302, 1, 19, 744512) And God is both gentle and hard.
('34', 302, 1, 20, 744545) He tries us through and through to the last suffering point but He is so gentle as never to test us to the breaking point.
('34', 302, 2, 21, 744668) Young India, 18 2 1926
('34', 302, 3, 22, 744691) 36. JAILS OR “HOSPITALS”?
('34', 302, 4, 23, 744717) Lord Lytton in recently speaking about jails to the Rotarians of Calcutta, said that just as we send our sick in body to hospitals and not to jails, so must we ‘provide moral doctors and moral hospitals’ for the sick in mind, i.e., criminals.
('34', 302, 4, 24, 744960) His Excellency thus introduced his subject:
('34', 302, 5, 25, 745004) The ideal I wish to set before me, stated in the briefest and simplest form, is just this—the substitution of reformation for retribution as the basis of our Penal Code.
('34', 302, 5, 26, 745174) Punishment can instil fear and enforce habits—it cannot inspire goodness.
('34', 302, 5, 27, 745248) As a means of moral regeneration, therefore, it is worse than useless and should be abandoned.
('34', 302, 5, 28, 745343) A morality which is only enforced by pains and penalties is a false morality, and those who would secure the acceptance of moral standards should employ other methods.
('34', 303, 0, 1, 745511) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 303, 1, 2, 745553) Of the uses and limitations of punishments Lord Lytton said:
('34', 303, 2, 3, 745614) Punishment, if resorted to at all, must always be aimed at teaching habits necessary for the well being of the individual or discipline necessary to the well being of a community.
('34', 303, 2, 4, 745794) I do not say that punishment will always succeed; the form of punishment selected in any particular case may be well or badly suited for the attainment of its object.
('34', 303, 2, 5, 745961) Again, I do not say that punishment is the only way of achieving this object.
('34', 303, 2, 6, 746039) What I say is that those are the only objects which can be obtained by punishment.
('34', 303, 2, 7, 746122) The one thing which can never be acquired by coercion is goodness or moral conduct.
('34', 303, 2, 8, 746206) All punishment therefore which aims at correcting wickedness or teaching goodness is definitely mischievous.
('34', 303, 2, 9, 746315) Goodness is a condition of mind as health is a condition of the body.
('34', 303, 2, 10, 746385) Moral defects of character are no more to be cured by punishment than defects of the body.
('34', 303, 2, 11, 746476) It may be necessary in the interest of health of a community forcibly to segregate a person with an infectious disease; it may be necessary on the same ground to segregate persons whose moral defects are a danger to society; but it would be just as senseless and mischievous to try to cure a man of scarlet fever by shutting him up with a number of persons suffering from measles, tuberculosis or leprosy, as it is to try to cure a man of stealing or cheating by shutting him up with other thieves and cheats.
('34', 303, 2, 12, 746986) After this pronouncement one would expect a description of prison reform being attempted or pending in Bengal.
('34', 303, 2, 13, 747097) Instead, however, H. E. the Governor of Bengal quoted two instances of successful humanitarian effort in England and said:
('34', 303, 3, 14, 747220) You may ask why I have chosen to speak to you about this subject.
('34', 303, 3, 15, 747286) The reason is that this is work which no Government can do.
('34', 303, 3, 16, 747346) Governments only hamper and spoil work of this kind by interference, it must be done by those who have the calling.
('34', 303, 3, 17, 747462) Having thus absolved his and all governments from responsibility for the much needed reform, he threw it on the broad and “idealistic” shoulders of the Rotarians present.
('34', 303, 3, 18, 747633) As an old and experienced prisoner, however, I believe that governments have to begin the reform Lord Lytton will have his hearers to undertake.
('34', 303, 3, 19, 747778) Humanitarians can but supplement government efforts.
('34', 303, 3, 20, 747831) As it is, the humanitarian, if he attempted anything, will first have to undo the mischief done in prisons where the environment hardens the criminal tendency, and in the case of innocent prisoners they learn how to commit crimes without being detected.
('34', 303, 3, 21, 748085) I hold that humanitarian effort cannot cope with the evil wrought in the jails.
('34', 304, 0, 1, 748165) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 305
('34', 304, 1, 2, 748210) Lord Lytton must have recognized this patent fact when in his introduction he talked of substituting “reformation for retribution as the basis of our Penal Code”.
('34', 304, 1, 3, 748373) But evidently in winding up his speech he forgot that he had intended his Penal Code to be the basis of reform, and as he realized that he had no reform to show to the credit of his government, wound up by saying that it was no business of governments to attempt the reform.
('34', 304, 1, 4, 748648) If, as Lord Lytton correctly put it, punishment must be inflicted purely for protection of society, mere detention should be enough and that too only till the detenus can be fairly presumed to have been cured of their evil habits or securities are found for their good behaviour.
('34', 304, 1, 5, 748928) There can be no difficulty about a scientific classification of prisoners, apportionment of work from a humanitarian standpoint, selection of better class warders, abolition of the system of appointing prisoners as warders, and a host of other changes that one might easily suggest.
('34', 304, 1, 6, 749211) According to Lord Lytton’s own standard, the detention of political prisoners without trial and their reported ill treatment is wholly wrong.
('34', 304, 1, 7, 749353) It is to be wished that His Excellency will apply his own admirable tests to the administration of his own jails, and there is no doubt that he will make startling discoveries in the shape of reforms that can be easily attempted by his government far more easily than anything that humanitarians can ever hope to attempt or achieve.
('34', 304, 2, 8, 749686) Young India, 18 2 1926
('34', 304, 3, 9, 749709) 37. 5,000 MILES AWAY
('34', 304, 4, 10, 749730) The recent debate in the Assembly over the proposal to appoint two additional judges to the Privy Council for the purpose of hearing Indian appeals has revived the controversy about the location of this final court of appeal.
('34', 304, 4, 11, 749956) If it were not for the hypnotism under which we are labouring we would see without effort the futility, the sinfulness, of going five thousand miles away to get (or buy?) justice.
('34', 304, 4, 12, 750136) It is said that at that delightful distance the judges are able to decide cases with greater detachment and impartiality than they would if they had to hear appeals, say in Delhi.
('34', 304, 4, 13, 750316) The moment the argument is examined it breaks down.
('34', 304, 4, 14, 750368) Must the poor Londoners have their Privy Council in Delhi?
('34', 304, 4, 15, 750427) And what should the French and the Americans do?
('34', 304, 4, 16, 750476) Must the
('34', 305, 0, 1, 750485) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 305, 1, 2, 750527) French by arrangement have their final court of appeal in America and the Americans in France?
('34', 305, 1, 3, 750622) What should we do if India was an independent country?
('34', 305, 1, 4, 750677) Or is India an exceptional “case’ requiring special favoured treatment giving the right of appeal in far off London?
('34', 305, 1, 5, 750794) Let one quote in support of the seat of the Privy Council in London the case of the great Colonies.
('34', 305, 1, 6, 750894) They retain the anachronism out of sentiment.
('34', 305, 1, 7, 750940) And the movement is on foot in several Colonies to have their final courts of appeal in their own homes.
('34', 305, 1, 8, 751045) The sentiment in India is the other way.
('34', 305, 1, 9, 751086) A self respecting India would never tolerate the location of her final court of appeal anywhere else but in India.

('34', 305, 3, 11, 751224) 38. PROGRESS OF KHADI
('34', 305, 4, 12, 751246) The Secretary, A.I.S.A. 1, has received a letter from the Chittoor District Khadi Board giving valuable information about khadi made from self spun yarn from September to December 1925. I take the following 2 from that letter: The value of the information given in the foregoing lies in the fact that the self spinners include lawyers, graduates, a Municipal Councillor, an M.L.C. and an M.L.A. who perhaps have their clothes made partly or wholly from self spun yarn, not for the sake of saving money, but for love of the thing.
('34', 305, 4, 13, 751776) Farmers such as Natha Patel whose story Mahadev Desai relates in another column spin and weave their own yarn predominantly for the sake of saving considerable expenses.
('34', 305, 4, 14, 751946) As he himself says, his yearly expense for the family was no less than Rs. 250. Thus khadi has both an economic and a sentimental value, both to be equally cherished.
('34', 305, 4, 15, 752113) Whilst I can congratulate the organizers and the spinners on their energy and devotion, I am sorry I am unable to endorse the scheme that has been sketched by the correspondent in order to enourage self spinning.
('34', 305, 4, 16, 752326) He promises to give as present one towel to every spinner who spins at a recognized club for one hour every day for 30 days, and he promises further to weave the yarn free for those
('34', 305, 5, 17, 752508) 1 The All India Spinners’ Association 2 Not reproduced here
('34', 306, 0, 1, 752568) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 307
('34', 306, 1, 2, 752613) spinners who spin for 90 days at the rate of one hour per day.
('34', 306, 1, 3, 752676) I think that if these promises are meant for the class of spinners mentioned in the letter reproduced by me, it is an undesirable temp tation.
('34', 306, 1, 4, 752819) M.L.Cs, M.L.A.s and lawyers may not have their yarn spun free of charge.
('34', 306, 1, 5, 752892) The whole value of their work at the spinning wheel is lost if they spin because there is a substantial prize to be obtained at the end of their spinning.
('34', 306, 1, 6, 753047) Such men should spin for the love of it.
('34', 306, 1, 7, 753088) The satisfaction of wearing cloth made out of yarn spun by themselves must be its own full reward.
('34', 306, 1, 8, 753187) Prizes are meant for unwilling spinners.
('34', 306, 1, 9, 753228) They may also be given to willing spinners who are needy and for whom every pice saved is so much added to their bread and butter.
('34', 306, 1, 10, 753359) The idea of giving self spinners free slivers is really tentamount to encouraging beggary.
('34', 306, 1, 11, 753450) Why should men who can afford have free slivers, when the yarn spun is to be their own property?
('34', 306, 1, 12, 753547) Surely, it is enough that they get facilities for spinning and all the attention that may be necessary to make them accomplished spinners.
('34', 306, 1, 13, 753686) Free slivers can only be given to paupers in order to enable them to earn a living and in order to encourage them to work, because idleness seems at the present moment to be spreading in the nation.
('34', 306, 1, 14, 753885) What was at one time forced upon us is becoming a vice with us.
('34', 306, 1, 15, 753949) Let it never be forgotten by khadi workers that the whole plan of khadi is based upon the supposition that there are millions of people living in utter starvationor semi starvation, and they are so living for want of work either during the whole of the year or at least a third of the year.
('34', 306, 1, 16, 754240) Therefore every rupee that is spent by Khadi Associations must, so far as it is possible, find its way directly into the pockets of these starving millions and even then not as a free gift but as an equivalent for some work done.

('34', 311, 1, 2, 762163) 45. WIDOW REMARRIAGE
('34', 311, 2, 3, 762184) A widow writes: 1
('34', 311, 3, 4, 762202) The letter does credit to the correspondent, but her argument does not solve the problem whether widows should have the freedom to remarry.
('34', 311, 3, 5, 762342) When a child widow is totally ignorant of any dharma, how can we expect her to understand the dharma of a widow?
('34', 311, 3, 6, 762455) Living a life of dharma implies an understanding of what dharma means.
('34', 311, 3, 7, 762526) Can we say that a child who simply does not understand the distinction between right and wrong is guilty of a falsehood?
('34', 311, 3, 8, 762647) A child widow of nine years does not understand the meaning of marriage, nor of widowhood.
('34', 311, 3, 9, 762738) She is, as far as she is concerned, unmarried.
('34', 311, 3, 10, 762785) How, then, can we say that she has become a widow?
('34', 311, 3, 11, 762836) She was married by her parents, and it is they who think that she has become a widow?
('34', 311, 3, 12, 762922) If, therefore, the widow’s life earns merit for anyone, it does so for the parents.
('34', 311, 3, 13, 763006) But can they really earn such merit at the sacrifice of a nine year old girl?
('34', 311, 3, 14, 763084) Even if they can, the problem of the girl’s future is still with us.
('34', 311, 3, 15, 763153) Let us suppose that she has grown into a young woman of twenty years.
('34', 311, 3, 16, 763223) As she gradually came to understand things, she realized from the attitude of the people round her that she was regarded as a widow.
('34', 311, 3, 17, 763356) But let us suppose she has not understood a widow’s dharma, and also that, by the time she was twenty, the natural impulses had grown in her and become strong.
('34', 311, 3, 18, 763516) What should she do now?
('34', 311, 3, 19, 763540) She cannot say anything to her parents, for they have already decided that their daughter—a young woman now—was a widow and that marriage was out of the question for her.
('34', 311, 3, 20, 763711) This is only an imaginary instance.
('34', 311, 3, 21, 763747) But there are many Hindu widows in the country, thousands of them, whom this description will fit.
('34', 311, 3, 22, 763846) As we have seen, they earn merit for none by living as widows.
('34', 311, 3, 23, 763909) Whom shall we hold responsible for the many sins into which these young women fall in yielding to desire?

('34', 319, 4, 11, 778589) 57. GIVE US COTTON
('34', 319, 5, 12, 778608) The following 1 is a vivid description of a visit paid to some of the spinning centres in Bihar by Sjt.
('34', 319, 5, 13, 778712) Satish Chandra Das Gupta of Khadi Pratishthan.
('34', 319, 5, 14, 778759) It shows in the clearest manner possible what spinning is doing for the humble folks of this greart land of ours.
('34', 319, 5, 15, 778873) Millions of threads spun are like so many rays of sunshine brought into the frigid and dark dungeons miscalled homes of India.
('34', 319, 5, 16, 779000) The title that Satish Babu has chosen for his description well fits it.
('34', 319, 5, 17, 779072) This raw product goes to Manchester when our millions are ever crying “Give us cotton”.
('34', 319, 5, 18, 779160) Deft fingers are ready to turn it into warmth giving yarn for a few coppers but find it difficult to procure it.
('34', 319, 5, 19, 779273) Thousands of bales of this beautiful stuff are being exported abroad in order to raise the dividends of the huge multi millionaires who are engaged in exploiting the dumb millions of India.
('34', 319, 5, 20, 779463) It is up to every lover of the land, at least to see to it that he takes his full share in supplying cotton to those whom Satish Babu has described.
('34', 319, 5, 21, 779612) He can do it either by controlling such depots himself or sending his own subscription to the All India Spinners’ Association which will do it for him.
('34', 319, 5, 22, 779764) And he must be ready to make use of all the khaddar that can be woven out of yarn so spun.
('34', 319, 5, 23, 779855) He or she may add as many other activities as he or she likes to this primary one.
('34', 319, 5, 24, 779938) Young India, 25 2 1926
('34', 319, 6, 25, 779961) 1 Not reproduced here
('34', 320, 0, 1, 779983) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 321
('34', 320, 1, 2, 780028) 58. OUR HUMILIATION
('34', 320, 2, 3, 780048) Dr. Malan’s proposal and its final acceptance by the Viceroy make up a bitter cup of humiliation for the nation.
('34', 320, 2, 4, 780161) The Union Government has given a Select Committee that will take evidence on the principle as well as the details of the Asiatic Bill.
('34', 320, 2, 5, 780296) Dr. Malan has hedged it in with four conditions: That the Paddison Deputation should be the only party to give evidence before this Committee on behalf of the Government of India; that there should be no other deputation, no “agitator”—this is Dr. Malan’s own expression,—sent from India to supplement that evidence; that the Select Committee should report on or before the 1st of March and that the Bill should be taken up for final disposal during the present session of the Union Parliament.
('34', 320, 2, 6, 780791) In my opinion, not one of these conditions could be accepted by a free nation.
('34', 320, 2, 7, 780870) The Paddison Deputation went only to collect facts, and not to negotiate.
('34', 320, 2, 8, 780944) A far more important deputation would have gone if it had to negotiate and tender evidence.
('34', 320, 2, 9, 781036) It is insulting to impose a condition that no other deputation should proceed to South Africa.
('34', 320, 2, 10, 781131) It is still more insulting to insinuate that the Government of India could ever send an agitator to South Africa.
('34', 320, 2, 11, 781245) The patronizing language used by Dr. Malan regarding the Paddison Deputation only adds injury to insult.
('34', 320, 2, 12, 781350) The condition that the Select Committee should report before the 1st of March makes it hardly possible for the Government of India or the Indian settlers to collect and marshal all the evidence that can be tendered to show that the principle of the measure is contrary to the settlement of 1914. The announcement, side by side with that of the appointment of the Select Committee, that the Bill is to be proceeded with during the current session of the Union Parliament, shows that the Union Government has made up its mind regarding what it intends to do and that the appointment of the Select Committee is merely an eye wash designed to save the face of the Government of India and to hoodwink the world into believing that the Union Government wishes to do nothing unfair.
('34', 320, 2, 13, 782126) From this so called concession of the Union Government, therefore, I have no hope of any satisfaction for the doomed settlers.
('34', 320, 2, 14, 782253) That Government is conscious of its strength and is bent on using all that strength against the settlers.
('34', 320, 2, 15, 782359) It seems clear that the Government of India will accept the finding of the Select Committee and leave the settlers to their own fate.
('34', 320, 2, 16, 782493) India in her present state will probably be able to do nothing more than registering another more strong, emphatic and unanimous protest against the
('34', 321, 0, 1, 782642) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 321, 1, 2, 782684) action of the Union Government.
('34', 321, 1, 3, 782716) What then will the settlers do?
('34', 321, 1, 4, 782748) It is a question that they alone can answer.
('34', 321, 2, 5, 782793) Young India, 25 2 1926
('34', 321, 3, 6, 782816) 59. A STUDENT’S QUESTIONS
('34', 321, 4, 7, 782842) A Christian Indian domiciled in Ceylon but at present studying in the United States writes: 1
('34', 321, 5, 8, 782936) The magazines and papers here have so many different accounts about your actions that I am asking you for the true account for my own information and for that of my American friends.
('34', 321, 5, 9, 783119) Though some of the questions put have been already answered in these pages, they are of such general interest that they will bear repetition.
('34', 321, 5, 10, 783261) His first quesstion is:
('34', 321, 6, 11, 783285) What is your attitude towards the teachings of Jesus Christ?
('34', 321, 6, 12, 783346) They have an immense moral value for me, but I do not regard everything said in the Bible as the final word of God or exhaustive or even acceptable from the moral standpoint.
('34', 321, 6, 13, 783521) I regard Jesus Christ as one of the greatest teachers of mankind, but I do not consider him to be the “only son of God”.
('34', 321, 6, 14, 783642) Many pasages in the Bible are mystical.
('34', 321, 6, 15, 783682) For me “the letter killeth, the spirit giveth life” The second question is: Do you believe in caste?
('34', 321, 6, 16, 783783) If so, what do you consider to be its value?
('34', 321, 6, 17, 783828) I do not believe in caste as it is at present constituted, but I do believe in the four fundamental divisions regulated according to the four principal occupations.
('34', 321, 6, 18, 783993) The existing innumerable divisions with the attendant artificial restrictions and elaborate ceremonial are harmful to the growth of a religious spirit, as also to the social well being of the Hindus and therefore also their neighbours.
('34', 321, 6, 19, 784229) The third question is:
('34', 321, 7, 20, 784252) Is it your desire that India should be given Dominion status within the British Empire or that she should be given full independence and sever all connection from Britain?
('34', 321, 7, 21, 784424) If the latter is your desie, what system of government have you in view to take the place of the British system?
('34', 321, 7, 22, 784537) I should be quite satisfied with Dominion status within the British Empire, if it is a reality and not a sham.
('34', 321, 7, 23, 784648) I have no desire to sever all connection with Britain for the sake of it; but if I had the power, I should without a moment’s delay end the present unnatural
('34', 321, 8, 24, 784806) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('34', 322, 0, 1, 784843) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 323
('34', 322, 1, 2, 784888) and false position as it interferes with the fullest growth of the nation.
('34', 322, 1, 3, 784963) The only connection therefore with Britain that I would desire and value is that of an absolutely free and equal partnership at will.
('34', 322, 1, 4, 785097) If, however, the connection is broken, India will naturally have a system of democratic government suited to the genius of the people.
('34', 322, 1, 5, 785232) It will be shaped not according to one man’s wishes but to those of a multitude.
('34', 322, 1, 6, 785313) The fourth question is:
('34', 322, 2, 7, 785337) What is your attitude towards the Indian States and their Rulers?
('34', 322, 2, 8, 785403) My attitude towards the Indian States and their Rulers is that of perfect friendship.
('34', 322, 2, 9, 785489) I desire a radical reform in their constitution.
('34', 322, 2, 10, 785538) The condition in many States is most deplorable, but reform has to come from within and it is a matter for adjustment between the Rulers and the subjects, save for such pressure as is bound to be exerted upon them by the expression of enlightened public opinion in their neighbourhood.
('34', 322, 2, 11, 785824) The fifth question is:
('34', 322, 3, 12, 785847) Do you favour the idea of a United States of India on the lines of the U.S.A.?
('34', 322, 3, 13, 785926) The analogy is dangerous.
('34', 322, 3, 14, 785952) What seems to answer in the United States may not in India.
('34', 322, 3, 15, 786012) But subject to that caution, I suppose the final constitution would be a free and healthy union amongst the different provinces to be formed on a linguistic basis.
('34', 322, 3, 16, 786176) The sixth question is:
('34', 322, 4, 17, 786199) Many articles in these papers here say that you have differed from Dr. Tagore in many matters and have been estranged from him.
('34', 322, 4, 18, 786327) Is that true?
('34', 322, 4, 19, 786341) If so, what matters have caused the disagreement?
('34', 322, 4, 20, 786391) I have not differed from Dr. Tagore in many matters.
('34', 322, 4, 21, 786444) There are certainly differences of opinion between us in some matters.
('34', 322, 4, 22, 786515) It would be strange if there were none.
('34', 322, 4, 23, 786555) But there is not only not the slightest estrangement between us on that or any other account, but the most cordial relations have always existed and continue between us.
('34', 322, 4, 24, 786725) Indeed the friendship between us is all the richer and truer for the intellectual differences between us.
('34', 322, 4, 25, 786831) The seventh question is:
('34', 322, 5, 26, 786856) What are you doing in India just now?
('34', 322, 5, 27, 786894) Have you given up political leadership and politics?
('34', 322, 5, 28, 786947) At the present moment I am enjoying what may be called well earned rest, and at the same time trying to develop the working of the All India Spinners’ Association which is at present the only all India activity that engages my attention.
('34', 322, 5, 29, 787185) My political leadership technically ended with the closing of the year for which I was President of the Congress, but in reality it ended with my incarceration.
('34', 322, 5, 30, 787346) But I have not
('34', 323, 0, 1, 787361) 324 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 323, 1, 2, 787403) given up politics in my sense of the term.
('34', 323, 1, 3, 787446) I never was a politician in any other sense.
('34', 323, 1, 4, 787491) My politics concern themselves with internal growth but being of a universal nature they re act upon the external in a most effective manner.
('34', 323, 1, 5, 787633) The eighth question is:
('34', 323, 2, 6, 787657) I find a good deal of colour prejudice prevalent here, and at times we have to undergo many hardships on account of our colour.
('34', 323, 2, 7, 787785) What would you advise me to do in such cases?
('34', 323, 2, 8, 787831) Am I justified in writing home and telling them about it?
('34', 323, 2, 9, 787889) Or am I justified in telling the United States people themselves whenever I get an invitation to speak in public?
('34', 323, 2, 10, 788003) My advice is: Having gone there live down the prejudice, but resist unto life wherever it hurts your self respect in any shape or form.
('34', 323, 2, 11, 788139) Hardships must be the lot of those who have to live in an uncongenial atmosphere and who will still retain their self respect.
('34', 323, 2, 12, 788266) You are certainly justified in writing about it anywhere so long as you do so without bitterness and without exaggeration.
('34', 323, 2, 13, 788389) It would be the most proper thing to tell in a dignified manner the people of the United States of the hardships whenever you get an opportunity.
('34', 323, 2, 14, 788535) The ninth question is:
('34', 323, 3, 15, 788558) Would you please send me a small message for the students here?
('34', 323, 3, 16, 788622) They are as a rule very fine men and are preparing to devote their lives to Y.M.C.A. work.
('34', 323, 3, 17, 788713) If you mean Indian students, my humble advice is: Express the best that is in you in that far off foreign land, so that your lives may be an example to your neighbours.
('34', 323, 3, 18, 788882) Do not slavishly follow all that you see in the West.
('34', 323, 3, 19, 788936) And as you seem to be speaking on behalf of Christian students, I feel tempted to quote from the Bible: “Seek thee first the Kingdom of God and His righteousness and everything will be added unto you.”
('34', 323, 4, 20, 789138) Young India, 25 2 1926
('34', 323, 5, 21, 789161) 60. IN MITIGATION
('34', 323, 6, 22, 789179) I gladly publish the following from a German friend:
('34', 323, 7, 23, 789232) Last year, you published in Young India several articles on or letters from Germany which needs must give wrong impressions as to the situation in our country.
('34', 323, 7, 24, 789392) I intend to set right any false information about our country, though I am convinced you won’t have got a contemptuous opinion concerning the German nation.
('34', 323, 7, 25, 789549) I hope you will endorse a statement of C. F. Andrews writing to me on the 10th of July 1925: “I believe that India and Germany may meet on the basis of pure idealism: more closely than any other
('34', 324, 0, 1, 789744) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 325
('34', 324, 1, 2, 789789) nations of the world.” And in all humility I should like to give some remarks 1, for your information, on the above mentioned articles.
('34', 324, 1, 3, 789925) The writer is right in feeling assured that I can have no contemptuous opinion about Germans or Germany.
('34', 324, 1, 4, 790030) Who can dare?
('34', 324, 1, 5, 790044) Germans are a great and brave people.
('34', 324, 1, 6, 790082) Their industry, their scholarship, and their bravery command the admiration of the world.
('34', 324, 1, 7, 790172) One hopes that they will lead the peace movement.
('34', 324, 1, 8, 790222) They were defeated in the last War, not vanquished.
('34', 324, 1, 9, 790274) All that is needed is a transmutation of their marvellous energy for the promotion of the progress of the world as a whole, rather than its application for their own as against that of the whole world.
('34', 324, 1, 10, 790476) There are signs of that desirable change coming over them as over the other peoples of the earth.
('34', 324, 1, 11, 790574) Young India, 25 2 1926
('34', 324, 2, 12, 790597) 61. LETTER TO K. SRINIVASAN ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 25, 1926
('34', 324, 3, 13, 790662) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('34', 324, 3, 14, 790695) I am glad that the history of my life appeals to you and is helpful.
('34', 324, 3, 15, 790764) I could endorse your opinion that these inner experiences of mine are far more valuable than the tremendous political activity in which I have found myself throughout my life.
('34', 324, 3, 16, 790940) Such value as that activity possesses is derived from the inner experiences which I am endeavouring to recall and relate as accurately as it is possible for one to do.
('34', 324, 3, 17, 791108) I am trying to bring out every weakness and to show also how the weakness was overcome.
('34', 324, 3, 18, 791196) I do hope that you will give more attention to your spinning than you seem to have done.
('34', 324, 3, 19, 791285) As you are a scientist I need hardly draw your attention to the well established experience of the world that whatever is worth doing, is worth doing as well as it is possible for us to do.
('34', 324, 3, 20, 791475) Many of us who are spinning find it simple enough to spin 300 yards at least per hour provided the wheel is kept in order and the slivers are good.
('34', 324, 3, 21, 791623) The highest speed attained is 900 yards per hour.
('34', 324, 3, 22, 791673) Yours sincerely, K. SRINIVASAN DEPARTMENT OF ELECTRICAL TECHNOLOGY INDIAN INSTITUTE OF SCIENCE HEBBAL, P. O. BANGALORE

('34', 325, 1, 2, 791885) 62. LETTER TO C. SRINIVASA ROW
('34', 325, 2, 3, 791916) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 25, 1926
('34', 325, 3, 4, 791953) DEAR FRIEND,
('34', 325, 4, 5, 791966) I have your letter.
('34', 325, 4, 6, 791986) You have put me a most difficult question: Whether asking for Government recognition or financial assistance from the government for your institution is a moral sin or not is a question solely for you or the management to decide.
('34', 325, 4, 7, 792216) For one whom there is no consciousness of sin in a matter of this character there is no sin.
('34', 325, 4, 8, 792309) A stranger’s opinion therefore is of no value in determining the nature of the act proposed.
('34', 325, 4, 9, 792402) For my own self, if I were you, I could not possibly ask for Government recognition or assistance.
('34', 325, 4, 10, 792501) And, if thereby the students desert me, I should not feel sorry 1 because of the consiousness of the rightness of my abstention.
('34', 325, 4, 11, 792630) Whether your acceptance will be a political blunder or not is a question on which an outsider can give an opinion.
('34', 325, 4, 12, 792745) In terms of the Congress resolutions and the present tendency of Congressmen in general, it will not be a political blunder.
('34', 325, 4, 13, 792870) In the sense that an institution that has hitherto refused to bend before the storm might now feel impelled to bend, does really add to the already existing weakness.
('34', 325, 4, 14, 793037) On the whole, however, you must regard my opinion as purely an academic opinion.
('34', 325, 4, 15, 793118) You must therefore decide according to the inner promptings of your conscience and nobody would have the right to point the finger of scorn if you decide to take Government assistance.
('34', 325, 4, 16, 793303) You must fearlessly do what you consider to be right.
('34', 325, 4, 17, 793357) Yours sincerely, C. SRINIVASA ROW, ESQ.
('34', 325, 4, 18, 793397) ANDHRA JATHEEYA KALASALA MASULIPATAM

And the gentlemen who have gathered here and myself are of the opinion that so long as the new form that the conference has adopted at its Bhavnagar session is not stabilized, my presence would prove helpful.
('34', 327, 6, 12, 796083) I shall not hesitate to preside over the session if it helps the conference moving forward.

('34', 330, 1, 2, 799812) 70. LETTER TO S. GANESAN
('34', 330, 2, 3, 799837) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 27, 1926
('34', 330, 3, 4, 799874) DEAR MR. GANESAN,
('34', 330, 4, 5, 799892) I have your two letters.
('34', 330, 4, 6, 799917) I understand your point of view.
('34', 330, 4, 7, 799950) But you should also understand and appreciate mine.
('34', 330, 5, 8, 800002) Bapu has decided not to give permission regarding the Autobiography to anyone as it will require to be revised and even rewritten if necessary in the light of criticisms that may be made upon it.
('34', 330, 5, 9, 800198) After it is revised we desire to publish it from the Young India office and strike a new departure.
('34', 330, 5, 10, 800298) Bapu wants the thing to be done, if possible, in his presence and under his direct supervision which means that it cannot be entrusted to anyone else outside.
('34', 330, 6, 11, 800457) As regards translations also into foreign languages, the same remarks apply and to those that approach you for permission to translate, you should write in the terms of this letter.
('34', 330, 7, 12, 800639) Regarding foreign copyrights, Macmillan & Co.
('34', 330, 7, 13, 800685) approached Bapu through Mr. John Haynes Holmes who cabled that they were prepared to offer suitable terms for an American British copyright for the Autobiography.
('34', 330, 7, 14, 800848) Having already cabled to Haynes an affirmative reply, he is helpless though he will make it a strict condition that we will supply them with the manuscript and that it shall in no case be tampered with.
('34', 330, 8, 15, 801051) I have had a long talk with Bapu in the matter and I am writing this detailed letter after full consultation with him.
('34', 330, 9, 16, 801170) Yours sincerely,
('34', 330, 10, 17, 801187) MAHADEV DESAI SJT.

('34', 331, 1, 2, 801338) 71. LETTER TO G. A. NATESAN
('34', 331, 2, 3, 801366) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 27, 1926 DEAD MR. NATESAN,
('34', 331, 3, 4, 801421) I must hasten to repair an error I have unconsciously made.
('34', 331, 3, 5, 801481) I entirely misunderstood your telegram and so did Bapu and I wired to you in reply that you could certainly reproduce the Autobiography.
('34', 331, 3, 6, 801618) I understood you to mean that you wanted to reproduce my translation of the Autobiography in the Indian Review but I hear that you are already making preparations for publishing it in book form.
('34', 331, 3, 7, 801813) Please pardon me.

('34', 332, 3, 10, 804129) 73. ROYAL DISPLEASURE
('34', 332, 4, 11, 804151) The papers say that King George visited the Industrial Exhibition now being held in England.
('34', 332, 4, 12, 804244) There, in a section exhibiting English manufactured typewriters, he noticed a government employee typing letters on an American typewriter.
('34', 332, 4, 13, 804384) The King was angry at this and asked why, if English manufactured typewriters were in demand outside England, they in England used American typewriters.
('34', 332, 4, 14, 804537) The officer in charge promised to inquire into the matter and tried to pacify the King.
('34', 332, 4, 15, 804625) But the latter would not be pacified and said that he himself would inquire.
('34', 332, 4, 16, 804702) The manufacturer of the English typewriter stated that, if his typewriters were introduced in government offices in England, he could certainly provide employment for one more person for every typewriter bought.
('34', 332, 4, 17, 804914) Commenting on the incident, British newspapers say that, where the House of Commons has been helpless, the King’s firmness and displeasure will have some effect.
('34', 332, 4, 18, 805076) We may perhaps feel that England, which exports her goods to all countries in the world, has no justification for resenting the use of American typewriters.
('34', 332, 4, 19, 805233) If, however, we look at the matter from the King’s point of view, his displeasure will seem justified.
('34', 332, 4, 20, 805336) It was argued in defence that American typewriters were being used in government offices because of their superior quality.
('34', 332, 4, 21, 805460) But the King, a shrewd man, saw that one should not reject a local product because a foreign article

('34', 333, 3, 22, 807665) 74. WHAT IS EDUCATION?
('34', 333, 4, 23, 807688) The English word ‘education’ etymologically means ‘drawing out’.
('34', 333, 4, 24, 807753) That means an endeavour to develop our latent talents.
('34', 333, 4, 25, 807808) The same is the meaning of kelavani, the Gujarati word for education.
('34', 333, 4, 26, 807878) When we say that we develop a certain thing, it does not mean that we change its kind or quality, but that we bring out the qualities latent in it.
('34', 334, 0, 1, 808026) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 335
('34', 334, 1, 2, 808071) ‘education‘ can also mean ‘unfoldment’.
('34', 334, 1, 3, 808111) In this sense, we cannot look upon knowledge of the alphabet as education This is true even if that knowledge gains us the M.A. degree or enables us to adorn the place of a Shastri 1 in some pathshala 2 with the requisite knowledge of Sanskrit.
('34', 334, 1, 4, 808356) It may well be that the highest literary knowledge is a fine instrument for education or unfoldment, but it certainly does not itself constitute education.
('34', 334, 1, 5, 808512) True education is something different.
('34', 334, 1, 6, 808551) Man is made of three constituents, the body, mind and spirit.
('34', 334, 1, 7, 808613) Of them, spirit is the one permanent element in man.
('34', 334, 1, 8, 808666) The body and the mind function on account of it.
('34', 334, 1, 9, 808715) Hence we can call that education which reveals the qualities of spirit.
('34', 334, 1, 10, 808787) That is why the seal of the Vidyapith carries the dictum ‘Education is that which leads to moksha 3’ Education can also be understood in another sense; that is, whatever leads to a full or maximum development of all the three, the body, mind and spirit, may also be called education.
('34', 334, 1, 11, 809071) The knowledge that is being imparted today may possibly develop the mind a little, but certainly it does not develop the body and spirit.
('34', 334, 1, 12, 809209) I have a doubt about the development of the mind too, because it does not mean that the mind has developed if we have filled it with a lot of information.
('34', 334, 1, 13, 809364) We cannot therefore say that we have educated our mind.
('34', 334, 1, 14, 809420) A well educated mind serves man in the desired manner.
('34', 334, 1, 15, 809475) Our literate mind of today pulls us hither and thither.
('34', 334, 1, 16, 809531) That is what a wild horse does.
('34', 334, 1, 17, 809563) Only when a wild horse is broken in can we call it a trained horse.
('34', 334, 1, 18, 809631) How many ‘educated’ young men of today are so trained?
('34', 334, 1, 19, 809686) Now let us examine our body.
('34', 334, 1, 20, 809715) Are we supposed to cultivate the body by playing tennis, football or cricket for an hour every day?
('34', 334, 1, 21, 809815) It does, certainly, build up the body.
('34', 334, 1, 22, 809854) Like a wild horse, however, the body will be strong but not trained.
('34', 334, 1, 23, 809923) A trained body is healthy, vigorous and sinewy.
('34', 334, 1, 24, 809971) The hands and feet can do any desired work.
('34', 334, 1, 25, 810015) A pickaxe, a shovel, a hammer, etc., are like ornaments to a trained hand and it can wield them.
('34', 334, 1, 26, 810112) That hand can ply the spinning wheel well as also the ring and the comb while the feet work a loom.
('34', 334, 1, 27, 810212) A well trained body does not get tired in trudging 30 miles.
('34', 334, 1, 28, 810273) It can scale mountains without getting breathless.
('34', 334, 1, 29, 810324) Does the student acquire such physical culture?
('34', 334, 1, 30, 810372) We can assert that modern curricula do not impart physical education in this sense.
('34', 334, 2, 31, 810456) 1 Teacher 2 Indigenous school 3 Freedom from phenomenal existence as the goal of life
('34', 335, 0, 1, 810542) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 335, 1, 2, 810584) The less said about the spirit the better.
('34', 335, 1, 3, 810627) Only a seer or a seeker can enlighten the soul.
('34', 335, 1, 4, 810675) Who will awaken that dormant spiritual energy in us all?
('34', 335, 1, 5, 810732) Teachers can be had through an advertisement.
('34', 335, 1, 6, 810778) Is there a column for spiritual quest in the testimonials which they have to produce?
('34', 335, 1, 7, 810864) Even if there is one, what is its value?

('34', 339, 2, 3, 820692) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 2, 1926
('34', 339, 3, 4, 820725) DEAR MR. PETIT, I have your letter.
('34', 339, 3, 5, 820761) I have received two cables almost in the same language as that of the cables received by you.
('34', 339, 3, 6, 820855) I do not attach much importance to these cables.
('34', 339, 3, 7, 820904) Hence it was that I did not forward them to you.
('34', 339, 3, 8, 820953) There is a great deal of bickering going on at present in South Africa amongst our countrymen.
('34', 339, 3, 9, 821048) The community is cut up into so many groups.
('34', 339, 3, 10, 821093) Mr. Andrews’ presence there is a godsend.
('34', 339, 3, 11, 821135) The South African Indian Congress is an amalgamation of several associations.
('34', 339, 3, 12, 821213) The Natal Indian Congress is a body representing a section of Indians in Natal.
('34', 339, 3, 13, 821293) The British Indian Association is an association representing Transvaal Indians.

('34', 343, 4, 17, 828242) 82. NOTES
('34', 343, 5, 18, 828252) FOR JUVENILES Owing to the repeated requests of young friends under 18 years to become members of the All India Spinners’ Association, the Council has passed a resolution, at its last meeting, permitting boys and girls under 18 years who are habitual wearers of khaddar to become members upon sending 1,000 yards per month of their own spinning.
('34', 343, 5, 19, 828598) The idea is to encourage boys and girls to cultivate regularity, and to establish a moral bond between themselves and the poorest in the land.
('34', 343, 5, 20, 828741) And this inestimable advantage is gained apart from the art of spinning being a training for the eye and fingers.
('34', 343, 5, 21, 828855) Youths who wish to become members will be expected to spin daily for at least half an hour and if they will set apart a parcticular half hour for the purpose, they will find that it will induce a regularity in all other studies and work that they may undertake.
('34', 343, 5, 22, 829117) They will be expected to keep their wheels in perfect order, learn to repair them and learn also the art of carding and making their own slivers.
('34', 343, 5, 23, 829263) All these processes take up very little time, that is, for those who love their work.For schoolboys and girls, I recommend not the spinning wheel but the takli.
('34', 343, 5, 24, 829424) It has been ascertained that the takli enables one easily to
('34', 344, 0, 1, 829485) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 345
('34', 344, 1, 2, 829530) spin 80 yards per hour.
('34', 344, 1, 3, 829554) Spinning on the takli at the rate of half an hour daily gives one the required monthly subscription of 1,000 yards.
('34', 344, 1, 4, 829670) I hope therefore that many boys and girls will register them selves as members, subject to the permission of their parents or guardians.
('34', 344, 1, 5, 829807) So far schools are concerned, it will be saving of postage if schoolmasters will take charge of the yarn that may be spun and make one parcel taking care to attach cards to the quantity spun by each boy or girl.
('34', 344, 1, 6, 830019) The parcels should be addressed to the Director, Technical Department of the All India Spinners’ Association, Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati.
('34', 344, 1, 7, 830159) Juveniles or their guardians at the time of sending self spun yarn should note the name, age, sex and address of the spinner, give also the number of yards and state that the spinner habitually wears hand spun and hand woven khaddar.
('34', 344, 2, 8, 830393) FOR SELF SPINNERS The Director of the Technical Department of the All India Spinners’ Association writes that members have been repeatedly writing for the return of their yarn for converting into khaddar for their personal use and offering to pay any reasonable price.
('34', 344, 2, 9, 830662) The Secretary undertook to convert it into khadi and let them have it, provided that they did not mind the mixing of other hand spun yarn if their own was not sufficient.
('34', 344, 2, 10, 830833) But this proposal to mix it was not acceptable to the members inasmuch as they wanted the satisfaction of wearing clothes made out of yarn spun by themselves.
('34', 344, 2, 11, 830992) It has not been possible to comply with the desire of the members, laudable though it is in many respects, because of the possibility of some returning the same yarn as subscription.
('34', 344, 2, 12, 831175) For, it would not be possible for the Association to pick and choose, favour some members and condemn others.
('34', 344, 2, 13, 831285) A way has therefore been now discovered of selling the yarn received to the subscribers by doing so after bleaching it.
('34', 344, 2, 14, 831405) Bleaching will in no way damage the yarn.
('34', 344, 2, 15, 831447) It will whiten it, and if anything make it a trifle stronger.
('34', 344, 2, 16, 831509) Those, therefore, who want their yarn back against payment can have it on application to the Director, Technical Department, or the Secretary of the All India Spinners’ Association.
('34', 344, 2, 17, 831691) And those members who desire the return of their yarn will please take care to mark on the cards attached to their yarn in clear words “to be returned”.
('34', 344, 2, 18, 831844) The department will not be able to send the yarn by V.P. post.
('34', 345, 0, 1, 831907) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 345, 1, 2, 831949) therefore suggest, in order to avoid delay, that the senders deposit with the Director Rs. 5 when yarn will be returned immediately upon entry and examination and bleaching, unless the senders desire that sufficient quantity should be collected before the yarn is retuned.
('34', 345, 1, 3, 832222) ABOUT AUTOBIOGRAPHY Several friends in India and outside have been writing, cabling and wiring to me for permission to publish in book form the chapters that I am writing at present on “My Experiments with Truth”.
('34', 345, 1, 4, 832436) Whilst I have no objection to proprietors of newspapers and periodicals copying the chapters in their magazines or newspapers from time to time, I do not want to give permission for the publication of the chapters in book form at the present stage.
('34', 345, 1, 5, 832685) I have myself no idea when the story will be completed, and I would not like the chapters to be published in parts, and without undergoing a revision by me or under my direction.
('34', 345, 1, 6, 832864) Publishers will therefore kindly note that at the present moment I am not prepared to allow the chapters to be published or translated in book form.
('34', 345, 2, 7, 833013) Young India, 4 3 1926
('34', 345, 3, 8, 833035) 83. A REPUDIATION
('34', 345, 4, 9, 833053) H. R. Scott 1 at present stationed at Surat writes: 2
('34', 345, 5, 10, 833107) I have been reading with much interest your “Story” in Young India .
('34', 345, 5, 11, 833176) I was the only missionary in Rajkot during those years (from 1883 to 1897) .
('34', 345, 5, 12, 833253) I certainly never preached “at a corner near the High School” .
('34', 345, 5, 13, 833317) and I certainly never “poured abuse on Hindus and their gods” .
('34', 345, 5, 14, 833381) During my time in Rajkot I baptised a number of Brahmins and Jain sadhus.
('34', 345, 5, 15, 833455) They certainly had not to “eat beef and drink liquor”, either at their baptism or at any other time.Though the preaching took place over forty years ago the painful memory of it is still vivid before me.
('34', 345, 5, 16, 833659) What I have heard and read since has but confirmed that first impression.
('34', 345, 5, 17, 833733) I have read several missionary publications and they are able to see only the dark side and paint it darker still.
('34', 345, 5, 18, 833848) The famous hymn of Bishop Heber’s—“Greenland’s icy mountains’—is a clear libel on Indian humanity.
('34', 345, 5, 19, 833947) I was favoured with
('34', 345, 6, 20, 833967) 1 This appears to be a slip for S. R. Scott.Vide “Letter to S. R. Scott”, 23 2 1926. 2 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('34', 346, 0, 1, 834089) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 347
('34', 346, 1, 2, 834134) some literature evenat the Yeravda prison by well meaning missionaries, which seemed to be written as if merely to belittle Hinduism.
('34', 346, 1, 3, 834268) About beef eating and wine drinking at baptism I have merely stated what I heard and I have said as much in my writing.
('34', 346, 1, 4, 834388) And whilst I accept Mr. Scott’s repudiation I must say that though I have mixed freely among thousands of Christian Indians, I know very few who have scruples about eating beef or other flesh meats and drinking intoxicating liquors.
('34', 346, 1, 5, 834621) When I have gently reasoned with them, they have quoted to me the celebrated verse “Call thou nothing unclean” as if it referred to eating and gave a licence for indulgence.
('34', 346, 1, 6, 834795) I know that many Hindus eat meat, some eat even beef and drink wines.
('34', 346, 1, 7, 834865) They are not converts.
('34', 346, 1, 8, 834888) Converts are those who are “born again” or should be.
('34', 346, 1, 9, 834942) A higher standard is expected of those who change their faith, if the change is a matter of the heart and not of convenience.
('34', 346, 1, 10, 835068) But I must not enter into deeper waters.
('34', 346, 1, 11, 835109) It is a matter of pleasure to me to be able to say that if I have had painful experiences of Christians and Christian missionaries I have pleasant ones also which I treasure.
('34', 346, 1, 12, 835284) There is no doubt that among them the spirit of toleration is growing.
('34', 346, 1, 13, 835355) Among individuals there is also a deeper study of Hinduism and other faiths and an appreciation of their beauties, and among some even an admission that the other great faiths of the world are not false.
('34', 346, 1, 14, 835559) One is thankful for the growing liberal spirit but I have the conviction that much still remains to be done in that direction.

('34', 347, 3, 14, 837750) 85. ‘MISSION TO THE WOMEN OF INDIA’
('34', 347, 4, 15, 837786) When I paid my humble tribute to the memory of the late Mrs. Ramabai Ranade, I had occasion to mention the great work of the Poona Seva Sadan Society of which Sjt.
('34', 347, 4, 16, 837950) G. K. Devadhar is the soul.
('34', 347, 4, 17, 837978) He has however sent me literature about the work of this society and asks me to review it in the hope that the readers of Young India might help the institution which has an annual income of nearly 2 lakhs but whose total expenditure is estimated at 2 1 2 lakhs.
('34', 347, 4, 18, 838241) I rarely review the work of any institution which I do not know intimately.
('34', 347, 4, 19, 838317) I cannot claim to know this great society intimately, but I do know Sjt.
('34', 347, 4, 20, 838390) G. K. Devadhar intimately.
('34', 347, 4, 21, 838417) We have political differences between us but they have never blinded me to his devotion to the country and his indefatigable energy which he has sustained now for nearly a generation.
('34', 347, 4, 22, 838601) This is his own claim for the Seva Sadan Society’s work:
('34', 347, 5, 23, 838658) By gradual steps the Seva Sadan, Poona, has developed now into a big organization of the nature of a Mission to the women of India.
('34', 347, 5, 24, 838790) It promotes, through a widespread network of its branches and other allied institutions,
('34', 348, 0, 1, 838879) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 349
('34', 348, 1, 2, 838924) education—literary, industrial, medical and musical in character, specially among poor and grown up women of all castes and creeds in India.
('34', 348, 1, 3, 839065) The is how the origin of the institution is described: 1
('34', 348, 2, 4, 839122) While engaged in the famine relief campaign in the United Provinces in 1907 08, the conviction that was dawning in my mind grew deeper and stronger every day that India needed just as much an army of trained women workers in various fields of national advance for benefit to their sisters as she needed a band of devoted and trained men.
('34', 348, 2, 5, 839460) These meetings resulted in a resolve to undertake the education and training of half a dozen poor widows as social workers.
('34', 348, 2, 6, 839584) Thus the small seed has steadily developed today into a mighty growth.
('34', 348, 2, 7, 839655) It has eight branches conducting 94 classes in which 1,234 girls and women drawn from all classes receive instruction.
('34', 348, 2, 8, 839774) 48 is the percentage of widows attending these classes.
('34', 348, 2, 9, 839830) It is interesting to note that there are 3 women belonging to the suppressed class.
('34', 348, 2, 10, 839914) There are 8 Jews, 24 Christians and 7 Mohammedans.
('34', 348, 2, 11, 839965) The percentage of non Brahmins is 40. There are 270 women residing in the 13 hostels maintained by the society.
('34', 348, 2, 12, 840077) There are 92 receiving nursing and medical education.
('34', 348, 2, 13, 840131) It has turned out already 125 certified teachers, 42 fully qualified nurses, 31 midwives, 19 doctors, 17 matrons and governesses, 30 craft mistresses and 9 music teachers.
('34', 348, 2, 14, 840303) The institution is ever growing.
('34', 348, 2, 15, 840336) It is the largest of its kind in India.
('34', 348, 2, 16, 840376) For an institution that caters for the needs of poor women it certainly lacks one thing: hand spinning and use of khaddar.
('34', 348, 2, 17, 840499) But there probably Sjt.
('34', 348, 2, 18, 840523) Devadhar does not see eye to eye with me.
('34', 348, 2, 19, 840565) I can bide my time, for time always runs with the poor who have or have to have inexhaustible patience, and since the General Secretary’s heart is with the poor, he will not fail one day to recognize that if his hand of fellowship is to reach out to the poorest in the land, it will do so only through hand spun yarn.
('34', 348, 2, 20, 840883) To look at, it is a flimsy cotton thread but it is stout enough to bind all the millions of India together in its gentle and loving coil.
('34', 348, 2, 21, 841021) No doubt, embroidery work and such other things taught at the Seva Sadan are more paying than spinning but surely everything need not be reduced into rupees, annas, pies.
('34', 348, 2, 22, 841192) The 1,234 girls and women can be induced to give to their less fortunate fellow sisters half an hour of their time every day and they can well afford to wear and carry the weight of somewhat heavier khadi saris when they have the knowledge that these saris have helped to fill the hungry mouths of some of their unfortunate sisters.

('34', 349, 1, 2, 841621) 86. IN ITS NAKEDNESS
('34', 349, 2, 3, 841642) The Forward of Calcutta has rendered a public service by publishing extracts from the Report of the Indian Jail Committee of 1919 20 being the evidence given by Lt.
('34', 349, 2, 4, 841807) Colonel Mulvany on the treatment of State prisoners.
('34', 349, 2, 5, 841860) It brings vividly to light the evil of the present system of Government in all its nakedness.
('34', 349, 2, 6, 841954) It shows how the officials themselves are coached to do the wrong thing and thus corrupted and deprived of any sense of self respect.
('34', 349, 2, 7, 842088) Colonel Mulvany was Superintendent of the Alipore Central Jail at the time.
('34', 349, 2, 8, 842164) I cull the following 1 from his statement:
('34', 349, 3, 9, 842207) I have been in charge of one or the other of the Calcutta jails since the very beginning of the anarchical movement.
('34', 349, 3, 10, 842324) And I cannot say less than that my feelings were outraged by the cruelty of the treatment I was ordered and expected to carry out.
('34', 349, 3, 11, 842455) I submitted a report .
('34', 349, 3, 12, 842478) concerning two State prisoners in which I expressed my opinion that the degree of confinement to which they were subjected was so severe as to be liable to injure their health, that the confinement was more stringently solitary than any solitary confinement imposed under the Prisons Act or under jail regulations both of which were limited strictly to seven days.
('34', 349, 3, 13, 842843) I submitted this report deliberately with intent to force a crisis which must result either in my removal (which I did not anticipate) or in some amelioration of the cruelties I was ordered to inflict.
('34', 349, 3, 14, 843045) What was the result?
('34', 349, 3, 15, 843066) My letter was returned to me with the request to reconsider it.
('34', 349, 3, 16, 843130) The correspondence too referred to by Lt.
('34', 349, 3, 17, 843172) Colonel Mulvany is reproduced by the Forward.
('34', 349, 3, 18, 843218) I cannot resist the temptation to quote from the letter of the then Inspector General of Prisons who on receipt of the damning report from Lt.
('34', 349, 3, 19, 843361) Colonel Mulvany asked him to reconsider it and suggested the falsehood he was to say in his revised report.
('34', 349, 3, 20, 843469) Here is the relevant quotation:
('34', 349, 4, 21, 843501) Please reconsider this letter.
('34', 349, 4, 22, 843532) Remember it has to go to Simla and it will rouse the Olympian wrath.
('34', 349, 4, 23, 843601) The degree of solitary confinement is dictated to us by the police need of separating these prisoners not only from other native prisoners but from each other.
('34', 349, 4, 24, 843761) I think you might so far report that the prisoners are in solitary confinement and are permitted to exercise daily and that both are cheerful and the health of neither has suffered or words to that effect.
('34', 349, 5, 25, 843967) 1 Only excerpts reproduced here
('34', 350, 0, 1, 843999) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 351
('34', 350, 1, 2, 844044) Upon the receipt of this letter Lt.
('34', 350, 1, 3, 844080) Colonel Mulvany regretfully pocketed his pride and sent what he knew to be an untruthful report.
('34', 350, 1, 4, 844177) How is it possible after this report to believe any at all coming from a Government source and intended to whitewash it?
('34', 350, 1, 5, 844298) Nor is this an exceptional case.
('34', 350, 1, 6, 844331) This cooking of reports and statements is a most usual thing with the Government as is known to everyone who has had anything to do with Government departments.
('34', 350, 1, 7, 844492) Today everything has to be “edited” by superior officers.
('34', 350, 1, 8, 844550) Relatives of the brave men of Bengal who are being indefinitely detained without a trial have with difficulty come to know certain things about the prisoners, which have been given to the world and which go to show that they are being put to much unnecessary hardship.
('34', 350, 1, 9, 844819) The allegations are generally denied and where a total denial is not possible, partial truth is admitted and the blame for what suffering is admitted is thrown on the prisoners.
('34', 350, 1, 10, 844997) When Sjt.
('34', 350, 1, 11, 845007) Goswami succeeds in forcing a debate in the Assembly he is laughed at and told from the Government benches that Lt.
('34', 350, 1, 12, 845123) Colonel Mulvany’s statement was not accepted by the Committee.
('34', 350, 1, 13, 845186) The Government entrenching itself behind a wall of lies and the force of its bayonets treats the complaints with contempt in the certain belief that the detention and ill treatment of prisoners are necessary for the safety of the Englishmen it represents.
('34', 350, 1, 14, 845442) Bengal has declared a day of hartal by way of protest.
('34', 350, 1, 15, 845497) The Government cares little about hartals of impotent people.
('34', 350, 1, 16, 845559) It listens to no argument save that of force, whether of the sword or the soul.
('34', 350, 1, 17, 845639) It knows and respects the former, it does not know the latter and therefore fears it.
('34', 350, 1, 18, 845725) We have not the former.
