('34', 351, 3, 9, 846420) 88. LETTER TO HARIBHAU
('34', 351, 4, 10, 846443) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 4, 1926
('34', 351, 5, 11, 846476) DEAR HARIBHAU,
('34', 351, 6, 12, 846491) Maganlal has passed on your message to me.
('34', 351, 6, 13, 846534) If an expert can be posted in Poona, he will be sent but I want to controvert your argument.
('34', 351, 6, 14, 846627) We are not like Dunlops or Singers.
('34', 351, 6, 15, 846663) We have not an unlimited capital to lose.
('34', 351, 6, 16, 846705) We may not exploit in the sense that they do.
('34', 351, 6, 17, 846751) We may not add thousand per cent to the cost at the base.
('34', 351, 6, 18, 846809) Our methods therefore must be different from theirs.
('34', 351, 6, 19, 846862) If we concentrate upon a central factory for turning out wheels and their parts, the movement is doomed to fail.
('34', 351, 6, 20, 846975) On the contrary we must make the people self reliant and therefore teach them to make their own wheels.
('34', 351, 6, 21, 847079) This teaching of decentralization can only commence with the province and therefore you have to do what you are expecting Sabarmati to do, that is, the Central Board.
('34', 351, 6, 22, 847246) Maharashtra must train experts who will spread themselves in different parts and in their turn whilst helping the people will teach them.
('34', 351, 6, 23, 847384) Those who believe in the wheel must not be satisfied with merely spinning yarn but must understand the mechanism of the wheel themselves, to be able to mend it, to replace parts, learn all the easy methods of making and adjusting holders, spindle, outfit, etc.
('34', 351, 6, 24, 847645) What is in its nature easy we must not make difficult by telling people that they need to come to us for putting their wheels right when they get out of order.
('34', 351, 6, 25, 847805) I therefore suggest to you that you now begin to make an effort to become self reliant and self contained, getting from
('34', 352, 0, 1, 847925) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 353
('34', 352, 1, 2, 847970) here all the help you need in the process.
('34', 352, 1, 3, 848013) We have now reached a stage in the career of khadi when it can go forward in leaps and bounds if only the few workers that we are would make ourselves experts in all its various branches—a consummation which really does not require either much time or extraordinary intelligence or ability.
('34', 352, 1, 4, 848304) All that is required is sustained application.
('34', 352, 1, 5, 848351) Maganlal is dealing with the rest of your letter.
('34', 352, 1, 6, 848401) Yours, From a microfilm: S. N. 19343

('34', 362, 10, 17, 865418) 105. WITH BARE RELIGIOUS RITES
('34', 362, 11, 18, 865449) Though the Satyagraha Ashram has kept before itself the ideal of inviolate celibacy, it recently celebrated some marriages; the events being of general interest, I have commented on them in Navajivan.
('34', 362, 11, 19, 865650) I have discussed privately among friends how the Ashram which has accepted celibacy as its ideal can thus encourage marriages.
('34', 362, 11, 20, 865777) However, a brief reply to the question for the benefit of readers who take interest in the activities of the Ashram will not be out of place.
('34', 362, 11, 21, 865919) If those who aspire to follow the ideal of brahmacharya accepted by the Satyagraha Ashram cannot even bear to see a wedding, I think, they will never be able to practise brahmacharya for their whole life.
('34', 362, 11, 22, 866124) We all know the story of Rishyashrung 1. If a person hankers after a thing from which he keeps himself away and still pretends that he is indifferent to it, his pretence will not succeed for
('34', 362, 12, 23, 866315) 1 In the Ramayana; a young ascetic, brought up without any acquaintance with women, was fascinated by the first woman he set eyes on.
('34', 363, 0, 1, 866449) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 363, 1, 2, 866491) He should, on the countrary, be ready to battle with the temptations which may occasionally face him.
('34', 363, 1, 3, 866593) He whose mind wavers is no brahmachari; only that self restraint which is exercised of one’s own free will can endure.
('34', 363, 1, 4, 866712) This is what Nishkulanand had in mind when he wrote in his poem: “Renunciation cannot last without detachment”.
('34', 363, 1, 5, 866824) One who feels joy in self restraint and loves it will not be tempted by things which might violate his vow of self restraint, but will remain indifferent to them.
('34', 363, 1, 6, 866987) Moreover, there are boys and girls in the Satyagraha Ashram and it cannot attempt to keep them unmarried against their will.
('34', 363, 1, 7, 867112) It naturally becomes the Ashram’s duty to help them to marry when they feel that they will not be able to observe brahmacharya throughout their lives.
('34', 363, 1, 8, 867263) Moreover, the Ashram has a few well wishers and its inmates feel bound to help in any way they can to make the weddings of these friends’ sons and daughters model celebrations.
('34', 363, 1, 9, 867440) It has been my view that, though arranged under the auspices of the Ashram, such weddings are not likely to harm its ideal of brahmacharya.
('34', 363, 1, 10, 867580) Hence, instead of forbidding I have actually encouraged the Ashram to arrange them under its auspices.
('34', 363, 1, 11, 867683) One such wedding of a girl brought up in the Ashram itself took place recently.
('34', 363, 1, 12, 867763) Readers of Navajivan know Shri Lakshmidas Purushottam.
('34', 363, 1, 13, 867818) His eldest daughter, Chi.
('34', 363, 1, 14, 867844) Moti, was married about a month ago to Shri Najuklal Chokshi, a worker in the Broach Kelavani Mandal.
('34', 363, 1, 15, 867946) The marriage was arranged without any stipulation of gifts from either side.
('34', 363, 1, 16, 868023) I have been told that such marriages are rare in the Bhatia community.
('34', 363, 1, 17, 868094) We may add that the marriage was the result of free choice by the bride and the bridegroom, for though the initiative was taken by the bride’s parents the final decision was made by the parties themselves.
('34', 363, 1, 18, 868300) The wedding was arranged only when both of them felt that they wished to be joined in holy wedlock.
('34', 363, 1, 19, 868400) None except close friends were invited to the ceremony, either as guests in the party of the bride or the bridegroom or in any other capacity.
('34', 363, 1, 20, 868543) The couple wore their usual khadi dress.
('34', 363, 1, 21, 868584) They had, on their own, decided not to wear ornaments.
('34', 363, 1, 22, 868639) Both of them kept a fast till the ceremony of joining their hands in marriage.
('34', 363, 1, 23, 868718) The wedding cermony included nothing besides what was laid down in the ancient Shastras.
('34', 363, 1, 24, 868807) The bridegroom had sent no gifts for the bride, for the latter’s parents did not want any to be sent.
('34', 363, 1, 25, 868909) Weddings like this where neither side is put to the expense of even five rupees and the occasion is regarded as an opportunity for the exercise of self restraint are very rare in the country.
('34', 364, 0, 1, 869101) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 365
('34', 364, 1, 2, 869146) A marriage celebrated in this manner cannot be considered a licence for self indulgence.
('34', 364, 1, 3, 869235) The couple’s married life will be a course of self restraint, just as brahmacharya is.
('34', 364, 1, 4, 869322) I know that expenditure on marriages among Bhatias is increasing day by day, since the community has plenty of money.
('34', 364, 1, 5, 869440) The bride is, so to say, a commodity offered in sale, and this is done shamelessly since the practice is almost universal among them.
('34', 364, 1, 6, 869574) A poor Bhatia, therefore, finds it extremely difficult to get a bride.
('34', 364, 1, 7, 869645) I have given such publicity to this event in the hope that religious minded Bhatia families will follow the example of the wedding here described.
('34', 364, 1, 8, 869792) Another wedding, of the same kind as the one described above if not exactly like it, was celebrated under the auspices of the Ashram on Sunday last.
('34', 364, 1, 9, 869941) The parties were members of the Marwari community.
('34', 364, 1, 10, 869992) Shri Jamnalal Bajaj gave in marriage his eldest daughter, Chi.

('34', 364, 1, 17, 870497) Shri Jamnalalji wanted it to be solemnized without ostentation and with the minimum of expenditure, and wished at the same time that the ceremony should bring home to the brideand the bridegroom the significance of marriage, its essentially religious character, and also clearly explain to them their mutual obligations.
('34', 364, 1, 18, 870818) Shri Jamnalalji and I felt that such a wedding could be celebrated only in the precincts of the Ashram.

('34', 364, 1, 26, 871472) Both the bride and the bridegroom were dressed in khadi.

('34', 367, 1, 2, 874910) 107. LETTER TO SAROJINI NAIDU
('34', 367, 2, 3, 874940) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 9, 1926
('34', 367, 3, 4, 874973) DEAR MIRABAI, I enclose herewith a copy of cable received from Johannesburg.
('34', 367, 3, 5, 875050) I telegraphed the substance to Sorabji but I thought you should have the full text.
('34', 367, 3, 6, 875134) I have replied ‘Await decision Committee, Delhi’.
('34', 367, 3, 7, 875184) This reply I have sent in continuation of my assurance to Sorabji that I shall not give any advice to the settlers in South Africa contrary to what the Committee that seems to have been formed there may say or do.
('34', 367, 3, 8, 875398) My own opinion however remains unchanged that we are being ourselves in the wrong by absolutely refusing to give evidence even on the principle of the Bill.
('34', 367, 3, 9, 875555) I have heard the objection namely that our people will not be able to stand the fire of cross examination and that there is no Indian of sufficient calibre and experience in South Africa who can give evidence.
('34', 367, 3, 10, 875765) The obvious answer is that no Indian need give evidence.
('34', 367, 3, 11, 875822) As you will see the Select Committee has asked for a written representation which can be prepared and the Solicitor who may be engaged on our behalf may submit himself for cross examination.
('34', 367, 3, 12, 876013) I know the difficulty of selecting such a Solicitor or Counsel, but it is not an impossible task.
('34', 367, 3, 13, 876111) Adam Alexander would not make a bad representative.
('34', 367, 3, 14, 876163) He is a fairly conscientious man and his sympathies are with us.
('34', 367, 3, 15, 876228) It is possible to think of others who can also give evidence without compromising or selling the community.
('34', 367, 3, 16, 876336) What I want to say is that though nothing may come out of the Select Committee, we should not leave it open to them to say that although we were given the opportunity we did not even lead evidence.
('34', 367, 3, 17, 876534) Let it not be said that in 1914 I boycotted the Solomon Commission.
('34', 367, 3, 18, 876602) I did so for the simple reason that the community had taken the solemn resolution that if the Government did not widen the terms of the Commission and appoint a representative on behalf of the community on the Commission it would be boycotted.
('34', 367, 3, 19, 876846) Hence the adherence to the resolution.
('34', 367, 3, 20, 876885) Even so it could be recalled that before even the Commission sat, I had come to an understanding with General Smuts that the Asiatic Act would be repealed and that General Smuts would require from the Commission a finding that would enable him to offer us an honourable settlement.
('34', 367, 3, 21, 877167) This is a matter of partly of record [sic].
('34', 367, 3, 22, 877211) I hope you are keeping well and I wish you every success in the
('34', 368, 0, 1, 877275) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 369
('34', 368, 1, 2, 877320) delicate tasks which are just now engaging your attention.
('34', 368, 2, 3, 877379) Yours sincerely, Encl.

('34', 369, 0, 1, 878423) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 369, 1, 2, 878465) 110. ANDREWS’ AGONY
('34', 369, 2, 3, 878485) The reader will like to share with me the following letter from Charlie Andrews, that noble hearted Englishman who fights our battles whether in or outside India with a selflessness and devotion difficult to equal, impossible to surpass, often in the midst of misunderstanding.
('34', 369, 2, 4, 878763) We shall probably never know what solace and strength his presence has meant to our countrymen in South Africa, in their hour of need.
('34', 369, 2, 5, 878898) Here is his letter dated Cape Town, 23rd February, without the alteration or removal of a single word: 1
('34', 369, 3, 6, 879003) This has been a long drawn agony such as I have never experienced hitherto, with its rises and falls, its hopes and crushing disappointments.
('34', 369, 3, 7, 879145) There seemed to be for a time one of those sudden revolutions when all doors seemed open and it appeared possible that there might be a relenting and a realizing just as there was in 1914. I had two very long talks,—one with General Hertzog and one with Malan, both of them extremely earnest and as I felt sincere.
('34', 369, 3, 8, 879460) It even seemed to me that their fundamental position was shaken and that there would be at least a long postponement.
('34', 369, 4, 9, 879578) But now it has all gone back again.
('34', 369, 4, 10, 879614) The reaction began with the Colour Bar Bill.
('34', 369, 4, 11, 879659) Nothing could have been more spiritually degrading than the scenes in Parliament—each side charging the other with hypocrisy.
('34', 369, 5, 12, 879785) The scene at the First Reading was significant.
('34', 369, 5, 13, 879833) Smuts and Smartt at Drummond Chaplin stayed away.
('34', 369, 5, 14, 879883) The rest went almost frivolously to a Division—81 to 10 —the later merely being a handful of Cape members who have coloured voters to care for.
('34', 369, 6, 15, 880027) It is a strange South Africa today.
('34', 369, 6, 16, 880063) All the liberal element which you and I knew so well in 1914 seems to have vanished .
('34', 369, 7, 17, 880149) Manilal has been working so well and he has been feeling it all the more deeply than anyone else.
('34', 369, 7, 18, 880247) I do not share Mr. Andrews’ gloomy forecast, not that I believe in the Imperial Government or the Government of India doing anything heroic.
('34', 369, 7, 19, 880388) But I believe in the ultimate triumph of truth when it is embodied in brave souls and in the ability and willingness of Indian settlers to render a good account of themselves when the supreme moment comes.
('34', 369, 7, 20, 880594) They have but to be prepared for voluntary and ennobling suffering in order to win.
('34', 369, 7, 21, 880678) Compulsory and degrading suffering is provided for them in the laws against which they are fighting.
('34', 369, 7, 22, 880779) Theirs is the choice.
('34', 369, 8, 23, 880801) Young India, 11 3 1926
('34', 369, 9, 24, 880824) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('34', 370, 0, 1, 880861) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 371
('34', 370, 1, 2, 880906) 111. STILL SHIRKING THE ISSUE Another case like the one discussed in these pages recently has been decided in the South with reference to the vexed question of temple entry by the so called untouchables.
('34', 370, 1, 3, 881110) One Murugesan, a Mala by caste, was tried before the Stationary Sub Magistrate of Tirupathi for having ventured to enter a temple at Tiruchanur for the purpose of offering worship.
('34', 370, 1, 4, 881291) The Lower Court regarded this entry as ‘defilement with intent to insult the religion of a class’ under section 295 of I.P.C. and fined the accused Rs. 75 or in default rigorous imprisonment for one month.
('34', 370, 1, 5, 881497) Fortunately for the poor outcaste there were reformers who were interested in him.
('34', 370, 1, 6, 881580) The case went in appeal.
('34', 370, 1, 7, 881605) The appellate court sustained the appeal.
('34', 370, 1, 8, 881647) I quote the following from the judgment.
('34', 370, 2, 9, 881688) In the Lower Court 7 witnesses were examined for the prosecution.
('34', 370, 2, 10, 881754) It is shown by their evidence that the appellant is a Mala by caste, that Malas are not allowed to enter the temple and that the entry of Malas into the temple is considered a defilement of it.
('34', 370, 2, 11, 881948) It is shown also that appellant went into the temple to the garbagudi where caste Hindus alone may enter.
('34', 370, 2, 12, 882054) He was then dressed properly and wearing marks of piety; the Archaka taking him for a caste Hindu, received his offering of cocoanuts and performed camphor harathi for him, for which service appellant paid the prescribed fee of four annas.
('34', 370, 2, 13, 882294) After appellant departed the temple authorities found that he was a Mala and as the place of worship was considered defiled by his presence it became necessary to perform a purificatory ceremony.
('34', 370, 2, 14, 882490) The first thing to consider is whether the prosecution evidence has made out the elements of the offence so as to warrant the framing of a charge.
('34', 370, 2, 15, 882637) The fact of defilement of the place of worship by the entry therein of accused who is a Mala is sufficiently made out in the sense that a ritual impurity was caused thereby.
('34', 370, 2, 16, 882811) But in addition it was necessary to show that the effect was an insult to the religion of any class of persons and that the accused intended such effect or knew of its possibility.
('34', 370, 2, 17, 882992) The case for the prosecution does not seem to have been conducted with this point kept in view and it has not been elicited from any of the witnesses that accused’s act was an insult to the religion of the witnesses or any class of persons leaving alone the question whether accused intended such insult or knew it to be likely.
('34', 370, 2, 18, 883321) On account of this defect in the state of the prosecution evidence I think the conviction cannot stand.
('34', 370, 2, 19, 883425) I do not think the case should be ordered to be retried.
('34', 370, 2, 20, 883482) Again the prosecutors, the judges and the deliverers of the poor despised men were his co religionists—Hindus.
('34', 370, 2, 21, 883593) Again the accused was happily saved from rigorous imprisonment (he could not pay the exorbitant fine I presume).
('34', 370, 2, 22, 883706) But again the cause remains undecided.
('34', 370, 2, 23, 883745) It was open to the Hindu judge to say that the entry into a Hindu temple
('34', 371, 0, 1, 883818) 372 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 371, 1, 2, 883860) by a Panchama Hindu with the object of offering worship could not by any stretch of the meaning of the word ‘insult’ constitute an insult to the Hindu religion to which the accused claimed and was admitted to belong.
('34', 371, 1, 3, 884077) It may have been improper in the estimation of some Hindus for the accused to enter the temple, it may have been contrary to custom, it may have been a hundred other things, but it was not an insult to the religion of any class such as to amount to a crime under the Indian Penal Code.
('34', 371, 1, 4, 884363) It is worthy of note that the accused bore no visible marks of his despised birth.
('34', 371, 1, 5, 884446) He was “dressed properly and wearing marks of piety”.
('34', 371, 1, 6, 884500) Indeed if these persecuted men choose to practise deception, it would be imposible to distinguish them from the rest.
('34', 371, 1, 7, 884618) It is simple fanatical obstinacy to persist in persecuting men in the sacred name of religion.
('34', 371, 1, 8, 884713) It is the persecutors who are unknowingly defiling their own religion by keeping out of public temples men who are at least as honourable as they claim to be themselves and are willing to abide by all the ceremonial rules observable by Hindus in general on such occasions.
('34', 371, 1, 9, 884986) More than that no man has any right to impose or expect.
('34', 371, 1, 10, 885043) The heart of man only God knows.
('34', 371, 1, 11, 885076) An ill dressed Panchama may have a much cleaner heart than a meticulously dressed high caste Hindu.
('34', 371, 2, 12, 885176) Young India, 11 3 1926
('34', 371, 3, 13, 885199) 112. NOTES
('34', 371, 4, 14, 885210) THE POET AND THE WHEEL
('34', 371, 5, 15, 885233) In spite of the weakness of body to which the Poet himself referred in his address at the Abhoy Ashram, it was a good thing for Dr. Suresh Bannerji, the manager of the Abhoy Ashram, at Comilla, to have drawn Dr. Tagore there.
('34', 371, 5, 16, 885459) The reader knows that the Abhoy Ashram was established for the purpose of khaddar development.
('34', 371, 5, 17, 885554) The Poet’s acceptance of the address and such association as it may imply on his part with khaddar movement dispels, if any dispeller was necessary, the superstition that the Poet is against the spinning wheel and the khaddar movement in every shape or form.
('34', 371, 5, 18, 885813) In the epitome of his address published in the Servant, I find the following reference to the movement:
('34', 371, 6, 19, 885917) The country is not one’s own by mere accident of birth but becomes so by one’s life’s contribution.
('34', 371, 6, 20, 886017) An animal has got its fur but man has got to spin and weave because what the animal has got, it has got once for all and ready 
('34', 372, 0, 1, 886145) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 373
('34', 372, 1, 2, 886190) It is for man to re arrange and reshuffle for his purposes materials he finds placed before him.
('34', 372, 2, 3, 886287) But there are other pregnant facts in the address which are helpful to workers for swaraj.
('34', 372, 2, 4, 886378) This is what the Poet has to say to us:
('34', 372, 3, 5, 886418) That we were so long kept from realizing India in her true self is due to the fact that we have not by daily endeavour created her moment by moment making her healthful and fruitful.
('34', 372, 3, 6, 886601) Thus he adjures us each one individually to make daily endeavour if we are to gain swaraj.
('34', 372, 3, 7, 886692) In the very next sentence he asks us “not to cherish the dream that swaraj can be ours by some extraneous happening”.
('34', 372, 4, 8, 886810) The Poet adds:
('34', 372, 5, 9, 886825) It can be ours in so far as we succeed in permeating our consciousness throughout the country by service.
('34', 372, 6, 10, 886931) He tells us also how to attain unity.
('34', 372, 6, 11, 886969) “We could attain unity only through work.” That is what the inmates of the Abhoy Ashram are actually doing.
('34', 372, 6, 12, 887077) For, through their spinning they are helping Hindus, Mussalmans, in fact everybody, who needs help through that source.
('34', 372, 6, 13, 887197) They are teaching untouchable boys and girls through their school and through it teach them to spin also.
('34', 372, 6, 14, 887303) Through their dispensary they are giving relief to the ailing irrespective of race or religion.
('34', 372, 6, 15, 887399) They need to preach no sermon on unity.
('34', 372, 6, 16, 887439) They live it.
('34', 372, 6, 17, 887453) This work inspires the Poet and he therefore proceeds to say:
('34', 372, 7, 18, 887515) Life is an organic whole.
('34', 372, 7, 19, 887541) It is the spirit that after all matters.
('34', 372, 7, 20, 887582) It is not a
('34', 372, 8, 21, 887594) fact that there is lack of strength in our arms.
('34', 372, 8, 22, 887643) The fact is that our mind has not
('34', 372, 9, 23, 887677) been awakened.
('34', 372, 9, 24, 887692) Our greatest fight here therefore is that against mental
('34', 372, 10, 25, 887749) lethargy.
('34', 372, 10, 26, 887759) The village is a living entity.
('34', 372, 10, 27, 887791) You cannot neglect any one
('34', 372, 11, 28, 887818) department of its life without injuring the other.
('34', 372, 11, 29, 887869) We are to realize today the
('34', 372, 12, 30, 887897) soul of our country as a great indivisible whole and likewise all our disabilities
('34', 372, 13, 31, 887980) and miseries as one inter related whole.
('34', 372, 14, 32, 888021) Referring to our failure the Poet truly says:
('34', 372, 15, 33, 888067) Man’s creation can be beautiful in so far as he has given himself to his
('34', 372, 16, 34, 888140) The reason why our enterprises in this country fail so often is that we
('34', 372, 17, 35, 888212) give only a portion of ourselves to the cause dear to our heart.
('34', 372, 17, 36, 888277) We give with
('34', 372, 18, 37, 888290) the right hand to steal back with the left.
('34', 373, 0, 1, 888334) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 373, 1, 2, 888376) WHY NOT VISIT AMERICA?
('34', 373, 1, 3, 888399) A correspondent writes:
('34', 373, 2, 4, 888423) You are refusing invitations from America.
('34', 373, 2, 5, 888466) Of course you know better than I whether the time is really opportune or not.
('34', 373, 2, 6, 888544) Yet I cannot make out why you should not visit the New World.
('34', 373, 2, 7, 888606) Your one and main ground is that you have not yet been completely successful in your own land amongst your own people.
('34', 373, 2, 8, 888725) But success or failure should be judged by God alone.
('34', 373, 2, 9, 888779) Do you mean to say that the movement of non violence inaugurated by you has not yet been firmly established?
('34', 373, 2, 10, 888888) Truth supports truth.
('34', 373, 2, 11, 888910) Would you differ from me in holding that this movement requires a world wide campaign?
('34', 373, 2, 12, 888997) And America and India— should they not be alike to you in respect of truth and non violence?
('34', 373, 3, 13, 889090) I should cite one or two instances as well in this connection.
('34', 373, 3, 14, 889153) Our Prophet Hazrat Muhammad (peace be on Him) did not, when necessary, hesitate to accept the help of His followers from Medina though outside Mecca, His own birth place.
('34', 373, 3, 15, 889324) More recently Swami Vivekanannda found a better field in America to proclaim his message to the world.
('34', 373, 4, 16, 889427) And again, if to materialize [sic] the success of khaddar movement stands in your way, you know that you can collect funds from America.
('34', 373, 4, 17, 889564) Why not make a condition (to yourself at least) that you must collect for khaddar from America this or that amount of rupees.
('34', 373, 4, 18, 889690) “Give and take”must have its sway.
('34', 373, 4, 19, 889725) If funds be sufficient at the back of khaddar movement, its popularity and success will not be long coming.
('34', 373, 4, 20, 889833) This is one out of many received by me pressing me to accept the invitation from America.
('34', 373, 4, 21, 889923) My reason is simple.
('34', 373, 4, 22, 889944) I have not enough self confidence to warrant my going to America.
('34', 373, 4, 23, 890010) I have no doubt that the movement of non violence has come to stay.
('34', 373, 4, 24, 890078) I have no doubt whatsoever about its final success; but I cannot give an ocular demonstration of the efficacy of non violence.
('34', 373, 4, 25, 890205) Till then, I feel that I must continue to preach from the narrower Indian platform.
('34', 373, 4, 26, 890289) There is no analogy between the illustrations cited and my case.
('34', 373, 4, 27, 890354) But in any case the Prophet and the Swami felt the call.
('34', 373, 4, 28, 890411) I do not as yet.
('34', 373, 4, 29, 890428) The success of khaddar rests not merely upon sufficiency of funds.
('34', 373, 4, 30, 890495) There are many factors whose co ordination is necessary for the stabilization of khaddar.
('34', 373, 4, 31, 890585) If ever I go to America, it will not be with the intention of collecting funds for any Indian movement with which I may be connected.
('34', 373, 4, 32, 890719) India must shoulder her won burden and if America feels the call to help she would do so not on the principle of “give and take” but independently.
('34', 373, 4, 33, 890867) My visit and America’s help must each stand on its own merits.
('34', 373, 5, 34, 890930) A CORRECTION A correspondent writes to say that the M.L.C. referred to in
('34', 374, 0, 1, 891004) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 375
('34', 374, 1, 2, 891049) Young India of 18 2 26 is not himself a self spinner.

('34', 374, 1, 5, 891158) I printed the information as it came from an authoritative source.
('34', 374, 1, 6, 891225) The khaddar movement and for that matter any movement can gain nothing by exaggeration.
('34', 374, 1, 7, 891313) The slightest inaccuracy harms a pure movement.
('34', 374, 1, 8, 891361) If M.L.C.s spin the fact may be advertised but the movement must continue in its purity whether M.L.C.s spin or not, whether many spin or a few only.
('34', 374, 1, 9, 891511) If it has intrinsic value, i.e., if there are millions of starving people in India, if they are idling away at least a third of their time and if hand spinning be the only occupation immediately available for such a vast mass of humanity, the cult will advance even if for the time being only one true man represents it.
('34', 374, 1, 10, 891832) If the assumptions be wrong, the movement will perish even though the Viceroy may spin.
('34', 374, 1, 11, 891920) Let every khadi worker then realize that this is a movement for the multitude of paupers of India and that for rapid advance it needs above all else the strictest accuracy of statement.
('34', 374, 1, 12, 892106) The Secretary who supplied the figures published writes to say that the prizes offered were not meant for rich men but that they were meant for those poor people who attend clubs regularly.

('34', 376, 1, 2, 894633) 115. LETTER TO D. HANUMANTHARAO
('34', 376, 2, 3, 894665) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 11, 1926
('34', 376, 3, 4, 894699) MY DEAR HANUMANTHARAO,
('34', 376, 4, 5, 894722) I like your letters, the latest more especially, though I dissent entirely from several of your conclusions.
('34', 376, 4, 6, 894831) I like your robust faith in the no drug theory and I like also your insistence on my avoidance of all drugs under every conceivable circumstance, but experience has taught me that reformers develop a certain amount of intolerance and fanaticism which hinder the reform that they have so much at heart.
('34', 376, 4, 7, 895133) The evils that you recite about quinine, for instance, are evils that arise from taking large doses and for a prolonged period, whereas I took it in five grain doses, never more than 10 grains in 24 hours, diluted in fresh lemon juice and plenty of water and mixed with soda bicarb.
('34', 376, 4, 8, 895416) In all, I took not more than 30 grains spread over 5 days.
('34', 376, 4, 9, 895475) Thus for 4 days I had only 5 grains per day.
('34', 376, 4, 10, 895520) I have suffered from no visible evil effect and I was able to satisfy so many anxious friends and doctors who insisted on my taking 15 grain doses.
('34', 376, 4, 11, 895668) The indiscriminate attack upon quinine will prove futile because that is the one drug whose general potency for the temporary cure of malaria is not to be questioned.
('34', 376, 4, 12, 895835) People won’t be frightened by the possible evil effect of quinine if it produces the tangible present result of checking the ravages of malaria.
('34', 376, 4, 13, 895980) The attack therefore must be a flank attack.
('34', 376, 4, 14, 896025) The reasons for my taking quinine were just the same as the reasons for undergoing the operation 1 when I was under restraint.
('34', 376, 4, 15, 896152) If the restraint then induced me to give in, how much more the restraint of unadulterated love should have done in the latest instance?
('34', 376, 4, 16, 896288) But nothing could either have induced me to undergo the operation at the Sassoon hospital if I had not been convinced that it was purely an echo of my own weakness.
('34', 376, 4, 17, 896453) But that weakness is weakness of faith in the absolute efficacy of what you call “nature treatment”.
('34', 376, 4, 18, 896554) Even nature treatment is under exploration and is a growing thing.
('34', 376, 4, 19, 896621) It has not yet reached that perfect stage when we can ensure absolute results.
('34', 376, 4, 20, 896700) And if you have in mind something beyond nature treatment, that is faith in God and consequent absolute resignation; I own I have not yet
('34', 376, 5, 21, 896838) 1 In 1924; vide “Interview to V. S. Srinivas Sastri”, January 12, 1924.
('34', 377, 0, 1, 896910) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 377, 1, 2, 896952) attained that stage.
('34', 377, 1, 3, 896973) We can only come to it by painful effort.
('34', 377, 1, 4, 897015) We cannot put it on like a garment, nor can one be argued into that absolute consciousness of the presence within us of the “All Protecting Power.” I reason with you at length because I honour your sincerity, but I detect your growing impatience and intolerance which are calculated to hinder your progress as a nature cure advocate.
('34', 377, 1, 5, 897349) Do not again run away with the idea that all things that taste bitter are necessarily bad.
('34', 377, 1, 6, 897440) Bitterness, sweetness, etc., are relative terms.
('34', 377, 1, 7, 897489) Do you know that for some people sweetness in more nauseating than bitterness?
('34', 377, 1, 8, 897568) Will you not subscribe to the statement that a regular use of sugar is more harmful than a regular use of the bitter nim leaf?
('34', 377, 1, 9, 897695) And I am not at all sure that a person who will clean his teeth well with a brush made from nim tree will not keep his mouth in a nice and healthy condition.
('34', 377, 1, 10, 897853) Or will you prescribe for the him a tea spoonful of sugar powder to brush his teeth with?
('34', 377, 1, 11, 897943) Lastly on the principle of “physician, cure thyself” I must ask you to become strong and robust and to be an object lesson and advertisement for nature cure.
('34', 377, 1, 12, 898101) This letter is written not to discourage you from bombarding me.
('34', 377, 1, 13, 898166) Only you must be prepared to receive counter bombardments.
('34', 377, 1, 14, 898225) I wonder if you have received my letter written to you some days ago regarding those two friends who want to come to the Ashram and about the Ashram at Nellore.

('34', 379, 2, 3, 900165) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 11, 1926
('34', 379, 3, 4, 900199) DEAR FRIEND,
('34', 379, 4, 5, 900212) I have your letter.
('34', 379, 4, 6, 900232) I wish indeed that I could visit Europe and see so many of my unknown European friends.
('34', 379, 4, 7, 900320) But for the time being, I feel I must not leave India.
('34', 379, 4, 8, 900375) When I feel that the way is clear for me, I shall not hesitate to go to Europe.
('34', 379, 4, 9, 900455) Till that time we must meet one another through correspondence.
('34', 379, 4, 10, 900519) Nor will it be possible at the present moment to send Mr. Andrews or any other friends.
('34', 379, 4, 11, 900607) Mr. Andrews is away in South Africa.
('34', 379, 4, 12, 900644) He returns next month but the work here is already cut out 1 for him and it will keep him for several months.
('34', 379, 4, 13, 900754) There is no doubt about it that Tolstoy’s writings had a powerful effect on me.
('34', 379, 4, 14, 900834) He strengthened my love of non violence.
('34', 379, 4, 15, 900875) He enabled me to see things more clearly than I had done before.
('34', 379, 4, 16, 900940) His manner of putting this is all his own.
('34', 379, 4, 17, 900983) At the same time I know that there were fundamental differences betwen us and though they will abide, they are of little consequence compared with so many things for which I shall feel ever grateful to him.
('34', 379, 4, 18, 901190) My patriotism is patent enough; my love for India is ever growing but it is derived from my religion and is therefore in no sense exclusive.
('34', 379, 5, 19, 901331) Yours sincerely,

('34', 380, 1, 2, 901857) 121. LETTER TO T. K. MADHAVAN
('34', 380, 2, 3, 901887) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 11, 1926
('34', 380, 3, 4, 901921) MY DEAR MADHAVAN,
('34', 380, 4, 5, 901939) I have your letter.
('34', 380, 4, 6, 901959) I am glad of the settlement at Suchindram.
('34', 380, 4, 7, 902002) Dr. Naidoo did telegraph to me about it and I wrote him in reply that I would not notice it in the pages of Young India till I had a full text of the settlement.
('34', 380, 4, 8, 902164) I now see that it is all confidential.
('34', 380, 4, 9, 902203) I suppose therefore I must say nothing about it.
('34', 380, 4, 10, 902252) I do not at all like the idea of your resigning the membership as a protest against the Dewan’s ruling.
('34', 380, 4, 11, 902356) If every member who considers some ruling to be unjust were to resign there would be no member left.
('34', 380, 4, 12, 902457) We must not become judges in our own suits in the manner you have been.
('34', 380, 4, 13, 902529) How do you know your interpretation is right and the Dewan’s wrong?
('34', 380, 4, 14, 902597) Of course, I know nothing of the merits but I know the principle on which resignation by way of protest can be tendered.
('34', 380, 4, 15, 902718) The injustice of the ruling may be a cause for moving the adjournment of the house or making a simple statement and doing many other things, but surely not for resignation.
('34', 380, 4, 16, 902891) I would like every act of yours to be well considered and dignifed.
('34', 380, 4, 17, 902959) Your responsibility is much greater than an ordinary member’s because you are a representative of suppressed classes and unfortunately even an error of judgement on your part will be magnified whereas many stupidities on the part of ordinary members will be condoned.
('34', 380, 5, 18, 903227) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('34', 380, 5, 19, 903249) T. K. MADHAVAN TRIVANDRUM LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY MEMBER TRIVANDRUM

('34', 381, 7, 14, 904357) 123. MESSAGE TO “LIBERATOR”
('34', 381, 8, 15, 904385) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 11, 1926
('34', 381, 9, 16, 904419) The Liberator has an ambitious programme.
('34', 381, 9, 17, 904461) If it succeeds in any single one of the items enumerated in the notice before me it will have earned the name Swami Shraddhanandji has chosen to give his latest creation.
('34', 381, 9, 18, 904632) The notice before me rightly places emphasis upon the work of liberating the suppressed classes but there are still more numerous classes held under suppression by our insane desire to clothe ourselves in foreign cloth.
('34', 381, 9, 19, 904852) And they are not a fifth of the population of India but they are four fifths and if the Liberator will liberate villages from the temptation of cities, I venture to suggest that the task is an impossibility without the spinning wheel.
('34', 381, 10, 20, 905087) From a microfilm: S.N. 19357
('34', 382, 0, 1, 905116) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 383
('34', 382, 1, 2, 905161) 124. LETTER TO CHUNILAL
('34', 382, 2, 3, 905185) ASHRAM March 11, 1926
('34', 382, 3, 4, 905207) BHAI CHUNILALJI, I have your letter; I have also gone through your scheme.
('34', 382, 3, 5, 905282) I do not see any substance in it.
('34', 382, 3, 6, 905316) Cow slaughter goes on only in towns and there is only one way of checking it viz., to bid higher than the butchers at the sales.
('34', 382, 3, 7, 905445) This is possible only if we realize expense on all the cows that we recover, which again is not possible unless we take to dairy farming and a matter of religion start trading in hides, etc., from carcasses.
('34', 382, 3, 8, 905653) Since we escape beef eating by taking cow’s milk we regard it as sacred.
('34', 382, 3, 9, 905726) In the same way since we thereby save the cattle from being butchered we should regard it our sacred duty to utilize their carcasses for hides, bones, etc.
('34', 382, 3, 10, 905882) Now we find ourselves facing two things: one to seek the help of dairy and tanning technicians; second to disabuse the minds of the people and convince them that it is not only righteous but also religious to deal in hides, bones, etc., of dead animals.
('34', 382, 3, 11, 906136) If my view is correct, we may run our goshalas and pinjrapoles on the model of dairies and tanneries.
('34', 382, 3, 12, 906238) The work of cow protection has now become humdrum; the reason is that though we collect lacs of rupees under this pretext we have not been able in actual fact to save a single cow.
('34', 382, 3, 13, 906419) On the contrary, cow slaughter is on the increase since their prices have gone down owing to the lack of scientific knowledge of cow protection.
('34', 382, 3, 14, 906564) You may read this to the convention if you wish to.
('34', 382, 4, 15, 906616) From a photostat of the Hindi: S.N. 12398
('34', 382, 5, 16, 906658) 125. MESSAGE TO THE “HINDUSTANI” [March 12, 1926] Whoever asks me for a message for his paper makes a serious mistake if he is not a lover of the spinning wheel and khadi for I can think of nothing else much less can I write of anything else.
('34', 382, 5, 17, 906901) All around me I see distress, dissensions, and defeats and consequent dejection.
('34', 382, 5, 18, 906982) The one solace I find and therefore recommend is the spinning.
('34', 382, 5, 19, 907045) It gives me peace and it gives me joy in the thought that through it I establish an indissoluble bond between the lowliest in the land and myself.
('34', 382, 5, 20, 907192) Through the wheel and by my personal labour I add something to the desirable wealth of the country.
('34', 382, 5, 21, 907292) I contribute my
('34', 383, 0, 1, 907308) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 384
('34', 383, 1, 2, 907350) quota however humble towards clothing the naked through it and I invite the poorest in the land to labour for their living rather than beg for it.
('34', 383, 1, 3, 907497) The wheel stands above all discord and differences.
('34', 383, 1, 4, 907549) It is or should be the common property of every Indian.
('34', 383, 1, 5, 907605) If then the Hindustani stands for the political uplift of the country and its readers appreciate its object, they cannot do better than give to the spinning wheel at least half an hour per day and reject foreign or mill made cloth and use only hand spun and hand woven khaddar and thus distribute whatever they pay for khaddar amongst the poorest in the land.
('34', 383, 2, 6, 907965) From a microfilm: S.N. 19358
('34', 383, 3, 7, 907994) 126. LETTER TO SARDUL SINGH CAVEESAR
('34', 383, 4, 8, 908031) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 12, 1926
('34', 383, 5, 9, 908065) DEAR FRIEND, I have your two letters.
('34', 383, 5, 10, 908103) In answer to the general letter here is my article or message, whatever you may call it, for the Hindustani.
('34', 383, 5, 11, 908212) Your second letter makes painful reading.
('34', 383, 5, 12, 908254) There is nothing to be done but to let the fury work itself out and if we who know the evil of these dissensions and self seeking survive the shock all will be well.
('34', 383, 5, 13, 908420) They copy of your third letter is deeply interesting.
('34', 383, 5, 14, 908474) Your jail experience is very useful.
('34', 383, 5, 15, 908511) Your impressions of the things as you see them after your discharge from the prison provoke deep thinking.
('34', 383, 5, 16, 908618) I agree with you that non co operation has not failed and that we have not seen the last of it.
('34', 383, 5, 17, 908714) I agree also that swaraj is nearer than many may think.
('34', 383, 5, 18, 908770) The whole thing resolves itself into conversion of the educated classes.
('34', 383, 5, 19, 908843) This is bound to happen if some of us remain true as I know we will.
('34', 383, 5, 20, 908912) The attitude of a staunch non co operationist like myself towards the Swarajists requires fairly elaborate argument.
('34', 383, 5, 21, 909029) I shall not therefore deal with it here.
('34', 383, 5, 22, 909070) Put in one sentence, I can say that my attitude is based upon the hope that most is to be expected from them in the way of a forward policy.
('34', 383, 5, 23, 909211) It is quite true that the spinning wheel cannot be introduced as a subsidiary employment amongst those like the Punjab farmers whose time is almost fully occupied with more profitable concerns.
('34', 383, 5, 24, 909405) But the middle class who have always ample time to waste if they feel for their
('34', 384, 0, 1, 909485) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 385
('34', 384, 1, 2, 909530) country as a whole should think of the millions of paupers and for their sake wear khaddar and spin for half an hour per day by way of example and encouragement if nothing else.
('34', 384, 1, 3, 909708) Its greatest political value should not escape your keen penetrative intellect.
('34', 384, 1, 4, 909788) It lies in the fact that millions who are today leading less than animal life will have an honourable occupation and a means of livelihood.
('34', 384, 1, 5, 909928) Today they can be induced to do nothing whilst they are passive instruments of submission to any tyrant.
('34', 384, 1, 6, 910033) And why does khaddar lose its political importance because I invited Lord Reading to use it?
('34', 384, 1, 7, 910126) Will non co operation or civil disobedience lose their importance if I invited Lord Reading to take to either or both?
('34', 384, 1, 8, 910245) Lastly, civil revolution on a mass scale I hold to be an impossibility unless we acquire sufficient control and influence over the masses so as to ensure their abstention from disturbing the peace of the country by a violent demonstration.
('34', 384, 1, 9, 910485) Every time in the past when I have called off Civil Resistance upon outbreak of violence, you will find that Congressmen had a hand in it and that therefore it had a political value.
('34', 384, 1, 10, 910668) I should not hesitate to go forward even if there were a thousand eruptions in the country if I was sure that they had nothing to do with the political upheaval and that Congressmen had no hand in them directly or indirectly.
('34', 384, 1, 11, 910894) Regarding my health I am certainly weak but you have given me full credit by hoping that I know the value of my life much better than any of my admirers.
('34', 384, 1, 12, 911048) I assure you that I shall try to conserve it to the best of my ability but old age will overtake the most careful men.
('34', 384, 1, 13, 911167) On the whole I think that I am keeping very good health.
('34', 384, 2, 14, 911224) Yours sincerely, SARDAR SARDUL SINGH CAVEESAR LODGE LIBERTY RAM GALI, LAHORE
('34', 384, 3, 15, 911301) From a microfilm: S.N. 19358

('34', 388, 7, 13, 916179) 134. DISTRUST, OR LEGITIMATE PRECAUTION?
('34', 388, 8, 14, 916220) A lover of the spinning wheel writes in pain as follows: 1
('34', 388, 9, 15, 916279) Personally I think there was nothing in the suggestion made by the Association which could pain anyone.
('34', 388, 9, 16, 916383) The question how many members had asked for the return of their yarn is beside the point.
('34', 388, 9, 17, 916473) The pertinent question is whether anyone had done so.
('34', 388, 9, 18, 916527) The answer to this will be found in the note in Navajivan.
('34', 388, 9, 19, 916586) If the yarn is not returned, how can any member then supply the same yarn again?
('34', 388, 9, 20, 916667) If, however, we want to know reasons for distrust, there are plenty of them.
('34', 388, 9, 21, 916744) The same yarn was given by many members again and again to get themselves enrolled as members of the Congress.
('34', 388, 9, 22, 916855) Not only this, but even the Congress committee had openly used the same bundles over and over again.
('34', 388, 9, 23, 916956) Taking certain precautions, however, does not imply distrust and should certainly not be understood in that light.
('34', 388, 9, 24, 917071) It is not distrust of their children which prompts parents to place certain restrictions on them, but the knowledge of the laxity to which human nature is inclined in the absence of precautions.
('34', 388, 9, 25, 917266) Following the same principle, institutions frame rules in the nature of restraints on their members for their protection and men and women impose restrictions on themselves which we know as vows, to save themselves from yielding to temptations.
('34', 388, 9, 26, 917511) That people do not feel drawn to join the
('34', 388, 10, 27, 917553) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('34', 388, 10, 28, 917590) The correspondent had expressed his pain at the note “For Self spinners” in Navajivan, 7 3 1926; vide also “Notes”, March 4, 1926, for its Young India version.
('34', 389, 0, 1, 917750) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 390
('34', 389, 1, 2, 917792) Association, this indeed is the real trouble.
('34', 389, 1, 3, 917838) To say that they do not feel drawn is as much as to say that they do not believe, it can do any good.
('34', 389, 1, 4, 917940) Were it not so, why should not thousands and hundreds of thousands of men and women contribute yarn for the selfless yajna which the Spinners’Association has organized?
('34', 389, 1, 5, 918109) If, however, the people do not feel drawn to it, is that any reason why the organizers, too, should remain slack?
('34', 389, 1, 6, 918223) Should they cheapen membership of the Association?
('34', 389, 1, 7, 918274) We ought to get rid of the false notion that there is no gain in anything which does not fill one’s pocket.
('34', 389, 1, 8, 918382) If the members hold the Association in high esteem, sooner or later the world will accept it at their estimation, for the cause it serves is a sacred one.
('34', 389, 1, 9, 918537) Just as, to a mother, her child is more beautiful than other children, so should an institution be dear to those who run it and to its thoughtful members, even if the world thinks little of them and, therefore, of theirinstitution.
('34', 389, 1, 10, 918769) If the person who first repeated the name of Rama by way of prayer had felt ashamed of doing so or valued the name as merely helping him to get the pleasures of heaven, Rama would have been today no more than one among the thirty three crores of gods.
('34', 389, 1, 11, 919021) But that devotee of Rama linked the name with moksha, and the result has been that a good many people have attained moksha by uttering Rama’s name in prayer.
('34', 389, 1, 12, 919179) God is always at the service of his devotees; He is ever the Servant of His servants.
('34', 389, 1, 13, 919265) He justifies the devotee’s faith.
('34', 389, 1, 14, 919299) What is true about God and His devotees is also true about an institution and its organizers.
('34', 389, 1, 15, 919393) I hope, therefore, that my correspondent, a lover of the spinning wheel, will forget his pain and be happy instead, that he will look upon the Spinners’ Association as no ordinary institution and will be able to see, and will help others to see, that some effort is required to get back one’s yarn from the Association.
('34', 389, 1, 16, 919713) The value of his yarn, then, will rise in his eyes.
('34', 389, 1, 17, 919765) Those who have money, therefore, and wish, to their great credit, to wear cloth woven from yarn spun by themselves, should welcome the restrictions laid down by the Secretary of the Production Section.
('34', 389, 1, 18, 919967) I would, however, most certainly suggest that the members should welcome the yarn given to the All India Spinners’ Association being utilized for the benefit of the whole country.
('34', 389, 1, 19, 920147) It would be more commendable on their part to look upon such yarn as an offering in a yajna and not to wish to have it returned.

('34', 390, 1, 2, 920358) 135. HOW TO TACKLE EVIL CUSTOMS
('34', 390, 2, 3, 920390) A gentleman writes 1: The principle which we have applied to the system of British Government is applicable here also.
('34', 390, 2, 4, 920509) If the people co operate in order not to allow that system to continue, its foundation will go; it will crumble right today.
('34', 390, 2, 5, 920634) Similarly, if one wishing to end the empire of evil customs offers non co operation that empire will certainly crack up.
('34', 390, 2, 6, 920755) The question naturally arises as to what purpose will be served if only one person non co operates thus.
('34', 390, 2, 7, 920860) One answer to this is that he who launches non co operation wins and becomes free from faults, and the empire is weakened to the extent of the loss of his co operation.
('34', 390, 2, 8, 921029) A house does not collapse if a single brick is removed, but everyone realizes that from the day the brick came off the house has certainly begun to get weakened.
('34', 390, 2, 9, 921191) While it is difficult for the first brick to get loose, it is not so for the second brick to fall away or get removed.
('34', 390, 2, 10, 921310) Every reform in the world has been initiated by the efforts of one man.
('34', 390, 2, 11, 921382) Today even an appropriate atmosphere has been created in respect of evil customs like child marriage, etc.
('34', 390, 2, 12, 921489) Those who regard them as evil customs are lax only in regard to acting against them.
('34', 390, 2, 13, 921574) If we today try to take an opinion poll, the majority will hold that customs like child marriage and spending lavishly on marriages are evil and costly dresses of foreign material are reprehensible and evil.
('34', 390, 2, 14, 921782) Majority opinion can be had against other such evil customs.
('34', 390, 2, 15, 921843) Despite this, they have not disappeared because those who are oposed to them are truly speaking weak and, while they are brave in bragging, they are afraid to act.
('34', 390, 2, 16, 922007) That cowardice will disappear only when a number of people refrain from attending such functions even by putting themselves to trouble.
('34', 390, 3, 17, 922143) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 14 3 1926
('34', 390, 4, 18, 922180) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('34', 390, 4, 19, 922217) The correspondent had asked how one could rid one’s caste of customs like child marriage, use of costly foreign dresses and lavish expenditure on marriages.

('34', 396, 6, 13, 931063) 145. INTERVIEW TO KATHERINE MAYO 1
('34', 396, 7, 14, 931098) March 17, 1926
('34', 396, 8, 15, 931113) My message to America is simply the hum of this wheel.
('34', 396, 8, 16, 931168) Letters and newspaper cuttings I get from America show that one set of people over rates the results of Non violent Non co operation and the other set onto only under rates it but imputes all kinds of motives to those who are concerned with the movement.
('34', 396, 8, 17, 931423) Don’t exaggerate one way or the other.
('34', 396, 8, 18, 931462) If therefore some earnest Americans will study the movement impartially and patiently then it is likely that the United States may know something of the movement which I do consider to be unique although I am the author of it.
('34', 396, 8, 19, 931689) What I mean is that our movement is summed up in the spinning wheel with all its implica tions.
('34', 396, 8, 20, 931785) It is to me a substitute for gun powder.
('34', 396, 8, 21, 931826) For, it brings the message of self reliance and hope to the millions of India.
('34', 396, 8, 22, 931905) And when they are really awakened they would not need to lift their little finger in order to regain their freedom.
('34', 396, 8, 23, 932021) The messge of the spinning wheel is, really, to replace the spirit of exploitation by the spirit of service.
('34', 396, 8, 24, 932130) The dominant note in the West is the note of exploitation.
('34', 396, 8, 25, 932189) I have no desire
('34', 396, 9, 26, 932206) 1 Katherine Mayo in her letter dated 24 3 1926 says: “In accordance with the message received through your Secretary, I am mailing to you with this my transcribed notes of your statement on the 17th.
('34', 396, 9, 27, 932406) I have left deliberate spaces where there is some doubt of some exact words.
('34', 396, 9, 28, 932483) I shall of course greatly appreciate amplification or correction and return .
('34', 396, 9, 29, 932561) .” (S.N. 12449); vide also “Letter to Katherine Mayo”, 9 4 1926.
('34', 397, 0, 1, 932626) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 398
('34', 397, 1, 2, 932668) that my country should copy the spirit of that note.
('34', 397, 1, 3, 932721) (As to the effects of multiplication of means of travel and transportation:)All that is coming to smother us, not to deliver us.
('34', 397, 1, 4, 932850) I can only say I hope that we shall be spared that affliction.
('34', 397, 1, 5, 932913) But it may be we shall have to drink the bitter cup.
('34', 397, 1, 6, 932966) If we do not learn by the experience of the West, we may have to drink it.
('34', 397, 1, 7, 933041) But I am leaving no stone unturned to avoid that catastrophe.
('34', 397, 1, 8, 933103) The powers of the West, however much they have fought amongst themselves, have agreed on this: “Let us exploit the other Nations—Asia and Africa”.
('34', 397, 1, 9, 933250) They are keeping up to that agreement with extraordinary accuracy.
('34', 397, 1, 10, 933317) Suppose we reciprocate.
('34', 397, 1, 11, 933341) Suppose we learn all the tricks of our Western teachers—What will happen?
('34', 397, 1, 12, 933415) A mightier copy of what happened in August 1914. It will come if Europe and America continue to say: “We shall be top dogs and you others shall be bottom dogs” and we do not learn the message of non violence and understand that we have but to cease to buy from you what we do not need.
('34', 397, 1, 13, 933701) Therefore in spite of all evidence to the contrary, I do my best not to co operate with that spirit of exploitation.
('34', 397, 1, 14, 933818) I decline to copy even though I am but one in three hundred millions.
('34', 397, 1, 15, 933888) At least I shall die with the satisfaction of knowing I die in doing what my consience directs.
('34', 397, 1, 16, 933984) We can be exploited only with our own consent, whether forced or willing, conscious or unconscious, and only if we buy all sorts of attrac tive things that Europe and America produce.
('34', 397, 1, 17, 934168) Mainly clothing.
('34', 397, 1, 18, 934185) This we can avoid because we have not yet quite lost the cunning of our hands.
('34', 397, 1, 19, 934264) The task of so providing for our needs will prove no burden but can be met just as we eat and drink—a little at a time in the course of each day, during spare hours.
('34', 397, 1, 20, 934430) There are many things today for which I am depen dent on the West.
('34', 397, 1, 21, 934497) When I am sure that I take only that is better done there and what is beneficent to me, it will be an honourable, free and mutually advantageous bargain.
('34', 397, 1, 22, 934651) But what is now done is a bargain des tructive to both sides.
('34', 397, 1, 23, 934713) For exploitation is as bad for one as for the other.
('34', 397, 1, 24, 934766) I want this country to be spared Dyerism.
('34', 397, 1, 25, 934808) That is, I do not want my country, when it has the power, to resort to frightfulness in order to impose her custom on others.
('34', 397, 1, 26, 934934) Very often we have to learn by hard experience, but if I believe that every one of us had to go in a vicious circle and do just what every other has done, I should know that no progress is possible and should preach the doctrine of suicide.
('34', 397, 1, 27, 935175) But we hope, and train our children in the hope, that they will avoid the
('34', 398, 0, 1, 935249) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 399
('34', 398, 1, 2, 935294) mistakes of their fathers.
('34', 398, 1, 3, 935321) Indeed I see sings, very faint, but unmistakable, of a better day in the West.
('34', 398, 1, 4, 935400) A tremendous movement is going on in the West today to retrace steps.
('34', 398, 1, 5, 935470) There is much progress in the thought world, although little is as yet translated into action.

('34', 398, 1, 8, 935804) Those who see the poverty of India and feel grieved should probe under the surface and find its real cause.
('34', 398, 1, 9, 935912) It is not as if it were slowly decreasing.
('34', 398, 1, 10, 935955) It is growing, in spite of hospitals, schools, metalled roads and railways.
('34', 398, 1, 11, 936031) In spite of all these you find the people are being ground down as between two millstones.
('34', 398, 1, 12, 936122) They live in enforced idleness.
('34', 398, 1, 13, 936154) A century ago every cottage was able to replenish its resources by means of the spinning wheel.
('34', 398, 1, 14, 936250) Now every farmer, scratching the earth only a few inches deep with the wooden plough, works in the season of cultivation.
('34', 398, 1, 15, 936372) But he cannot do much work in the other seasons of the year.
('34', 398, 1, 16, 936433) What are he, his children and his women then to do?
('34', 398, 1, 17, 936485) The women sat at the wheel in the old days and sang something not obscene—not trash—but a song to the Maker of us all.
('34', 398, 1, 18, 936604) The children imbibed it and so this custom was handed down and the children had it, although they were without polish or literary education.
('34', 398, 1, 19, 936745) But now it has all but died away.
('34', 398, 1, 20, 936779) The mother is groaning under poverty, her spirit is darkened.
('34', 398, 1, 21, 936841) She has no milk.
('34', 398, 1, 22, 936858) As soon as the child is weaned, she has only gruel to give it, that ruins the intestines.
('34', 398, 1, 23, 936948) What am I to ask these millions to do?
('34', 398, 1, 24, 936987) To migrate from their farms?
('34', 398, 1, 25, 937016) To kill off their babies?

('34', 398, 1, 27, 937108) I take to them the gospel of hope—the spinning wheel—saying, “I do this thing myself, side by side with you, and I give you coppers for your yarn.
('34', 398, 1, 28, 937255) I take your yarn that you have spun in your own place, in your own time, at your own sweet will.” She [the mother] listens with a little bit of hope in her eyes.
('34', 398, 1, 29, 937417) At the end of five weeks during which she has had help and co operation regularly, I find light in her eyes.
('34', 398, 1, 30, 937526) “Now”, she says, “I shall be able to get milk for my baby”.

('34', 398, 1, 32, 937660) Multiply that scene by three hundred millions and you have a fair picture of what I am hoping for.

('34', 399, 1, 2, 937863) Hunter, first showed that the poverty of the masses is growing rather than decreasing.

('34', 405, 12, 18, 951165) 152. NOTES
('34', 405, 13, 19, 951176) THE NATIONAL WEEK
('34', 405, 14, 20, 951194) The 6th and the 13th of April are never to be forgotten days in our national life.
('34', 405, 14, 21, 951277) The 6th of April, 1919 witnessed an unparalleled demonstration in which Hindus, Mussalmans and others joined freely.
('34', 405, 14, 22, 951394) It was too a day of freedom for the suppressed classes.
('34', 405, 14, 23, 951450) That day laid the foundation for true swadeshi.
('34', 405, 14, 24, 951498) And it was the day when the whole country offered civil disobedience.
('34', 405, 14, 25, 951568) The spirit of mass freedom and mass resistance was abroad.
('34', 406, 0, 1, 951627) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 407
('34', 406, 1, 2, 951672) The 13th April witnessed the Jallianwala massacre in which Hindu, Mussalman and Sikh blood mingled in one scarlet stream.
('34', 406, 1, 3, 951794) A dungheap was turned in a day into a place of political pilgrimage for all India.
('34', 406, 1, 4, 951877) It will remain that till India lives.
('34', 406, 1, 5, 951915) Since that day many events have happened.
('34', 406, 1, 6, 951957) Hope rose high in 1921 to be dashed seemingly to pieces the very moment it rose to the highest point.
('34', 406, 1, 7, 952059) The tide has appeared to be ebbing ever since.
('34', 406, 1, 8, 952106) We are passing through midnight gloom.
('34', 406, 1, 9, 952145) Possibly we have not yet seen the worst.
('34', 406, 1, 10, 952186) But that sacred week is still our hope and therefore we must celebrate it even though we are rent in twain and the Government safely flouts national demands, be they ever so pressing and withal reasonable.
('34', 406, 2, 11, 952392) There is no perpetual night on God’s earth.
('34', 406, 2, 12, 952436) Ours too will have its ending.
('34', 406, 2, 13, 952467) Only we must work for it.
('34', 406, 2, 14, 952493) How to celebrate the week then?
('34', 406, 2, 15, 952525) Not by hartal.
('34', 406, 2, 16, 952540) Not yet by civil disobedience.
('34', 406, 2, 17, 952571) We cannot proclaim or celebrate the unity of Hindus and non Hindus, for we Hindus and Mussalmans distrust one another and seek to consolidate our strength and power rather through the Government favour than through mutual forbearance and help.
('34', 406, 2, 18, 952815) That question must therefore for the time being be left to work itself out.
('34', 406, 2, 19, 952891) Untouchability is slowly but surely dying.
('34', 406, 2, 20, 952934) Khaddar alone lends itself to mass demonstration and mass effort.
('34', 406, 2, 21, 953000) It is the platform on which all can work hand in hand.
('34', 406, 2, 22, 953055) Sales can be organized.
('34', 406, 2, 23, 953079) Voluntary spinning can be pushed.
('34', 406, 2, 24, 953113) Collections can be made for the All India Das Memorial Fund whose sole object is the promotion of the spinning wheel and khaddar.
('34', 406, 2, 25, 953243) There are no doubt many other ways of celebrating the national week.
('34', 406, 2, 26, 953312) It is open to local workers to devise various ways.
('34', 406, 2, 27, 953364) I can only think of things in which millions can take part, which remind us of those seven days and which can promote swaraj.
('34', 406, 2, 28, 953490) I can think of nothing else that satisfies all the conditions so well as the spinning whell.
('34', 406, 3, 29, 953583) Oh, that we can do one thing truly and well!
('34', 406, 3, 30, 953628) It will rstore lost self confidence and it will give us a strength that can carry all before it.
('34', 406, 3, 31, 953725) The spinning wheel is the one thing which men, women, boys and girls of all classes and religions can work.
('34', 406, 3, 32, 953833) It is the one thing that can establish a link between the rich and the poor and it is the one thing that can bring a ray of sunshine into the dark and dilapidated dungeon of the half starved peasantry.
('34', 406, 3, 33, 954035) Let those who have faith in the wheel work to make khaddar more popular during the national week.

('34', 407, 1, 2, 954175) SPINNING IN MUNICIPAL SCHOOLS
('34', 407, 2, 3, 954205) In reply to circular letter of the Joint Secretary of the All India Spinners’ Association asking various Municipalities and District Boards to supply him with the progress made by hand spinning in their schools, three letters have been so far received.
('34', 407, 2, 4, 954458) One is from the Chairman, School Board, Ahmedabad Municipality.
('34', 407, 2, 5, 954522) It is stated that:
('34', 407, 3, 6, 954541) Two experts to train up spinning teachers for Municipal Girls’ Schools were employed last year.
('34', 407, 3, 7, 954637) The teachers underwent training for 6 months and it is now intended to introduce spinning as a compulsory subject in the Municipal Girls’ School.
('34', 407, 3, 8, 954783) The Vice Chairman of the Shahabad District Board says that eight primary schools had spinning introduced in 1925. Eight teachers of selected schools had special training in spinning and five wheels were supplied to each school.
('34', 407, 3, 9, 955011) 139 boys of ages varying from 10 to 15 are now receiving instruction.
('34', 407, 3, 10, 955081) The letter adds that “the work has been hitherto poor but better results are expected because the work has now become more systematized”.
('34', 407, 3, 11, 955219) The Board had spent up to 31st January last Rs. 274 out of Rs. 1,000 specially granted.
('34', 407, 3, 12, 955307) According to the letter of the District Board of Basti:
('34', 407, 4, 13, 955363) 15 boys spin regularly.
('34', 407, 4, 14, 955387) 15 charkhas are at work.
('34', 407, 4, 15, 955412) The average daily output is only one chatak (5 tolas); the yarn has been used for weaving daris 1; only two have been completed and they are used in the school.
('34', 407, 4, 16, 955573) Monthly expense is Rs. 20, being the salary of the teacher.
('34', 407, 4, 17, 955633) The materials have cost up to now Rs. 81 2 0. I trust that the other school Boards, if they have introduced hand spinning in their curricula, will furnish information about whatever progress spinning might have made in their schools.
('34', 407, 4, 18, 955867) I have already remarked in these pages that experience has shown that for shcool spinning, the takli is the most convenient and the most profitable implement for spinning.
('34', 407, 4, 19, 956039) The teachers, for one thing, are able to control the takli spinning of hundreds of boys and girls at a time.
('34', 407, 4, 20, 956148) This is impossible with the spinning wheel.
('34', 407, 5, 21, 956192) AN INGENIOUS SUGGESTION
('34', 407, 6, 22, 956216) I have before me a letter from a satyagrahi prisoner who had over four years’ experience of prison life.
('34', 407, 6, 23, 956321) On his discharge I asked him to give me his experiences.
('34', 407, 6, 24, 956378) In some respects his description is original.
('34', 407, 6, 25, 956424) Instead of telling me all about the tyranny of the authorities
('34', 407, 7, 26, 956487) 1 Carpets
('34', 408, 0, 1, 956497) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 409
('34', 408, 1, 2, 956542) and the hardships of jail life he has given me the results of his own introspection.
('34', 408, 1, 3, 956627) I cull from his letter the following two paragraphs:
('34', 408, 2, 4, 956680) Often I think that every student after he finishes his studies should perforce be sent to jail for six months at least.
('34', 408, 2, 5, 956800) This, in my opinion, would do greater good to our boys than the Continental tour does to English boys.
('34', 408, 2, 6, 956903) Voluntary tapasya is very difficult these days, but we can have easily almost all the fruits of tapasya for our boys if we put them in jail just before they enter life.
('34', 408, 2, 7, 957072) During six months, shut out from the world out side, they will be able to digest what they have acquired in their schools and colleges and they will have some quiet to think seriously what use they should make of their attainments.
('34', 408, 2, 8, 957304) It is not given to everybody outside the jail to think seriously; most of us live from hand to mouth as regards thought and action; our work is mostly based on impulse rather than thought.
('34', 408, 2, 9, 957493) Why not let each of us go every year to jail, say for a month, and review the work done during the past year and prospect of work for the ensuing year?
('34', 408, 3, 10, 957645) Another aspect of the jail life that drew my special attention was the way in which prisoners could live so cleanly, so economically, and so simply.
('34', 408, 3, 11, 957794) But for corruption and the forced nature of confinement in prisons, these institutions could stand as models for our village and town folk who have to live on small wages.
('34', 408, 4, 12, 957966) Though there is from my point of view much left to be done in respect of sanitation in the prisons of India, I can corroborate the description given by my correspondent.
('34', 408, 4, 13, 958136) Prison sanitation is certainly superior to the sanitation of our villages.
('34', 408, 4, 14, 958211) In fact, it is want of sanitation which one regretfully observes in the villages, no matter in what part one visits them.
('34', 408, 4, 15, 958333) Simialarly, simplicity of the jail dietary is also commendable and if the middle classes were to simplify their diet there will be an enormous saving in their wealth and heatlh.
('34', 408, 5, 16, 958511) The suggestion that the youth of the country should pass some time in the jails before embarking upon life and after finishing their scholastic career is certainly attractive, but how is it to be carried out?
('34', 408, 5, 17, 958720) Unless a revival of civil disobedience gives the students a chance of seeking imprisonment, the only way for them to reproduce prison discipline is to bury themselves for a season at least in villages and there live the simple life of the villages minus their insanitation.
('34', 408, 5, 18, 958994) They can become their own scavengers, as to an extent every prisoner must be.
('34', 409, 0, 1, 959072) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 410
('34', 409, 1, 2, 959114) NOT DESPONDENT I would also share with the reader my correspondent’s optimism in giving me his reflections upon the present condition of political India.
('34', 409, 1, 3, 959268) He says:
('34', 409, 2, 4, 959277) As regards “the things as I see them now”, I am glad I do not feel as much disappointed as many of my friends do.
('34', 409, 2, 5, 959391) I do not feel that non co operation has failed or that we have seen its last.
('34', 409, 2, 6, 959469) I still believe that India will get swaraj in the near future and that the final victory is to be achieved through civil revolution.
('34', 409, 2, 7, 959602) We may have to change our programme, but the salvation is to come through that source alone.
('34', 409, 2, 8, 959695) I believe that the victory is to come to us in the near future.
('34', 409, 2, 9, 959759) By near future, I do not mean one year, nor even five years, but certainly less than ten years, because, I find the heart of the people still sound.
('34', 409, 2, 10, 959908) What is wrong is with those who have to give lead to the people.
('34', 409, 2, 11, 959973) It is the educated classes to whom the common people generally look for guidance who have gone astray.
('34', 409, 2, 12, 960076) If they could again realize their responsibilities, the masses would follow their footsteps as surely as the magnet follows the poles.
('34', 409, 2, 13, 960211) How nice it would be if all non co operators were to share this correspondent’s faith in non co operation and civil disobedience!
('34', 409, 2, 14, 960341) He who runs may see that though non co operation has not brought us swaraj in the tangible sense that the people undestand, it has revolutionized our political aspect; has brought into being mass consciousness which in my opinion nothing else could have done.
('34', 409, 2, 15, 960601) And there is no doubt about it that whenever freedom comes, it will come through some application of non co operation including civil disobedience.
('34', 409, 2, 16, 960749) For, inspite of whatever may be said to the contrary, the method of violence has no following worth the name especially among the masses, and no method for the attainment of swaraj can possibly succeed unless the masses also adopt it.
('34', 409, 2, 17, 960984) If the definiton of swaraj includes the freedom not of a certain number of individuals or certain classes but of the whole of the masses of India, only non co operation and all that it means can regulate that mass consciousness which is absolutely necessary for democratic swaraj.
('34', 409, 2, 18, 961265) Only non violent, and therefore constructive, methods will weld the masses together and fire them with a national purpose and give them the desire and ability to achieve and defend national freedom.
('34', 409, 3, 19, 961464) ON KHADDAR The correspondent favours me with his views on khaddar also.
('34', 409, 3, 20, 961536) He says:
('34', 409, 4, 21, 961545) I attach great importance to charkha and khaddar, but sorry I do not feel
('34', 410, 0, 1, 961619) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 411
('34', 410, 1, 2, 961664) very hopeful about them.
('34', 410, 1, 3, 961689) And while I attach much importance to khaddar I do not attach as much importance to its political value as people generally used to do in 1921. I do not believe that English people rule India only in the interests of Lancashire.
('34', 410, 1, 4, 961918) Other considerations play an equally important part.
('34', 410, 1, 5, 961971) Your invitation to Lord Reading to use khaddar has still further reduced what little political value this item of the non co operation programme had before.
('34', 410, 1, 6, 962128) It is well that the correspondent grants the economic value of khaddar.
('34', 410, 1, 7, 962200) I venture to suggest to him and to those who think with him that its political value springs from its economic value.
('34', 410, 1, 8, 962318) A starving man thinks first of satisfying his hunger before anything else.
('34', 410, 1, 9, 962393) The celebrated incident of a disciplined sage like Vishwamitra, whose austerities have hardly been matched, stooping even to steal forbidden food when he was famishing, shows the stress under which a starving man labours.
('34', 410, 1, 10, 962615) He will sell his liberty and all for the sake of getting a morsel of food.
('34', 410, 1, 11, 962690) Sailors struggling for want of food in mid ocean have been known to resort to cannibalism in order to satisfy their hunger.
('34', 410, 1, 12, 962814) Such is the position of millions of the people of India.
('34', 410, 1, 13, 962871) For them liberty, God, and all such words are merely letters put together without the slightest meaning.
('34', 410, 1, 14, 962976) They jar upon them.
('34', 410, 1, 15, 962996) They will extend a welcome to any person who comes to them with a morsel of food.
('34', 410, 1, 16, 963078) And if we want to give these people a sense of freedom we shall have to provide them with work which they can easily do in their desolate homes and which would give them at least the barest living.
('34', 410, 1, 17, 963276) This can only be done by the spinning wheel.
('34', 410, 1, 18, 963321) And when they have become self reliant and are able to support themselves, we are in a position to talk to them about freedem, about Congress etc.
('34', 410, 1, 19, 963468) Those therefore, who bring them work and means of getting a crust of bread will be their deliverers and will be also the people who will make them hunger for liberty.
('34', 410, 1, 20, 963635) Hence the political value of the spinning wheel, apart from its further abilityto displace foreign cloth and thus remove the greatest temptation in the way of Englishmen to hold India even at the risk of having to repeat the Jallianwala massacre times without number.
('34', 410, 1, 21, 963903) And why should khaddar lose its political value because I invite Lord Reading to adopt it?
('34', 410, 1, 22, 963994) Surely we have no quarrel with Englishmen as such.
('34', 410, 1, 23, 964045) The method of non co operation is a method of conversion of Englishmen to thinking in terms of India.
('34', 410, 1, 24, 964147) If they will respond to our dearest aspirations; if they will make common cause with us and wear khaddar; co operate with us in making India dry and reducing the frightful military expenditure and are prepared to remain in India not on the strength of their bayonets but on that of our goodwill; will
('34', 411, 0, 1, 964448) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 412
('34', 411, 1, 2, 964490) they not be welcome co workers in common cause?
('34', 411, 1, 3, 964538) In my opinion the invitation to Englishmen to adopt khaddar and the spinning wheel enhances their political value, while at the same time it robs them of the slightest trace of suspicion that there is in them any antagonism to Englishmen as such.
