('34', 411, 6, 11, 965108) The office bearers of the Glasgow Indian Union have circulated a letter bringing to light the disabilities that have been imposed upon certain Indian residents in Glasgow.
('34', 411, 6, 12, 965280) I take the following from the letter:
('34', 411, 7, 13, 965318) The Home Secretary on 18th March, 1925, issued the order a copy of which is enclosed, directing the registration of “Alien Seamen”.
('34', 411, 7, 14, 965450) This order has been made applicable to Glasgow and District in Janu ary of this year and the Police authorities here acting under the instruction of the Home Office have arbitrarily registered as Aliens the individuals whose names and addresses are given in the accompanying list.
('34', 411, 7, 15, 965731) These individuals have all been in this country for periods of from three to fourteen years; they were born in India— majority in the Punjab—and are British subjects.
('34', 411, 7, 16, 965898) Many of them were employed here during the War and are still employed as laboureres, others as pedlars and in isolated cases as seamen.
('34', 411, 7, 17, 966034) They have all been quite peaceful and law abiding citizens.
('34', 411, 7, 18, 966094) It is the intention of the Home Secretary to register these men as “Alien Seamen” which they certainly are not, and it is very significant that in the identity books that have been issued to them their nationality and birth place are left blank.
('34', 411, 7, 19, 966340) We, Indians, consider that this action of the Home Office is the culmination of general policy of systematic exclusion of Indians which has developed in recent years.
('34', 411, 7, 20, 966507) All Indians have on the ground of their nationality been refused admission to certain picture houses and some other

('34', 415, 4, 7, 973675) 157. LETTER TO KISHORELAL MASHRUWALA ASHRAM, March 18, 1926
('34', 415, 5, 8, 973735) KISHORELAL,
('34', 415, 6, 9, 973747) I have both your letters.
('34', 415, 6, 10, 973773) I wanted to write to you when I got the second.
('34', 415, 6, 11, 973821) I have been worried since you wrote to me about the pinjrapole.
('34', 415, 6, 12, 973885) It is my constant desire that you should reach Deolali soon.
('34', 415, 6, 13, 973946) I had promptly gone through the article which you had left for me regarding the question of monkeys.
('34', 415, 6, 14, 974047) In the article, as in your letter, you have offered no final solution of the problem.
('34', 415, 6, 15, 974133) What we want now is a solution which is perfectly consistent with religion.
('34', 415, 6, 16, 974209) Of course it will be implemented in course of time.
('34', 415, 6, 17, 974261) How can we get over age old sentiments unless we have very grave reasons?
('34', 415, 6, 18, 974335) But we face now only the religious aspect of the problem.
('34', 415, 6, 19, 974393) Let us not forget we have been ourselves promo ting the multiplication of monkeys and now we are a passive witness to their destruction; (1) Englishmen and others destroying the monkeys that visit their neighbourhood, and (2) the export to foreign countries of live specimens for experiments while yet alive.
('34', 415, 6, 20, 974702) And the third inconsistency is that we feel a secret joy at the fall in their number due to these two causes.
('34', 415, 6, 21, 974812) What can we do in such circumstances?
('34', 415, 6, 22, 974850) If we can free ourselves from the sin of destroying a few monkeys, it is perhaps our duty to do so; or as members of society, it may be our duty to remain passive witnesses to it.

('34', 419, 2, 3, 980339) ASHRAM, March 19, 1926
('34', 419, 3, 4, 980362) BHAI GIRDHARLAL,
('34', 419, 4, 5, 980379) I have your letter.
('34', 419, 4, 6, 980399) One consolation is that there are at this very moment quite a few people in the world who are similarly situated.
('34', 419, 4, 7, 980513) (1) It is our environment rather than yourself that is to blame for your inability to put your spare time to good use.
('34', 419, 4, 8, 980632) You must not resign yourself to it thinking it God’s will.
('34', 419, 4, 9, 980691) On the contrary, you should cultivate the strength to stand against the environment.
('34', 419, 4, 10, 980776) (2) I do not see anything wrong in your being happy with Ramanama instead of abandoning yourself to futile laments whenever you are helpless.
('34', 419, 4, 11, 980918) (3) There is nothing to regret if you cannot earn money.
('34', 419, 4, 12, 980975) But if you fail to uphold your dharma that is a matter of regret; whether or not it is upheld is for you to decide.
('34', 419, 5, 13, 981091) (4) It is a serious blunder to believe that nocturnal discharge is more harmful than intercourse.
('34', 419, 5, 14, 981189) Both cause debility and often the latter causes more.
('34', 419, 5, 15, 981243) But we fail to see the harm in intercourse by reason of conventional approval, and since a night discharge upsets the mind we tend to magnify the harm.
('34', 419, 5, 16, 981395) I suppose you know that in spite of having sexual intercourse one may suffer from nocturnal discharge.
('34', 419, 5, 17, 981498) Therefore if you admit the merit of brahmacharya and intend to practise it, stick to it without grieving over discharges which occur in spite of your continued efforts to contrary.
('34', 419, 5, 18, 981679) After you have practi sed brahmacharya for some time you will gain control over your mind.
('34', 419, 5, 19, 981770) How long it will take, one cannot say, because everyone does not take the same time; one takes more or less time according to one’s capacity.
('34', 419, 5, 20, 981912) Some never obtain control over their thoughts; yet they get the certain fruit of brahmacharya observed in practice, so that they come to possess a physique which can check the mind with ease.
('34', 419, 6, 21, 982104) (5) In my opinion husband and wife do not have to obtain each other’s consent for practising brahmacharya.
('34', 419, 6, 22, 982211) It is desirable if both co operate with each other to attain it, it is quite proper also to seek such co operation.
('34', 419, 6, 23, 982327) But whether or not one gets the other’s consent, one who desires it should practise it and benefit from it.

('34', 426, 4, 14, 994513) 171. AN ANGUISHED CHARKHA DEVOTEE
('34', 426, 5, 15, 994547) The following letter in reply to the article “Distrust, or Legitimate Precaution?” 3 demonstrates how hard it is to follow dharma: 4
('34', 426, 6, 16, 994680) I have already accepted the contention that it would be best not to return the yarn once deposited with the Spinners’ Association, and it is desirable that no one should ask his yarn to be returned.
('34', 426, 6, 17, 994879) But human nature is not cast in one pattern.
('34', 426, 6, 18, 994924) And so it becomes necessary to make some concessions so long as they do not violate the principle and that is what has happened in this case.
('34', 426, 6, 19, 995066) The Rentia Premi’s 5 views on the Spinners’ Association were not ignored by me.
('34', 426, 6, 20, 995146) My only intention was to draw attention to the difficulties arising from what a simple reading of his article seemed to suggest.
('34', 426, 6, 21, 995275) The Spinners’ Association is, and is also not, an institution dedicated to a practical purpose.
('34', 426, 6, 22, 995371) All may not accept it as a door leading to moksha; in fact, very few persons look upon it in that light.
('34', 426, 7, 23, 995476) 1 Asterisks as in the source 2 The second book of the Ramayana 3 Dated 14 3 1926 4 The letter is not reproduced here.
('34', 426, 7, 24, 995594) The correspondent was not convinced by Gandhiji’s arguments in the article and had stated that the undesirable practices against which the Spinners’ Association was obliged to take precautions were the consequences of spinning having been made a part of politics through the franchise clause of the Congress.
('34', 426, 7, 25, 995903) 5 A lover of the spinning wheel
('34', 427, 0, 1, 995935) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 428
('34', 427, 1, 2, 995977) Most people accept khadi on economic grounds and join the Spinners’ Association because they think that it can render good help in promo ting the cause of khadi.
('34', 427, 1, 3, 996139) It is the duty of the organizers to take proper precautions in regard to such members.
('34', 427, 1, 4, 996226) The rules for general appli cation should be judged not from the point of view of people who maintain the highest standard but from that of ordinary men and women.
('34', 427, 1, 5, 996390) My remarks about “temptation” were intended to suggest that everyone should feel inspired to join institutions devoted wholly to public service.
('34', 427, 1, 6, 996535) The two suggestions made by the Rentia Premi for making the Spinners’ Association a success are certainly very good.
('34', 427, 1, 7, 996652) If all spin with the same diligence as he does and exert themselves to make it 100 per cent successful, the cause of khadi will make great strides.
('34', 427, 1, 8, 996800) Likewise, it is also beyond doubt that if the Spinners’ Association exercises the same care in rating, collecting and storing yarn which a jeweller does in rating and storing a diamond received by him, the khadi movement will make great progress.

('34', 427, 6, 14, 997430) 173. BENGAL’S DISTINCTION
('34', 427, 7, 15, 997456) Bengal is demonstrating her superiority over other provinces in the field of khadi as she has been doing in many other fields.
('34', 427, 7, 16, 997583) Other provinces manufacture quite a good quantity of khadi; for the sale of their products, however, they depend not on themselves but mostly on demands from outside.
('34', 427, 7, 17, 997750) Bengal, on the other hand, has from the very beginning preferred to follow the path of self reliance.
('34', 427, 7, 18, 997852) We see this practice not in one but in all khadi institutions.
('34', 427, 7, 19, 997915) Bengal has not sent out a single yard of khadi for sale.
('34', 427, 7, 20, 997972) This example of Bengal deserves to be pondered over by
('34', 428, 0, 1, 998027) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 429
('34', 428, 1, 2, 998072) institutions in other provinces.
('34', 428, 1, 3, 998105) There is no province as yet which produces enough khadi for its needs and, after it is sold, has still some surplus which it sends to other provinces.
('34', 428, 1, 4, 998256) Before we reach that stage, we shall have to manufacture khadi worth crores of rupees annually.
('34', 428, 1, 5, 998352) Since we wish to make the use of khadi universal, our aim should be to see that as a rule all the khadi produced is consumed locally.
('34', 428, 1, 6, 998486) The efforts we make in this direction will hasten the universal adoption of khadi.
('34', 428, 1, 7, 998569) An exception can be made to this rule only in favour of those provinces in which it is difficult to produce khadi, but there will be hardly any such province.
('34', 428, 1, 8, 998728) The chief khadi producing regions are Tamil Nad, Andhra Pradesh, Punjab and Bihar.
('34', 428, 1, 9, 998811) The bodies [connected with the manufacture of khadi] in these provinces depend very much on what they are able to send to other provinces.
('34', 428, 1, 10, 998950) It is necessary to increase the local demands in all these regions.
('34', 428, 1, 11, 999018) Other provinces which may find it necessary to obtain khadi from these centres will have no difficulty in getting their requirements, but efforts by provincial bodies to increase the local sale of khadi will result in a great increase in the production of khadi and in considerable saving in costs.
('34', 428, 1, 12, 999317) Bengal is showing us the way.
('34', 428, 1, 13, 999347) First, the Khadi Pratishthan took a bold step and had a fairly large quantity of khadi produced.
('34', 428, 1, 14, 999444) It is now carrying on propaganda work, with the help of magic lanterns and other aids, to sell that khadi.
('34', 428, 1, 15, 999551) It also intends to try to raise the necessary funds for this purpose from within Bengal.
('34', 428, 1, 16, 999640) Actually, the Pratishthan started its work with money obtained from local sources.
('34', 428, 1, 17, 999723) If workers keep these three principles in view—local manufacture, local consumption and local help—in carrying on khadi work, khadi will spread rapidly and the costs will be kept down.
('34', 428, 1, 18, 999908) In this, really, consists the value of khadi, its deeper significance.
('34', 428, 1, 19, 999979) The basis of the movement is the belief that khadi meets the needs of the people.
('34', 428, 1, 20, 1000061) We should prove the truth of this at every step.
('34', 428, 1, 21, 1000110) If, in addition, we also obtain monetary help locally, the hundreds of thousands of one anna coins received as contribution will add up to many lakhs of rupees.
('34', 428, 1, 22, 1000271) A crore of rupees donated by one person will not probably benefit the movement as much as contributions received in this manner.
('34', 428, 1, 23, 1000400) It will take time to reach this ideal and there will also be difficulties in the way; if we lose sight of the ideal, however, the khadi movement will fail in its original purpose.
('34', 428, 1, 24, 1000580) In order that it should become a pure source of help for the poor, it is necessary to pay increasing attention to the three principles mentioned above.
('34', 428, 1, 25, 1000732) Till the time that we can follow them, we shall have to adopt other measures,
('34', 429, 0, 1, 1000810) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 430
('34', 429, 1, 2, 1000852) accept help from outside sources and the provinces will have to seek and give mutual co operation.
('34', 429, 1, 3, 1000951) If, however, the khadi workers forget to keep their eyes fixed on our light house, they will meet the fate of careless sailors.
('34', 429, 1, 4, 1001079) The example of Bengal reminds us of this lesson.
('34', 429, 2, 5, 1001128) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 21 3 1926
('34', 429, 3, 6, 1001165) 174. SOCIAL REFORM
('34', 429, 4, 7, 1001184) Shri Jamnalalji’s speech as President of the Agrawal Mahasabha deserves to be read and pondered over.
('34', 429, 4, 8, 1001286) He has displayed the greatest freedom and courage in it.
('34', 429, 4, 9, 1001343) If the Marwari community can follow Shri Jamnalalji’s advice, it will lead in effecting essential social reforms as it leads in acquiring wealth.
('34', 429, 4, 10, 1001489) The reforms advocated by Shri Jamnalalji are equally necessary for the other castes among Hindus all over the country.
('34', 429, 4, 11, 1001608) Abuse of the pure weapon of boycott, dishonest and anti national commercial practices, love of pleasure among the rich, adoption of western ways by women, child marriages, heavy burden of marriage expenses, proliferation of sub castes, neglect of children’s education, these and other evils prevail in some measure among Hindus everywhere.
('34', 429, 4, 12, 1001948) They not only sap our vitality, but obstruct our progress towards swaraj.
('34', 429, 4, 13, 1002022) In his speech, Jamnalalji laid the fullest stress on the eradication of these evils as also on the removal of untouchability, on khadi and on improving the methods we adopt for protecting the cow.
('34', 429, 4, 14, 1002219) Let us all hope that the Agrawal members present at the meeting will act on Jamnalalji’s suggestions and facilitate the task of other Hindu communities.
('34', 429, 5, 15, 1002372) [From Gujarai] Navajivan, 21 3 1926

('34', 435, 5, 9, 1011591) There is a famous classical saying which has now become a proverb that the man “that hath no music in himself” is either an ascetic or a beast.
('34', 435, 5, 10, 1011735) We are far from being ascetics, and to the extent that we are devoid of music we are near allied to beasts.
('34', 435, 5, 11, 1011843) To know music is to transfer it to life.
('34', 435, 5, 12, 1011884) The prevalent discord of today is an indication of our sad plight.
('34', 435, 5, 13, 1011951) There can be no swaraj where there is no harmony, no music.
('34', 435, 5, 14, 1012011) Where there is discord and everyone striking his own tune, there is bad government or anarchy.
('34', 435, 5, 15, 1012106) Work for swaraj fails to appeal to us because we have no music in us.
('34', 435, 5, 16, 1012176) When we have millions of people singing together in harmony or taking God’s name in unison, making one music, we shall have taken the first step to swaraj.
('34', 435, 5, 17, 1012332) If we cannot achieve this simple thing, how can we win swaraj?
('34', 435, 5, 18, 1012395) We have free music classes in Ahmedabad for the last three years conducted by one who is an expert.
('34', 435, 5, 19, 1012495) And yet we have to be satisfied today with a roll attendance of 10 and regular attendance of four.
('34', 435, 5, 20, 1012594) It is poor consolation indeed; but we live in hope and Dr. Hariprasad, who sees a ray of hope when he finds even one pol out of the hundreds in Ahmedabad clean and tidy, might well feel sastisfied that we have at least four regular music lovers.
('34', 435, 5, 21, 1012840) Where there is filth and squalour and misery there can be no music.
('34', 435, 5, 22, 1012908) It implies an atmosphere quite the contrary.
('34', 435, 5, 23, 1012953) If we put a broad interpretation on music, i.
('34', 435, 5, 24, 1012999) e., if we mean by it union, concord, mutual help, it may be said that in no department of life can we dispense with it.

('34', 436, 1, 19, 1014865) We shall consider music in a narrow sense to mean the ability to sing and play an instrument well while carrying a tune and marking the correct beats of time but, in its wider sense, that is to say that true music is created only when life is attuned to a single tune and a single time beat.
('34', 436, 1, 20, 1015157) Music is born only where the strings of the heart are not out of tune.
('34', 436, 1, 21, 1015228) The experiment with music will be regarded as successful one when the crores of people in the entire country will start speaking with the same voice.
('34', 436, 1, 22, 1015378) In my opinion true music is implict in khadi and the spinning wheel.
('34', 436, 1, 23, 1015447) So long as that has not been made explicit, the country is going to welcome anarchy or misrule and, it will continue to be in a state of bondage.

('34', 444, 9, 22, 1029634) The hospital that was to be opened as an all Bengal Memorial is at last opened in the ancestral property of the late Deshbandhu which he gave away to a trust.
('34', 444, 9, 23, 1029793) One of its objects was to establish a hospital for women.
('34', 444, 9, 24, 1029851) The readers are aware that nearly eight lacs of rupees were collected out of ten that the trustees had expected to be able to collect.

('34', 444, 10, 29, 1030221) Doctors, nurses and a matron have been appointed and they have taken up their duties.

('34', 445, 1, 2, 1030406) Mattresses, bed covers, napkins, screens, cases, in fact all the necessary drapery has been made of khaddar procured from the Khadi Pratishthan.
('34', 445, 2, 3, 1030551) We have named the hospital “Chittaranjan Seva Sadan”.

('34', 445, 3, 5, 1030691) The hospital started under such auspices with fairly ample funds at its disposal should grow day by day and supply the need of the middle class women of Bengal.

('34', 445, 4, 8, 1031122) WILL IT Be WORKED?
('34', 445, 5, 9, 1031141) The Kongu Velala Conference held at Pollachi, South India, passed the following resolution:
('34', 445, 6, 10, 1031233) This Conference urges that the girls and ladies of the Kongu Velala caste should consider hand spinning as part of their caste industry and that all should wear khaddar clothing.
('34', 445, 6, 11, 1031412) It further believes that charkhas are the instruments that will drive away famine from the country.
('34', 445, 7, 12, 1031512) I congratulate the Conference upon passing the resolution, but will it be accepted by those who are advised to take up hand spinning as part of their caste industry?
('34', 445, 7, 13, 1031678) And will those who voted for khaddar wear take to it?
('34', 445, 7, 14, 1031732) I suggest to the members of this Conference that unless men take to spinning themselves, they will find it difficult to persuade the women to do so.
('34', 445, 7, 15, 1031881) They will find it still more difficult to make the necessary improvements in the spinning wheels or yarn unless there be sufficient men who will become experts in spinning and make such improvements as the local wheels are capable of being adapted to.
('34', 445, 7, 16, 1032133) Hand spinning for progress depends more upon solid work than upon resolutions.
('34', 445, 7, 17, 1032212) In all constructive work resolutions have only limited use in the shape of a slight propaganda.
('34', 445, 7, 18, 1032308) It is only intelligent and sustained work that counts.

('34', 446, 2, 7, 1033386) 198. ‘HE WON’T SPIN’
('34', 446, 3, 8, 1033407) “Neither will he toil.” If the writer of the following letter 1 had toiled enough to search the pages of Young India, he would have discovered that every one of the questions raised by him has been already dealt with.
('34', 446, 3, 9, 1033625) But on the principle that as often as error is repeated truth also must be retold, I hasten for the correspondent’s sake and for the sake of those who may think like him to reply to the questions raised by him.
('34', 446, 3, 10, 1033836) Surely, when Hindus have with a deliberate and conscious effort, not by way of policy but for self purification, removed the taint of untouchability, that act will give the nation a new strength born of consciousness of having done the right thing and will therefore contribute to the attainment of swaraj.
('34', 446, 3, 11, 1034143) We are powerless today because we have lost the power of cohesion.
('34', 446, 3, 12, 1034210) When we learn to regard these five to six crores of outcastes as our own, we shall learn the rudiments of what it is to be one people.
('34', 446, 3, 13, 1034345) That one act of cleansing will probably
('34', 446, 4, 14, 1034385) 1 Not reproduced here
('34', 447, 0, 1, 1034407) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 447, 1, 2, 1034449) solve also the Hindu Muslim question.
('34', 447, 1, 3, 1034487) For in it too the corrosive poison of untouchability is consciously or unconsciously working its way.
('34', 447, 1, 4, 1034589) Hinduism must be poor stuff, if it requires to be protected by an artificial wall of untouchability.
('34', 447, 1, 5, 1034690) If untouchability and caste are convertible terms, the sooner caste perishes the better for all concerned.
('34', 447, 1, 6, 1034797) But I am satisfied that caste if it is another word for varna is a healthy institution.
('34', 447, 1, 7, 1034885) The modern caste with its arrogant exclusiveness is as good as gone.
('34', 447, 1, 8, 1034954) The innumerable sub divisions are destroying themselves with a rapidity of which we can have no conception.
('34', 447, 1, 9, 1035062) But let me repeat for the thousandth time that I have not pleaded for inter dining nor have I advocated forcible entry into temples.
('34', 447, 1, 10, 1035195) But I have said and I do repeat that temple entry cannot be denied to these countrymen of ours.
('34', 447, 1, 11, 1035291) Time for satyagraha in the matter of temple entry has not yet come.
('34', 447, 1, 12, 1035359) It is our fault and shame that the suppressed classes are living outside towns and villages and that they are leading a wretched life.
('34', 447, 1, 13, 1035494) Even as we rightly charge the English rulers for our helplessness and lack of initiative and orginality, so let us admit the guilt of the high caste Hindus in making the untouchables what they are today.
('34', 447, 1, 14, 1035698) The writer seems to admit the necessity of giving these victims of our ignorance and superstition education both mundane and spiritual.
('34', 447, 1, 15, 1035834) How is that to be done unless we freely mix with them on terms of equality?
('34', 447, 1, 16, 1035910) Indeed we need more spiritual training than they do.
('34', 447, 1, 17, 1035963) And the Alpha of our spiritual training must begin by our coming down from our Himalayan height and feeling one with them.
('34', 447, 1, 18, 1036086) The writer has likened Communists to the untouchables.
('34', 447, 1, 19, 1036141) This is pure confusion.
('34', 447, 1, 20, 1036165) The Communists are not born.
('34', 447, 1, 21, 1036194) The untouchables are.
('34', 447, 1, 22, 1036216) Communism is a creed.
('34', 447, 1, 23, 1036238) Untouchability is a disability imposed from without.
('34', 447, 1, 24, 1036291) As for me, I did not avoid the Communists during the Congress week.
('34', 447, 1, 25, 1036359) I saw them freely and had I the time, I would probably have gone to their meeting.
('34', 447, 1, 26, 1036442) They were free to join the Congress on compliance with its constitution.
('34', 447, 1, 27, 1036515) I support the cause of the un touchables because I know that we have done them a grievous wrong.
('34', 447, 1, 28, 1036612) I should support the cause of the Communists, if it commended itself to me.
('34', 447, 1, 29, 1036688) Lastly, as the correspondent believes in and wears khaddar, let him demonstrate his full faith by spinning and thus contributing to the output, be it ever so little and linking himself with the teeming millions.

('34', 448, 1, 2, 1036968) 199. A SERVANT OF INDIA
('34', 448, 2, 3, 1036992) Hanumantharao, some time member of the Servants of India Society, is dead.
('34', 448, 2, 4, 1037067) He has died a martyr to his own ideals.
('34', 448, 2, 5, 1037107) He was a votary of the nature cure cult.
('34', 448, 2, 6, 1037148) He did not believe in the use of drugs for curing the many ills that flesh is heir to.
('34', 448, 2, 7, 1037235) The only aid to nature he acknowledged was hydropathy according to the system of Louis Kuhne.
('34', 448, 2, 8, 1037329) His belief in the efficacy of this treatment bordered on religious faith.
('34', 448, 2, 9, 1037403) He dreamt of popularizing this method among the villagers.
('34', 448, 2, 10, 1037462) He practised what he preached.
('34', 448, 2, 11, 1037493) He was seriously ill a year ago.
('34', 448, 2, 12, 1037526) He underwent the water treatment and was believed to be cured.
('34', 448, 2, 13, 1037589) He was convalescing at Vizagapatam and died on 20th instant.
('34', 448, 2, 14, 1037650) Up to the last moment he remained true to his faith.
('34', 448, 2, 15, 1037703) Only a few days before his death he wrote a long letter avowing his faith and gently rebuking me, a nature cure believer like himself, for weakly taking quinine and submitting to iron and arsenic injections.
('34', 448, 2, 16, 1037911) He had expected more strength from me.
('34', 448, 2, 17, 1037950) In these days of contradiction between precept and practice, it is refreshing to find a man like Hanumantharao who would remain true to his faith even unto death.
('34', 448, 2, 18, 1038113) What if he was mistaken?
('34', 448, 2, 19, 1038138) He was a searcher after truth.
('34', 448, 2, 20, 1038169) We shall find it only by following what we hold to be true.
('34', 448, 2, 21, 1038229) Hanumantharao lives though dead, for he had realized the immortality of the spirit in the perishable body.
('34', 448, 2, 22, 1038336) Hanumantharao was a patriot.
('34', 448, 2, 23, 1038365) He loved his country with a passion not to be surpassed.
('34', 448, 2, 24, 1038422) Yet there was no bitterness in him.
('34', 448, 2, 25, 1038458) Non violence with him was a creed, not a mere policy.
('34', 448, 2, 26, 1038512) He was therefore on my unwritten list of civil resisters of the first grade.
('34', 448, 2, 27, 1038589) He had opened a little institution near Nellore where assisted by a band of co workers, he was developing khaddar and serving the so called untouchables living in their neighbourhood.
('34', 448, 2, 28, 1038773) The deceased leaves a widow who believed in her husband and who supported him in his adoption of a life of poverty and extreme simplicity.
('34', 448, 2, 29, 1038912) Young India, 25 3 1926
('34', 448, 3, 30, 1038935) 200. ‘EXERCISE THE COPYRIGHT’
('34', 448, 4, 31, 1038965) A correspondent writes:
('34', 448, 5, 32, 1038989) Your permission to newspaper proprietors to copy, if they wish, the chapters of your autobiography seems to me to be prejudicial to the circulation of Young India as well as Navajivan.
('34', 448, 5, 33, 1039174) Having observed the commercial spirit in the newspaper world, I have arrived at the opinion that it is not right for you
('34', 449, 0, 1, 1039295) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 449, 1, 2, 1039337) to permit the newspapers to copy those chapters.
('34', 449, 1, 3, 1039386) People will then for the purpose of reading the autobiography subscribe to Young India and Navajivan who are not now subscribers and read the other articles contained in them.
('34', 449, 1, 4, 1039562) Why lose this opporunity of broadcasting your message and why be a sharer in the sins of broadcasting liquor and other questionable advertisements such as French art, invigorating and vitalizing medicines, obscene books and “short stories”?
('34', 449, 1, 5, 1039803) This is not only my opinion but that of many readers of Young India.
('34', 449, 2, 6, 1039872) Whilst I appreciate the benevolent motive underlying this advice, I cannot help saying that I am unconvinced of the soundness of the advice.
('34', 449, 2, 7, 1040013) I have never yet copyrighted any of my writings.
('34', 449, 2, 8, 1040062) Tempting offers have come to me no doubt in connection with the chapters of the autobiography, if such they may be called, and I am likely to succumb to the temptation for the sake of the cause I stand for.
('34', 449, 2, 9, 1040269) But even so, I dare not be exclusive.
('34', 449, 2, 10, 1040307) Writings in the journals which I have the privilege of editing must be common property.
('34', 449, 2, 11, 1040395) Copyright is not a natural thing.
('34', 449, 2, 12, 1040429) It is a modren institution, perhaps desirable to a certain extent.
('34', 449, 2, 13, 1040496) But I have no wish to inflate the circulation of Young India or Navajivan by forbidding newspapers to copy the chapters of the autobiography.
('34', 449, 2, 14, 1040638) The message I seek to deliver through the pages of Young India or Navajivan must stand on its own bottom and I am satisfied with the number of subscribers who buy these journals for the message that they stand for and not for any temporary interest that might be created in writings such as the autobiography.
('34', 449, 2, 15, 1040948) Nor am I able to subscribe to the opinion that by not availing myself of the statutory right of prohibiting the publication of anything I may write in the pages of these journals, I become a sharer in the sins of those newspaper proprietors who take in the advertisements referred to by the correspondent.
('34', 449, 2, 16, 1041254) I do not from the bottom of my heart detest these advertisements.
('34', 449, 2, 17, 1041320) I do hold that it is wrong to conduct newspapers by the aid of these immoral advertisements.
('34', 449, 2, 18, 1041413) I do believe that if advertisements should be taken at all there should be a rigid censorship instituted by newspaper proprietors and editors themselves and that only healthy advertisements should be taken.
('34', 449, 2, 19, 1041620) But I no more become a sharer in the crime of taking immoral advertisements by refraining from making use of the law of copyright, than I do by not walking to their offices and engaging the proprietors in a duel if they will not remove the offending advertisements.
('34', 449, 2, 20, 1041886) The evil of immoral advertisements is overtaking even what are known as the most respectable newspapers and magazines.
('34', 449, 2, 21, 1042005) That evil has to be combated
('34', 450, 0, 1, 1042034) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 451
('34', 450, 1, 2, 1042079) by refining the conscience of the newspaper proprietors and eidtors.
('34', 450, 1, 3, 1042148) That refinement can come not through the influence of an amateur editor like myself but it will come when their own conscience is roused to recognition of the growing evil or when it is superimposed upon them by a government representing the people and caring for the people’s morals.

('34', 451, 12, 29, 1045821) 1 Gandhiji was in correspondence with the addressee in 1926 in connection with the holding of the Kathiawar Political Conference at Porbunder; vide “Letter to Pratapsimha”, 25 2 1926. 2 The year is determined by the reference to the Rana’s return to Porbunder and the proposed meeting of the Kathiawar Political Conference there.
('34', 452, 0, 1, 1046151) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 453
('34', 452, 1, 2, 1046196) khadi and Antyajas.
('34', 452, 1, 3, 1046216) We alone have to make it respectable.
('34', 452, 1, 4, 1046254) And if we have the faith, why should we be stopped by public criticism?
('34', 452, 1, 5, 1046326) I am not convinced by your suggestion that we should stock cotton.
('34', 452, 1, 6, 1046393) Shambhushankar seems to have done it at Gariyadhar.
('34', 452, 1, 7, 1046445) I do not think there is anything wrong about it.
('34', 452, 1, 8, 1046494) People may be encouraged to store cotton, and we may get it carded and spun for them.
('34', 452, 1, 9, 1046580) But all this should be at their expense.
('34', 452, 1, 10, 1046621) Otherwise we fail to realize the significance of the khadi movement.
('34', 452, 1, 11, 1046690) The basic motive of the khadi movement is not boycott of foreign goods but providing work for the unemployed and freeing them, as far as we can, from hunger.
('34', 452, 1, 12, 1046848) Boycott may follow as a result of this.
('34', 452, 1, 13, 1046888) If we insist on making it an end in itself we shall fail.
('34', 452, 1, 14, 1046946) If unemployment and starvation in India were not linked together as cause and effect I would take my hands off the wheel.
('34', 452, 1, 15, 1047068) We must proceed with this in view.
('34', 452, 1, 16, 1047103) Therefore our job is to make the poor produce khadi and sell it to the masses.
('34', 452, 1, 17, 1047182) Hence I do not feel concerned about the piling of khadi in Amreli; I should, if it were to be taken outside Kathiawar.
('34', 452, 1, 18, 1047301) But if it comes to a standstill I may be prepared even to export it out of the country, not to speak of Bombay and other places.
('34', 452, 1, 19, 1047430) I can therefore propose only one test.
('34', 452, 1, 20, 1047469) Whenever we produce khadi we should see whether or not we get it spun only by those poor people who do not have an alternative occupation, whether we offer them the approved rates and whether the yarn is spun diligently or reluctantly.
('34', 452, 1, 21, 1047705) If you are satisfied on these three counts you may let the work continue there.
('34', 452, 1, 22, 1047785) People were mistaken if they had set high hopes on my statements regarding Gondal and Jamnagar.

('34', 454, 4, 12, 1050551) If you want this information also substantiated by me, I shall be pleased to send you proofs.
('34', 454, 4, 13, 1050645) I also suggest to you a method that even a man in the street may adopt for verification.
('34', 454, 5, 14, 1050734) 1. Is it or is it not true that nearly 80 per cent of the population of India is agricultural and living in remote villages scattered over an area of 1,900 miles long and 1,500 miles broad?
('34', 454, 5, 15, 1050924) 2. Is it or is it not true that these peasants are living in small holdings and often as serfs of big zamindars?
('34', 454, 5, 16, 1051037) 3. Is it or is it not true that the vast majority of them have at least four idle months in the year?
('34', 454, 5, 17, 1051139) 4. Is it or is it not true that before the British rule these very people had hand spinning and industry ancillary to agriculture which supplemented the slender income they had from agricultre?
('34', 454, 5, 18, 1051333) 5. Is it or is it not true that whilst hand spinning has been entirely killed no other industry has taken its place?
('34', 454, 5, 19, 1051450) If the answer to all these questions be in the affirmative, no matter what statements might be made by anybody, these agriculturists

('34', 456, 9, 24, 1054525) But if I am to select the day of departure, I would like to leave when the Ashram school closes for a
('34', 457, 0, 1, 1054627) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 457, 1, 2, 1054669) brief vacation.
('34', 457, 1, 3, 1054685) I would not like to leave a 30 minutes’ class I am taking and which is not tax on me.
('34', 457, 1, 4, 1054771) Moreover there are small things which I would like to finish before I go.
('34', 457, 1, 5, 1054845) Thirdly, and from the point of view of health, what is most important is that the weather here is delightfully cool.
('34', 457, 1, 6, 1054962) It is unusual for this part of India at this time of the year but copious rains having fallen in Marwar, they have made the atmosphere in Gujarat exceptionally cool.
('34', 457, 1, 7, 1055128) One needs to use blankets in the morning and throughout the day there is no oppressive heat.
('34', 457, 1, 8, 1055221) This kind of weather is likely to last for some time.
('34', 457, 1, 9, 1055275) It is therefore really speaking most agreeable for me at the present time.
('34', 457, 1, 10, 1055350) Even as I am dictaing this, a cold wind is blowing upon me.
('34', 457, 1, 11, 1055410) And I cannot imagine a better climate anywhere else.
('34', 457, 1, 12, 1055463) I am walking well at least an hour daily.
('34', 457, 1, 13, 1055505) I am eating well and speaking well.
('34', 457, 1, 14, 1055541) I am putting on weight at the rate of nearly one pound per week.

('34', 468, 0, 1, 1074412) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 469
('34', 468, 1, 2, 1074457) 225. SOME QUESTIONS ON RELIGIOUS ISSUES 1
('34', 468, 2, 3, 1074499) A friend has asked me questions on some religious issues.
('34', 468, 2, 4, 1074557) I continually receive such questions, and feel some hesitation in answering them so often.
('34', 468, 2, 5, 1074648) But it does not seem proper not to answer them either, since I have thought about these matters and come to certain conclusions.
('34', 468, 2, 6, 1074777) I therefore answer the following questions to the best of my ability and understanding.
('34', 468, 3, 7, 1074865) Q. What are your views about the yajnas which used to be performed in ancient times?
('34', 468, 3, 8, 1074950) Do such yajnas purify the air?
('34', 468, 3, 9, 1074981) Is there a place for them in our times?
('34', 468, 3, 10, 1075021) Some groups are reviving yajnas; will their revival be of any benefit?
('34', 468, 3, 11, 1075092) Yajna is a beautiful and highly suggestive word.
('34', 468, 3, 12, 1075141) Its meaning, therefore, can change and expand with the growth of our knowledge and experience or with changing times.
('34', 468, 3, 13, 1075259) The word can be interpreted to mean worship, sacrifice or service of others.
('34', 468, 3, 14, 1075336) Understood in this sense, yajna always deserves to be revived.
('34', 468, 3, 15, 1075399) But the yajnas of various types, that is, rituals of various kinds described as yajnas in Shastras, do not deserve to be, and in fact cannot be, revived.
('34', 468, 3, 16, 1075553) Some of these rituals are harmful, and it is also doubtful whether in Vedic times they were understood inthe sense which we attach to them now.
('34', 468, 3, 17, 1075697) Whether or not this doubt is justified, some of these rituals are repugnant to our reason and moral sense.
('34', 468, 3, 18, 1075804) Anthropologists tell us that there were human sacrifice in old days.
('34', 468, 3, 19, 1075873) Can we conceive of such a sacrifice being performed now?
('34', 468, 3, 20, 1075930) Anyone who proposes to perform the horse sacrifice would make himself an object of ridicule.
('34', 468, 3, 21, 1076023) We need not go into the question whether yajnas purify air, for it is irrelevant to ask, in connection with a religious ritual, whether it results in such a trivial benefit as the purification of air.
('34', 468, 3, 22, 1076224) Modern physical science can give us better help in that regard.
('34', 468, 3, 23, 1076288) The essen tial principles of Shastras are one thing [and the practice based on them another].
('34', 468, 3, 24, 1076382) The principles are the same at all times and in all places.
('34', 468, 3, 25, 1076442) But the practices based on them vary from age to age and country to country.
('34', 468, 4, 26, 1076519) Q. It is generally believed that to be born as a human being is a rare privilege and that, therefore, we would occupy our time in singing praises of God.
('34', 468, 4, 27, 1076673) If we fail to make the right use of our present opportunity, we shall once again have to go through the cycle of births in 84 lakhs of different species.
('34', 468, 4, 28, 1076827) What is the truth in
('34', 468, 5, 29, 1076848) 1 This was abridged and translated by Mahadev Desai and later published in Young India, 13 5 1926, under the sub titles “Sacrifice, Old and New”, “Place of Sanskrit”, and “Self help and Mutual Help”
('34', 469, 0, 1, 1077047) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 469, 1, 2, 1077089) this belief?
('34', 469, 1, 3, 1077102) Kabir also says in a song:
('34', 469, 2, 4, 1077129) Wake up, O brother, says Kabir, Else you are doomed to the round of eighty four lakhs of births; You may be born a swine or a fowl, And will suffer their fate, my brother.
('34', 469, 2, 5, 1077301) What lesson should we learn from this?
('34', 469, 3, 6, 1077340) I believe this to be quite true.
('34', 469, 3, 7, 1077373) One is born as a human being after going through the cycle of births in innumerable species, and moksha or complete deliverance from the pairs of opposites can be attainedonly through life in a human body.
('34', 469, 3, 8, 1077579) If in the ultimate analysis there is only one atman, its going through the cycle of countless species in the form of innumerable lives should not seem impossible or wonderful.
('34', 469, 3, 9, 1077755) Our reason, too, can accept the idea, and some persons even remember their past lives.
('34', 469, 4, 10, 1077842) Q. Between a yogi rising to the state of samadhi 1 through pranayama 2 and one who acquires control of the senses, who attains higher spiritual good?
('34', 469, 4, 11, 1077992) This question presupposes a contradiction between self control and yoga.
('34', 469, 4, 12, 1078065) In truth, one of them is the cause of other; or, rather, they are complements of each other.
('34', 469, 4, 13, 1078158) Samadhi without self control is no better than the sleep of Kumbhakarna 3. Without samadhi, again, self control is difficult to attain.
('34', 469, 4, 14, 1078294) Samadhi, in this context, should be understood ina wide sense, not inthe limited sense of the Hathayogi’s 4
('34', 469, 5, 15, 1078402) samadhi.
('34', 469, 5, 16, 1078411) In truth, this latter is not essential for attaining control of the senses.
('34', 469, 5, 17, 1078487) It may be a help, but in the present age ordinary samadhi is the best for us.
('34', 469, 5, 18, 1078565) Ordinary samadhi means the capacity to be absorbed in the chosen task.
('34', 469, 5, 19, 1078636) It should not be forgotton that yogic achievements are of no use if not accompanied by control of the senses.
('34', 469, 6, 20, 1078746) Q. Suppose that a person believes in self help, himself works in the fields and grows foodgrains for his use, makes with his own hands farm implements, like the plough, does the carpenter’s work, weaves his own cloth, even builds his own house, in short produces by his own efforts everything which he requires and does not employ other’s labour for that purpose.
('34', 469, 6, 21, 1079110) Would he be right or wrong to do this?
('34', 469, 6, 22, 1079149) What is your definition of a man of self help?
('34', 469, 7, 23, 1079196) 1 A state of thought free awareness 2 Breath control 3 In the Ramayana.
('34', 469, 7, 24, 1079268) He was Ravana’s brother, and was asleep and awake by turns for six months at a stretch.
('34', 469, 7, 25, 1079356) 4 A yogi who relies on certain physical techniques
('34', 470, 0, 1, 1079407) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 471
('34', 470, 1, 2, 1079452) Self help means the ability to stand on one’s own feet without help from others.
('34', 470, 1, 3, 1079533) This does not mean that one should be indifferent to such help, or decline it when offered or never desire it or ask for it.
('34', 470, 1, 4, 1079658) But a farmer who, though wanting and seeking others’ help, can preserve his composure and self respect when it is refused, is a man of self help.
('34', 470, 1, 5, 1079804) A farmer who, though he can get others’ help, himself attends to all the operations of tilling the land, sowing and reaping, himself makes the required implements, himself weaves cloth for his use from yarn spun by himself, stitches his own clothes, cooks his own food and labours to build a house for himself—such a farmer is either stupid or self conceited or is just a savage.
('34', 470, 1, 6, 1080184) Self help necessarily implies the yajna of bodily labour, which means that everyone should do such work to earn his livelihood.
('34', 470, 1, 7, 1080312) Any person, therefore, who works for eight hours in the fields is entitled to the services of a weaver, a carpenter, a blacksmith and a mason.
('34', 470, 1, 8, 1080455) It is his duty to seek their services, and he will get them easily enough.
('34', 470, 1, 9, 1080530) In return, carpenters, blacksmiths and other artisans get foodgrains produced by the farmer’s labour.
('34', 470, 1, 10, 1080632) An eye which hopes to do without help from the hand does not practise self help, it is just too proud.
('34', 470, 1, 11, 1080735) As the different limbs of our body practise self help in regard to their own functions, and yet are of service to others because they help one another and dependent on others because they are helped by one another, so we, the thirty crore limbs of the body that is India, should follow the duty of self help in our respective spheres of work and, to demonstrate that we are limbs of the same nation, exchange help with one another.
('34', 470, 1, 12, 1081167) Only then shall we have built up a nation and proved our claim to be patriots.
('34', 470, 2, 13, 1081246) Q. For the purpose of marriage ceremonies, sandhya 1, yajna rituals and prayers, Sanskrit verses are used in our age.
('34', 470, 2, 14, 1081364) The verses are recited by the person officiating on these occasions and those who have engaged him join him in reciting the verses without understanding their meaning.
('34', 470, 2, 15, 1081532) Sanskrit is no longer our mother tongue.
('34', 470, 2, 16, 1081573) Many institutions ask the people to use that language for prayers, sandhya, yajna rituals, etc.
('34', 470, 2, 17, 1081669) But the people do not understand the language.
('34', 470, 2, 18, 1081716) How, then, can they concentrate attention on what is being recited?
('34', 470, 2, 19, 1081784) Sanskrit, moreover, is a difficult language.
('34', 470, 2, 20, 1081829) Learning the verses by heart and remembering their meanings seems to me, therefore, a double burden.
('34', 470, 2, 21, 1081930) When Sanskrit was people’s mother tongue, all their work was done in it and that was but right.
('34', 470, 2, 22, 1082026) That is no longer the position now.
('34', 470, 2, 23, 1082062) It helps people to use their mother tongue for all their work, but our present practice is different.
('34', 470, 2, 24, 1082164) The religious ceremonies mentioned above are performed in Sanskrit among
('34', 470, 3, 25, 1082237) 1 Morning and evening prayers
('34', 471, 0, 1, 1082267) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 471, 1, 2, 1082309) the general public.
('34', 471, 1, 3, 1082329) My view is that Sanskrit should be used in all Hindu religious ceremonies.
('34', 471, 1, 4, 1082404) However good a translation, it cannot give us the meaning which lies in the sounds of certain words in the original.
('34', 471, 1, 5, 1082521) Moreover, by translating into regional languages, and remaining content with such translations, verses which belong to a language which has acquired a certain refinement over thousands of years and in which those verses have always been recited, we diminish the air of solemnity which attaches to them.
('34', 471, 1, 6, 1082824) But I have no doubt at all in my mind that the meaning of every verse and every step in the ceremony should be explained in their own language to the people for whose benefit they are being recited or performed.
('34', 471, 1, 7, 1083036) It is also my view that the education of every Hindu is incomplete without an elementary knowledge of Sanskrit.
('34', 471, 1, 8, 1083148) I simply cannot conceive the continued existence of Hinduism without a widespread knowledge of Sanskrit.
('34', 471, 1, 9, 1083253) The language has been made difficult by the type of curriculum we follow in teaching it, in itself it is not difficult at all.
('34', 471, 1, 10, 1083380) Even if it is, the practice of dharma is still more difficult and, therefore, to those who wish to follow it in life the means of doing so should seem easy, however difficult they may actually be.
('34', 471, 2, 11, 1083577) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 28 3 1926
('34', 471, 3, 12, 1083614) 226. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('34', 471, 4, 13, 1083641) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 28, 192[6] 1
('34', 471, 5, 14, 1083679) BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS, I have your letter.
('34', 471, 5, 15, 1083718) A telegram has just arrived from Jamnalal telling me that I may leave this place after the 16th of April.
('34', 471, 5, 16, 1083824) At present we have very nice weather here.

('34', 471, 5, 18, 1083944) Please believe me I would do my utmost if I could bring both the parties 2 together.

('34', 484, 1, 2, 1103447) 246. MY POLITICAL PROGRAMME
('34', 484, 2, 3, 1103475) I gratefully reproduce the following letter received from American friends accompanying a gift of 145 dollars:
('34', 484, 3, 4, 1103586) The signers of the accompanying note are a group of Bostonians and two Westerners who owe you much.
('34', 484, 3, 5, 1103686) Accept the gift we venture to send a very inadequate expression of our will to ally ourselves with your work.
('34', 484, 3, 6, 1103796) Small as they are, for some of us the gifts have meant sacrifices.
('34', 484, 3, 7, 1103863) We should be glad to have the money used in that part of your work which most directly appeals to us, that is in the interests of the untouchables and of Hindu Muslim unity.
('34', 484, 3, 8, 1104037) Dean Simonds and some of the other signers feel, like Professor Hocking, too little informed as to conditions in India to be quite ready to accept in full your political programme.
('34', 484, 3, 9, 1104218) We all, however, heartily wish to have a part in the work I have mentioned.
('34', 484, 4, 10, 1104294) God, who is with you, will surely bring to India the better day of which you are the prophet.
('34', 484, 4, 11, 1104388) Will you not pray sometimes for this America, no less in need of His help?
('34', 484, 4, 12, 1104463) I have told them that in accordance with their wishes the amount would be evenly divided between the two activities.
('34', 484, 4, 13, 1104580) But on receiving the letter I could not help feeling sad that even among extremely sympathetic and cultured American friends the movement is so little understood.
('34', 484, 4, 14, 1104743) When, therefore, American friends visit me and ask me how they can help India, I tell them to study the movement not superficially, not from newspapers, not as globe trotters in a hurry, but as serious students by accurate observation and by gleaning information from all sides and all parties.
('34', 484, 4, 15, 1105038) My political programme is extremely simple.
('34', 484, 4, 16, 1105082) If the donors had added the spinning wheel to untouchability and unity, they would have practically completed it.
('34', 484, 4, 17, 1105196) My opinion is becoming daily more and more confirmed that we shall achieve our real freedom only by effort from within, i.e., by self purification and self help, and therefore by the strictest adherence to truth and non violence.
('34', 484, 4, 18, 1105426) Civil disobedience is no doubt there in the background.
('34', 484, 4, 19, 1105482) But civil disobedience asks for and needs not a single farthing for its support.
('34', 484, 4, 20, 1105563) It needs and asks for stout hearts with a faith that will not flinch from any danger and will shine the brightest in the face of severest trial.
('34', 484, 4, 21, 1105708) Civil disobedience is a terrifying synonym for suffering.
('34', 484, 4, 22, 1105766) But it is better often to understand the terrible nature of a thing if people will truly appreciate its benignant counterpart.
('34', 484, 4, 23, 1105893) Disobedience is a right that belongs to every human being and it becomes a sacred duty when it
('34', 485, 0, 1, 1105988) 486 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 485, 1, 2, 1106030) springs from civility or, which is the same thing, love.
('34', 485, 1, 3, 1106087) The anti untouchability reformers are offering civil disobedience against entrenched orthodoxy.
('34', 485, 1, 4, 1106183) Protagonists of Hindu Muslim unity are resisting with their whole soul those who will divide classes and sects.
('34', 485, 1, 5, 1106295) Just as there may be this resistance against those who will hinder the removal of untouchability or promotion of unity, so must there be resistance against a rule that is stunting India’s manhood.
('34', 485, 1, 6, 1106492) It is daily grinding down the starving millions of this vast country.
('34', 485, 1, 7, 1106562) Heedless of future consequences the rulers are pursuing a course of conduct regarding intoxicating drinks and drugs that must, if it remains unchecked, corrupt the toilers of the land and make posterity ashamed of us who are making use of this immoral source of revenue for educating our children.
('34', 485, 1, 8, 1106860) But the condition of this terrible resistance against orthodoxy, resistance against enemies of unity, and resistance against Government—is possible of fulfilment only by a strong, and if need be a long, course of self purification and suffering.
('34', 485, 1, 9, 1107106) Young India, 1 4 1926
('34', 485, 2, 10, 1107128) 247. GOLDEN SLIPPERS V. RAGS
('34', 485, 3, 11, 1107157) They are for religion when in rags and contempt: but I am for him when he walks in his golden slippers, in the sunshine, and with applause.
('34', 485, 3, 12, 1107297) Thus ended Mr. By Ends his oration in support of his theory that the priest and the trader may be considered honest, even whilst the one tempers the scriptures to suit his audience and the other tempers truth to win custom.
('34', 485, 3, 13, 1107521) Mr. By Ends had the support of his distinguished friends Messrs Hold the World, Money Love and others.
('34', 485, 3, 14, 1107624) Overwhel med though Christian and Hopeful were by the orations of By Ends and Company, they stood their ground and with the whole power of their being defended their faith in religion especially when it came it came in rags and contempt.
('34', 485, 3, 15, 1107862) They had before them the finished act of Faithful who never flinched though he was tortured to death by the inhabitants of the town of Vanity.
('34', 485, 3, 16, 1108005) Almost similarly did Sjt.
('34', 485, 3, 17, 1108031) Rajagopalachari defend patriotism in rags and in contempt at the Bihar Vidyapith Convocation.
('34', 485, 3, 18, 1108125) He said: This Vidyapith is alive by the strength and faith of a few faithful men.
('34', 485, 3, 19, 1108207) It is struggling hard for its existence.
('34', 485, 3, 20, 1108248) It cannot boast of the rich appointments and shining splendours of the universities and colleges of the Government.
('34', 485, 3, 21, 1108364) No wonder they are splendid and no wonder that our Vidyapith is like unto a rag as compared with the silken robes of royalty.
('34', 485, 3, 22, 1108490) But ours is a yellow rag that serves its purpose and
('34', 486, 0, 1, 1108543) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 487
('34', 486, 1, 2, 1108588) clothes the naked sannyasi; it is clean and it is dear to us.
('34', 486, 2, 3, 1108650) No silken robes certainly, no golden slippers for the graduates of the Vidyapith, no shining metal chain for the Vice Chancellor.
('34', 486, 2, 4, 1108780) He must bear the burden of the rough khaddar to be woven and spun by the hardened fingers of the toiling spinners and weavers and the graduates must be content to bear the burden of willing service of the masses if they are to live true to the motto of their University.
('34', 486, 2, 5, 1109051) They belong to a Civil Service at the end of which the only pension may be ever recurring malaria, tuberculosis or some such disease, a mark of unremitting service in the swamps inhabited by the half starved millions who are made to find the wherewithal to build New Delhi, to train soldiers for the suppresion of their liberty and to instruct in palatial buildings young men and even young women in the art of ruling these millions The conductors of the Vidyapith had arranged a khaddar exhibition at the time of the annual ceremony.
('34', 486, 2, 6, 1109586) I gave last week extracts from the speech of Satis Babu who opened the Exhibition.
('34', 486, 2, 7, 1109669) This week I reproduce extracts from Sjt.
('34', 486, 2, 8, 1109710) Rajagopalachari’s address.
('34', 486, 2, 9, 1109737) There is food enough in both for young India to ponder over and digest.
('34', 486, 2, 10, 1109809) These national institutions should exist even though professors and teachers have to live from hand to mouth and even though the pupils may be counted by the digits of one hand.
('34', 486, 2, 11, 1109987) Only the teachers and the pupils must be true to the incredibly simple ideals, viz., truth and non violence expressed through the spinning wheel, purification of Hinduism by removing the taint of untouchability, and consoli dation of India by striving for the heart unity of different sections professing different faiths or subfaiths.
('34', 486, 2, 12, 1110323) National education must therefore respond to these needs and aspirations.
('34', 486, 2, 13, 1110397) A national University that would tamper with the ideal for the sake of gaining numbers will have sold its heritage for a mess of pottage and will deserve to die.
('34', 486, 2, 14, 1110559) The Bihar Vidyapith has been holding on to the ideal in the face of tremendous odds.
('34', 486, 2, 15, 1110644) I know its struggles.
('34', 486, 2, 16, 1110666) Bihar is a poor country but that does not mean that it has not its rich zamindars or its quota of rich enterprising men from other provinces who are adding to their riches by their operations in Bihar.
('34', 486, 2, 17, 1110868) Let all these examine the claim of the Vidyapith as stated in the annual report read before the Convocation and help if they find the claim to be established and if they are of opinion that the ideal I have just named is an ideal worth
('34', 487, 0, 1, 1111104) 488 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 487, 1, 2, 1111146) living for and dying for, an ideal which it would be well for the youth of the country to have instilled into their hearts.

('34', 487, 6, 8, 1111491) 249. NOTES
('34', 487, 7, 9, 1111502) BENGAL’S WORTHY EXAMPLE
('34', 487, 8, 10, 1111526) I wonder whether khadi lovers have noticed the interesting fact that out of all the povinces, Bengal alone has steadily refused to depend upon customers outside Bengal for the sale of her khadi.
('34', 487, 8, 11, 1111721) Although her production has been uniformly progressive, she has sold all her khadi in Bengal.
('34', 487, 8, 12, 1111815) It is the most proper way of handing this great problem.
('34', 487, 8, 13, 1111872) Deshbandhu whilst he was in Darjeeling used to tell me that the hope of Bengal leading the way in the matter of khadi as in many other matters was very great because of the interest the middle class people took in public matters.
('34', 487, 8, 14, 1112102) He said that he expected to reach the masses through the middle class who will not only be the first wearers of khadi but who will also be his first voluntary spinners.
('34', 487, 8, 15, 1112271) And he expected khadi and the wheel to permeate the masses through the influence of the middle class.
('34', 487, 8, 16, 1112373) That phenomenon seems to be taking place in Bengal today on a larger scale than in any other province.
('34', 487, 8, 17, 1112476) The two large khadi organizers—the Khadi Pratishthan and the Abhoy Ashram—have somehow or other set their face resolutely against sending their khadi outside Bengal for sale.
('34', 487, 8, 18, 1112651) The result is that they weave khadi according to the requirements of the middle class.
('34', 487, 8, 19, 1112738) Hence they are able to check themselves from time to time and are obliged to keep up a high level and their sales departments are as well organized as their production depots.
('34', 487, 8, 20, 1112914) I feel that if the workers all over India will copy the example of Bengal and organize themselves for local sales, much time and money will be saved and the progress of
('34', 487, 9, 21, 1113083) 1 Not reproduced here
('34', 488, 0, 1, 1113105) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 489
('34', 488, 1, 2, 1113150) khadi will be much more rapid.
('34', 488, 2, 3, 1113181) BEZVADA MUNICIPALITY AND KHADDAR
('34', 488, 3, 4, 1113214) The following report 1 from the Bezwada Municipality will be read with interest: This is a creditable record.
('34', 488, 3, 5, 1113324) The Municipality can easily quintuple the output of yarn by introducing the takli which leaves no room for excuse on the part of boards, teachers or pupils.
('34', 488, 3, 6, 1113481) The takli means practically no cost, no taking up of space, and no trouble of breakage of parts.
('34', 488, 4, 7, 1113578) NOT AVAILABLE
('34', 488, 5, 8, 1113592) A U.P. correspondent writes:
('34', 488, 6, 9, 1113621) I find here a great demand for khaddar among vakils.
('34', 488, 6, 10, 1113674) I sold some.
('34', 488, 6, 11, 1113687) They complained that they had no khaddar store in their town and told me they wanted to collect Rs. 5,000 and form a company.
('34', 488, 6, 12, 1113813) I hope the proposed company will be floated.
('34', 488, 6, 13, 1113858) I had complaints of this nature during the Bihar tour.
('34', 488, 6, 14, 1113913) The reason why the country is not dotted with khadi stores is that there is as yet not enough demand for khadi to warrant such stores.
('34', 488, 6, 15, 1114048) Experience shows that when such stores are opened, and for want of regular propaganda fail to be self supporting and are therefore closed after a time, the money invested is lost and the movement is lost and the movement is discredited.
('34', 488, 6, 16, 1114285) The better thing therefore is for the All India Spinners’ Association agents to keep in touch with khaddar lovers, advertise specimens and prices and periodically hawk khaddar in the likeliest place.
('34', 488, 6, 17, 1114485) When they find a place with a regular and large enough demand, they may advise local moneyed men to open khaddar store whose business will be to carry on regular propaganda.

('34', 488, 8, 21, 1114855) They need not cost much and might even be made self supporting.

('34', 488, 8, 23, 1115061) They have, when they are well managed, a great educational value.

('34', 490, 1, 2, 1116709) 252. LETTER TO F. A. BUSH
('34', 490, 2, 3, 1116735) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 1, 1926
('34', 490, 3, 4, 1116768) DEAR FRIEND,
('34', 490, 4, 5, 1116781) I thank you for your letter.
('34', 490, 4, 6, 1116810) It is perfectly true that very often things Indian are misreported and misrepresented.
('34', 490, 4, 7, 1116897) In the instance you have quoted, however, the President of the Congress is correctly reported.
('34', 490, 4, 8, 1116992) She did advocate a national militia.
('34', 490, 4, 9, 1117029) As a reformer wanting the whole world to accept Non violence as its final creed, I do not hesitate to appear on platforms where even direct violence may be preached.
('34', 490, 4, 10, 1117195) I no more indentify myself with that preaching than I identify myself with all the violence that goes on in the world being in it.
('34', 490, 4, 11, 1117326) I hold that it is enough if I dissociate myself from every form of violence, mentally and physically, and express my disapproval whenever the occasion requires it.
('34', 490, 4, 12, 1117490) I do not know whether you know that the Congress creed is ‘attainment of swaraj by peaceful and legitimate means’.
('34', 490, 4, 13, 1117605) Violence is therefore eschewed in its entirety in the national programme.
('34', 490, 4, 14, 1117679) But I must at the same own that it does not mean that on the Congress platform people may not advocate the formation of a national militia for purposes of defence.
('34', 490, 4, 15, 1117843) From my own standpoint, a national militia is not necessary but people who do not believe in Non violence as their final creed cannot possibly be made non violent.
('34', 490, 4, 16, 1118007) The spread of non violence depends upon cultivation of public opinion.
('34', 490, 4, 17, 1118078) Personally I am satisfied that that spirit is daily growing in spite of appearances to the contrary.
('34', 490, 5, 18, 1118179) Your sincerely, A. BUSH, ESQ MORDEN, SURREY ENGLAND
('34', 490, 6, 19, 1118231) From a photostat: S. N. 12456

('34', 492, 1, 2, 1119498) 255. LETTER TO S. P. ANDREWS DUBE
('34', 492, 2, 3, 1119532) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 1, 1926
('34', 492, 3, 4, 1119565) MY DEAR DUBE, I have your letter.
('34', 492, 3, 5, 1119599) I do not know where they are going to put me in Mussoorie.
('34', 492, 3, 6, 1119658) The whole arrangement is being made by Messrs Birla and Jamnalalji Bajaj.
('34', 492, 3, 7, 1119732) But I think that when I reach Mussoorie, I shall find you there, when you will tell me all about your sad experiences.
('34', 492, 3, 8, 1119851) Ramdas has just come here from Amreli.
('34', 492, 3, 9, 1119890) I am showing your letter to him.
('34', 492, 4, 10, 1119923) Yours sincerely, S. P. ANDREWS DUBE, ESQ.
('34', 492, 4, 11, 1119965) SERVANTS OF INDIA SOCIETY LUCKNOW
('34', 492, 5, 12, 1119999) From a microfilm: S.N. 19403
('34', 492, 6, 13, 1120028) 256. LETTER TO BINODE BEHARI DUTT
('34', 492, 7, 14, 1120062) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 1, 1926
('34', 492, 8, 15, 1120095) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter and your book on Town Planning in Ancient India for which I thank you.
('34', 492, 8, 16, 1120198) I wish I could make a promise that I would read your book at an early date but it is really not possible.
('34', 492, 8, 17, 1120304) All my time is filled up with the immediate work before me.
('34', 492, 8, 18, 1120364) But I am going to keep your book in front of me so that whenever I can steal in a minute I could have an idea of its contents.
('34', 492, 9, 19, 1120491) Yours sincerely, PROF.
('34', 492, 9, 20, 1120514) BINODE BEHARI DUTT 4/1 A, BADHAPRASAD LANE CALCUTTA
('34', 492, 10, 21, 1120566) From a microfilm: S.N. 19404

('34', 493, 1, 2, 1120637) 257. LETTER TO JANG BAHADUR SINGH
('34', 493, 2, 3, 1120671) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 1, 1926
('34', 493, 3, 4, 1120704) DEAR FRIEND,
('34', 493, 4, 5, 1120717) I have your letter and the cutting.
('34', 493, 4, 6, 1120753) In my opinion it would be much better for you to see Lalaji and Pandit Santanam and make a public appeal in co operation with them.
('34', 493, 4, 7, 1120885) I am quite certain that the institution should live but how to do it depends upon local circumstances.
('34', 493, 4, 8, 1120988) People would undoubtedly want to know what Lalaji and Pandit Santanam have to say.
('34', 493, 5, 9, 1121071) Yours sincerely, JANG BAHADUR SINGH, ESQ.
('34', 493, 5, 10, 1121113) EDITOR, “NATION” RAILWAY ROAD LAHORE
('34', 493, 6, 11, 1121150) From a microfilm: S.N. 19405
('34', 493, 7, 12, 1121179) 258. LETTER TO REV.
('34', 493, 7, 13, 1121199) JOHN M. DARLINGTON
('34', 493, 8, 14, 1121218) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 1, 1926
('34', 493, 9, 15, 1121251) DEAR FRIEND,
('34', 493, 10, 16, 1121264) I thank you for your letter.
('34', 493, 10, 17, 1121293) I remember our meeting.
('34', 493, 10, 18, 1121317) The incident referred to by you has never happened.
('34', 493, 10, 19, 1121369) I do not know where the report occurs.
('34', 493, 10, 20, 1121408) Whilst I have the highest regard for the teachings of Jesus, I have never held the belief attributed to me.
('34', 493, 11, 21, 1121516) Yours sincerely, REV.
('34', 493, 11, 22, 1121538) JOHN M. DARLINGTON 14 2, SUDDER STREET CALCUTTA
('34', 493, 12, 23, 1121586) From a photostat: S.N. 19406
('34', 494, 0, 1, 1121615) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 495
('34', 494, 1, 2, 1121660) 259. LETTER TO S. V. VENKATANARASAYYAN
('34', 494, 2, 3, 1121699) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 1, 1926
('34', 494, 3, 4, 1121732) DEAR FRIEND,
('34', 494, 4, 5, 1121745) I have your letter.
('34', 494, 4, 6, 1121765) I do not think that it is necessary to forget one’s own faith in order to be tolerant towards the rest.
('34', 494, 4, 7, 1121869) In fact, tolerance loses its value when one’s own faith is forgotten.
('34', 494, 4, 8, 1121939) In my opinion, tolerance requires the same respect to be paid to another’s faith as we claim for our own.
('34', 494, 4, 9, 1122045) I am of opinion that God can be reached without a mediator.
('34', 494, 5, 10, 1122105) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('34', 494, 5, 11, 1122127) S. V. VENKATANARASAYYAN 7, MILLER ROAD KILPAUK, MADRAS
('34', 494, 6, 12, 1122182) From a photostat: S.N. 19407
('34', 494, 7, 13, 1122211) 260. LETTER TO KALISHANKER CHAKRAVARTI
('34', 494, 8, 14, 1122250) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 1, 1926
('34', 494, 9, 15, 1122283) DEAR FRIEND,
('34', 494, 10, 16, 1122296) I have your letter regarding “widow marriage”.
('34', 494, 10, 17, 1122343) Don’t you see the fallacy underlying your letter?
('34', 494, 10, 18, 1122393) Could you consider that to be marriage where the girl knows nothing about what a husband can be, perhaps, she has not even seen the man who is to be her partner in life and where they have not even lived together for one single night?
('34', 494, 10, 19, 1122628) I know nothing in Hinduism to warrant such a connection being accepted as marriage.
('34', 494, 10, 20, 1122712) Then again, what is the use of defending widowhood of girls of tender age under plea of advocating purity on the part of men?
('34', 494, 10, 21, 1122838) The latter should certainly be advocated but it cannot be used in order to cover the wrong heaped upon the fair sex.
('34', 494, 10, 22, 1122955) The sanctity of widowhood must be felt by the widow, cannot be imposed upon her.
('34', 494, 10, 23, 1123036) Divorce and other irregularities going on in the West have surely nothing to do with the very simple question of doing elementary justice to the thousands of our own sisters.
('34', 494, 10, 24, 1123211) Hinduism is in
('34', 495, 0, 1, 1123226) 496 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('34', 495, 1, 2, 1123268) grave danger of being undermined by our own fanaticism and the habit of defending every practice of Hinduism no matter how repugnant it may be to the moral sense of the world.
('34', 495, 2, 3, 1123444) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('34', 495, 2, 4, 1123466) KALISHANKER CHAKRAVARTI JYOTI, CHITTAGONG
('34', 495, 3, 5, 1123508) From a photostat: S.N. 19408
('34', 495, 4, 6, 1123537) 261. LETTER TO SUDHANSHU KUMARI GHOSH
('34', 495, 5, 7, 1123575) ASHRAM,
('34', 495, 6, 8, 1123583) April 1, 1926
('34', 495, 7, 9, 1123597) DEAR FRIEND,
('34', 495, 8, 10, 1123610) I have your letter.
('34', 495, 8, 11, 1123630) It is very sad to find that Sarat Babu is fasting.
('34', 495, 8, 12, 1123681) Somehow or other I think that it is quite wrong and I hope that long before this reaches you he has broken his fast.
('34', 495, 9, 13, 1123798) Yours sincerely, SHRIMATI SUDHANSHU KUMARI GHOSH BARISAL
('34', 495, 10, 14, 1123855) From a microfilm: S.N. 19887
('34', 495, 11, 15, 1123884) 262. LETTER TO KISHORELAL MASHRUWALA
('34', 495, 12, 16, 1123921) ASHRAM, Thursday, Chaitra Vad 3 [April 1, 1926]
('34', 495, 13, 17, 1123969) KISHORELAL,
('34', 495, 14, 18, 1123981) I keep getting news about Gomati 1. Why can you not have a curtain to ward off mosquitoes?
('34', 495, 14, 19, 1124072) It is surprising that you should lose appetite there.
('34', 495, 14, 20, 1124126) We do use a number of foreign articles; try lithia water.
('34', 495, 14, 21, 1124184) Lithia water is a mineral product.
('34', 495, 14, 22, 1124219) Borodada used it regularly.
('34', 495, 14, 23, 1124247) Andrews had strongly recommended it to me, but I did not try it, because I never felt the need.
('34', 495, 14, 24, 1124343) But it would be good if Gomati tries it.
('34', 495, 14, 25, 1124384) The loss of appe tite must be due to the water.
('34', 495, 14, 26, 1124432) I have not forgotten the Nasik pinjrapole which you have mentioned.
('34', 495, 14, 27, 1124500) Its manager had seen me.
('34', 495, 14, 28, 1124525) I had no intention of opening a branch of the Satyagraha
('34', 495, 15, 29, 1124582) 1 Wife of the addressee
('34', 496, 0, 1, 1124606) VOL. 34: 11 FEBRUARY, 1926 1 APRIL, 1926 497
('34', 496, 1, 2, 1124651) Ashram, but Jamnalalji did suggest that we should acquire a plot in a healthy locality where ailing people could live and we did consider Nasik in this connection.
('34', 496, 1, 3, 1124815) If we keep only sick people in the place they will not be able to render such service.
('34', 496, 1, 4, 1124902) Therefore for the present we cannot busy ourselves with any other activity where we acquire a site.
('34', 496, 1, 5, 1125002) I am certainly here till the 15th.
('34', 496, 1, 6, 1125037) The date of departure will be fixed for some date after that.
('34', 496, 2, 7, 1125099) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 19401
('34', 496, 3, 8, 1125144) 263. LETTER TO P. S. VARIER
('34', 496, 4, 9, 1125172) [On or after April 1, 1926]
('34', 496, 5, 10, 1125200) DEAR FRIEND,
('34', 496, 6, 11, 1125213) I have your letter enclosing a copy of your Ashtangashareer for which I thank you.
('34', 496, 6, 12, 1125296) I should inform you that Young India is not a reviewing paper.
('34', 496, 6, 13, 1125359) Occasionally it notices books that are of superlative value and concern the subjects with which the writings in Young India are generally occupied.
('34', 496, 7, 14, 1125507) Yours, P. S. VARIER KOTTAKKAI
('34', 496, 8, 15, 1125537) From a microfilm: S.N. 19888
('34', 496, 9, 16, 1125566) 264. LETTER TO MIRZA KAZIM ALI
('34', 496, 10, 17, 1125597) [On or after April 1, 1926]
('34', 496, 11, 18, 1125625) DEAR FRIEND,
('34', 496, 12, 19, 1125638) I have your letter.
('34', 496, 12, 20, 1125658) I am getting quite well now.
('34', 496, 12, 21, 1125687) It is difficult for me to send Young India free.
('34', 496, 12, 22, 1125736) You should really go to some reading room and read it there.
('34', 496, 12, 23, 1125797) There are thousands of poor students and it is beyond my capacity to supply them all free copies.
('34', 496, 13, 24, 1125895) MIRZA KAZIM ALI STUDENT HYDERABAD
